body: Skip to contentSkip to site indexSearch & Section NavigationSection NavigationSEARCHU.S.InternationalCanadaEspañol中文 Today’s PaperSíguenos: FacebookTwitterNew York Times HomepageSection NavigationWorldU.S.PoliticsN.Y.BusinessOpinionScienceHealthSportsArtsBooksStyleFoodTravelMagazineReal EstateCookingThe AthleticWirecutterGamesNewsWorldBusinessArtsLifestyleOpinionCookingGamesWirecutterThe AthleticHighlightsPhotoCreditAgence France-Presse — Getty Images‘No se trata de otro golpe como los de siempre’: lo que hay que saber de la crisis en NígerEn medio de un golpe militar impredecible, los países vecinos han amenazado con entrar en guerra, algunos para frustrar la toma del poder y otros para garantizar su éxito. Por Declan WalshPhotoCreditAlana Paterson for The New York Times; Nasuna Stuart-Ulin for The New York TimesLos cambiaron al nacer: dos canadienses descubren sus raícesDurante 65 años, cada hombre tuvo la vida del otro. Por un lado, una infancia difícil complicada por las brutales políticas canadienses hacia los indígenas; por el otro, una educación despreocupada, impregnada de la cultura católica ucraniana. Por Norimitsu OnishiPhotoCreditJefferson Siegel para The New York TimesUn profesor es acusado de atraer mujeres a Nueva York y violarlasA lo largo de una década, Jorge Alberto Ramos le envió dinero al menos a tres mujeres para que viajaran desde El Salvador hasta el Bronx, donde abusó sexualmente de ellas, según la fiscalía. Por Lola FaduluPhotoCreditNicole RifkinOrígenesSurgen cuestionamientos a una teoría sobre la evolución del parto humanoLos científicos están revisando una influyente teoría que argumentaba que la evolución de los cerebros grandes en bebés y pelvis estrechas en mujeres lo volvía arriesgado. Por Carl ZimmerPhotoCreditAmit Elkayam for The New York Times¿Quién pagó por una misteriosa herramienta de espionaje? El FBI, según una investigación del FBITras un reportaje del Times, la agencia canceló su contrato con un contratista del gobierno. Pero sigue habiendo interrogantes. By Mark Mazzetti, Ronen Bergman y Adam GoldmanPhotoCreditLars LeetaruElon Musk quiere convertir a X en una ‘aplicación para todo’Al menos desde el año pasado, el magnate de la tecnología ha expresado su ambición de crear una aplicación integral, al estilo de las que se usan en Asia. By Ryan MacPhotoCreditGetty ImagesEl peso mexicano está fuerte. ¿Qué significa para tu economía?Para los mexicanos que trabajan en EE. UU. y otros países, un peso fuerte ha significado que el dinero que mandan a casa ya no rinde tanto como antes. Queremos saber tu experiencia. By J. Edward MorenoPhotoCreditMichael Sohn/Agence France-Presse — Getty ImagesAlemania enfrenta un desafío para lograr su independencia energética: bombas de conflictos pasadosLa complicada labor de encontrar y limpiar municiones antiguas y sin explotar se ha convertido en una rutina en la costa norte alemana. By Catie EdmondsonEnsayo invitadoPhotoCreditIlustración por Shoshana Schultz/The New York TimesEl poder del ‘lenguaje débil’ de las mujeresEn lugar de castigar a las mujeres por desafiar los estereotipos, deberíamos cuestionar esos estereotipos. By Adam GrantAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTOpiniónMás en Opinión ›PhotoCreditFelipe Dana/Associated PressHaeryun KangCorea del Norte y Corea del Sur se distancian cada día másSetenta años después del armisticio de la Guerra de Corea, el Norte y el Sur están más lejos de la unificación que nunca. By Haeryun KangPhotoCreditIlustración por Akshita Chandra/The New York Times; imágenes por Barbara Alper, Shelly Still/Getty ImagesJessica BennettVi ‘Barbie’ con una de las feministas más importantes del mundo. Y tiene una teoríaSusan Faludi, autora del clásico ‘Backlash’, tiene algunas ideas sobre la película de Greta Gerwig. By Jessica BennettPhotoCreditNatalie Keyssar para The New York TimesBret StephensLo que aprendí en UcraniaViajé al país y comprendí que los ucranianos hacen su vida cotidiana como si no hubiera guerra mientras hacen la guerra como si no hubiera vida cotidiana. By Bret StephensPhotoCreditAssociated PressKai BirdLa verdadera tragedia de OppenheimerLa historia del “padre de la bomba atómica”, como muestra la película de Christopher Nolan, es relevante para nuestros predicamentos políticos actuales. By Kai BirdPhotoCreditErnesto Ryan/Getty ImagesGuillermo GaratMontevideo se quedó sin agua dulce. ¿Pasará lo mismo en tu ciudad?Todas las ciudades del mundo tienen que empezar a planificar escenarios de sequías y en priorizar su agua potable. By Guillermo GaratEspecialMás en Especial ›PhotoCreditUniversal Pictures ("Oppenheimer"); Warner Bros. ("Barbie")‘Barbieheimer’: los entusiastas del cine están listos para una doble funciónAlgunos de los amantes del cine que planean ver el mismo día los estrenos de “Barbie” y “Oppenheimer” disfrutan de la incongruencia entre los dos estrenos. By Christopher KuoPhotoCreditAssociated PressLa verdadera tragedia de OppenheimerLa historia del “padre de la bomba atómica”, como muestra la película de Christopher Nolan, es relevante para nuestros predicamentos políticos actuales. By Kai BirdPhotoCreditRobert Alexander/Getty ImagesLo que ‘Oppenheimer’ no cuenta sobre la prueba de la bomba nuclearLa película aborda solo una parte de la historia del Proyecto Manhattan y no explora las consecuencias de la decisión de detonar el arma en un lugar donde mi familia y muchas otras habían vivido por generaciones. By Tina CordovaPhotoCreditEddie Adams/Associated PressQuién es quién en ‘Oppenheimer’: una guía de las personas y los hechos realesEl complejo drama de Christopher Nolan describe el desarrollo de la bomba nuclear y las maquinaciones políticas de mediados del siglo pasado. Este es el trasfondo. By Christopher KuoAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTWell: Notas de bienestarMás en Well: Notas de bienestar ›PhotoCreditEric Helgas for The New York Times¿El estrés puede provocar la caída del cabello?Si tu cabello se está volviendo más delgado durante momentos particularmente tensos, los expertos tienen algunas ideas sobre lo que podría estar pasando. By Melinda Wenner MoyerPhotoCreditJohn P. DessereauEste es el número que debería guíar tus decisiones de salud (y no es tu edad)La esperanza de vida figura cada vez más en los cálculos sobre si las pruebas de detección y los tratamientos son apropiados. Aquí te mostramos cómo averiguar la tuya. By Paula SpanPhotoCreditCarmen CasadoSi buscas una crema antiarrugas, el protector solar es tu mejor opciónLos rayos del sol causan la mayoría de los cambios en la piel que envejece. Te decimos cómo prevenirlos. By Dana G. SmithPhotoCreditJam Dong¿Es verdad que el azúcar alimenta a las células cancerosas?Muchos pacientes dicen que evitan los dulces para ayudar a combatir la enfermedad. Pero si bien una dieta saludable es importante, no se puede “matar de hambre a un tumor”. By Connie ChangPhotoCreditLars Klove para The New York TimesLo que deben saber los hombres antes de teñirse el cabelloPara muchos hombres, pintarse las canas puede ser la oportunidad de lucir una nueva apariencia o de señalar que están disponibles otra vez. A continuación, algunos consejos para hacerlo con dignidad. By Frank RojasEstados UnidosMás en Estados Unidos ›PhotoCreditMaddie McGarvey para The New York TimesLa acusación contra Trump desafía la democracia de EE. UU.La tercera acusación contra el expresidente aborda uno de los grandes temas de su presidencia: ¿Un mandatario puede difundir mentiras para mantenerse en el poder incluso si los votantes decidieron en las urnas lo contrario? By Peter BakerPhotoCreditKirsten Luce for The New York TimesLa explotación laboral de niños migrantes aumentó en el último año en EE. UU.Alrededor de 300.000 menores han llegado al país sin compañía desde 2021, lo que ha impulsado un aumento marcado en el trabajo infantil entre migrantes. By Hannah DreierPhotoCreditHaiyun Jiang para The New York Times; Desiree Rios para The New York Times¿A qué edad deberían retirarse los políticos?Dos momentos preocupantes que involucraron a los senadores Dianne Feinstein y Mitch McConnell provocaron preguntas sobre el envejecimiento de los líderes electos. By Lisa Lerer y Reid J. EpsteinPhotoCreditJames Devaney/GC Images vía Getty ImagesLa muy privada vida de Melania TrumpMientras su marido busca regresar a la Casa Blanca y se enfrenta a un riesgo legal cada vez mayor, la ex primera dama ha decidido mantenerse fuera del ojo público. By Lisa Lerer y Katie RogersPhotoCreditTrump es acusado por su papel en el asalto al Capitolio y la interferencia en las elecciones de 2020El expresidente, que está en campaña para regresar a la Casa Blanca, ha sido imputado por sus intentos de usar los mecanismos del Estado para permanecer en el poder. By Alan Feuer y Maggie HabermanAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTLo más recienteBuscarBuscarClear this text inputUn expresidente y tres acusacionesCuatro cargos contra Donald Trump, narcotanques en México y más para el fin de semana.Por Elda Cantú Lizzo es demandada por acoso y ambiente laboral hostilTres bailarinas aseguran que ir de gira con la ganadora del Grammy significó trabajar en una “atmósfera abiertamente sexual” y sus acusaciones parecen disputar la reputación de la cantante como defensora de la positividad corporal.Por Lauren McCarthyRead in English The MorningMéxico, un enemigo para algunos republicanosMiembros del Partido Republicano han planteado planes de intervención militar contra los cárteles mexicanos, lo que sería un acto de guerra contra uno de los aliados más cercanos de EE. UU.Por German LopezRead in English Ucrania y LatinoaméricaLa región ante la guerra, las consecuencias del “superpeso” mexicano y más.Por Elda Cantú Tech Fix¿ChatGPT te ha dado respuestas erróneas? Tal vez lo estás usando malSi guiamos a los chatbots de inteligencia artificial a fuentes confiables, reducimos el riesgo de que nos entreguen respuestas con datos erróneos.Por Brian X. ChenRead in English Los ‘narcotanques’ revelan el nivel de violencia de los cárteles en MéxicoLos grupos del crimen organizado están modificando camionetas con torretas armadas, refuerzos de acero y arietes, llevando el concepto de los camiones monstruo a nuevos niveles de letalidad.Por Simon Romero y Emiliano Rodríguez MegaRead in English Perfiles de la cienciaUn botánico con prisaDirigió la construcción del invernadero más grande de América y creó un programa para Colombia en los Jardines de Kew. El primer director latinoamericano del Jardín Botánico de Nueva York dice que es hora de que los jardines “empiecen a aportar soluciones al mundo”.Por Jennie Erin SmithRead in English Un peso mexicano fuerte plantea un desafío para quienes trabajan en el exteriorEl alza del peso significa que las remesas de los mexicanos en Estados Unidos no alcanzan para tanto como antes.Por J. Edward MorenoRead in English El Atlántico podría rebasar un ‘punto crítico’ de calentamiento en este sigloEl sistema de corrientes oceánicas que regula el clima de una franja del planeta podría colapsar antes de lo esperado, según un nuevo análisis.Por Raymond ZhongRead in English Hace 70 años se firmó el armisticio de la Guerra de Corea. Los combates terminaron; la guerra, noA lo largo de la zona desmilitarizada de Corea, los soldados de ambos lados están listos para enfrentarse. Las familias enfrentan décadas de separación, los turistas van a presenciar una historia viva y los sueños de reconciliación se desvanecen.Por Chang W. Lee y Choe Sang-HunRead in English AdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTSite IndexSite Information Navigation© 2023 The New York Times CompanyNYTCoContact UsAccessibilityWork with usAdvertiseT Brand StudioYour Ad ChoicesPrivacy PolicyTerms of ServiceTerms of SaleSite MapCanadaInternationalHelpSubscriptions

title: Science - The New York Times
body: Skip to contentSkip to site indexSearch & Section NavigationSection NavigationSEARCHScience Today’s PaperAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTSupported bySKIP ADVERTISEMENTScienceClimateSpace & AstronomyHealthTrilobitesMatterOut ThereCovid PandemicHighlightsPhotoCreditChristopher MahTrilobitesNew Antarctic Starfish Are Doting Parents and Vicious PredatorsA close examination of a collection of starfish in the Smithsonian revealed even more starfish inside those starfish. By Darren IncorvaiaPhotoCreditCatoctin Furnace Historical SocietyEnslaved African Americans in Maryland Linked to 42,000 Living RelativesThe analysis marks the first time historical DNA has been used to trace the descendants and distant cousins of enslaved people, researchers said. By Carl ZimmerPhotoCreditHyun-Tak KimLK-99 Is the Superconductor of the SummerSocial media users are excited about what would be a breakthrough in solid state physics, but many experts in the field are cautiously skeptical. By Kenneth ChangPhotoCreditEve ThomasonTrilobitesElectrocution Isn’t the Main Thing Killing Birds Along Power LinesA survey of power lines in four Western states found bullet fragments and shotgun pellets in most of the dead birds that were collected. By Carolyn WilkePhotoCreditAlberto GennariThis Ancient Whale May Have Been the Heaviest Animal EverPerucetus drifted through shallow seas like a gigantic manatee, scientists suspect. By Carl ZimmerTrilobitesPhotoCreditChristian McCall505-Million-Year-Old Jellyfish Fossils May Be the Oldest Ever FoundThe specimens are evidence of how little the squishy, tentacled predators have changed over the history of life on Earth. By Jack TamisieaPhotoCreditSteve Ruark/Associated PressFamily of Henrietta Lacks Settles With Biotech Company That Used Her CellsMs. Lacks’s family had accused Thermo Fisher Scientific of profiting from her cells, which have contributed to revolutionary advances in medicine, without seeking their permission. By Amanda HolpuchPhotoCreditHaas, et al., Science Advances 2020Move Over, Men: Women Were Hunters, TooAnthropologists are finding that women in modern foraging societies have played a major role in catching game. By Katrina MillerPhotoCredit6 Great Space Images From JulyA star with two faces, boulders cast into the void, space junk on a beach and more out of this world scenes. By Michael RostonAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTTrilobitesMore in Trilobites ›PhotoCreditPeter NickolausA Pancaked Turtle Fossil’s 150-Million-Year-Old TaleA beautifully preserved shelled reptile recovered from a Bavarian limestone deposit helps tell the story of how turtles first took to the seas. By Asher ElbeinPhotoCreditAleksey Suvorov/AlamyWhen Ancient Eruptions Pumped Diamonds to Earth’s SurfaceA new study offers clues to the mysteries of kimberlite eruptions, the source of most of the diamonds mined on Earth today. By Maya Wei-HaasPhotoCreditJustine Hudson/Fisheries and Oceans CanadaThe Prize for the Longest Pregnancy in Mammals May Go to This WhaleBowhead whales may carry their babies for as long as 23 months, although more research is needed to confirm the finding. By Miriam FauziaPhotoCreditMichael SkrepnickThis Fossil Is a Freeze-Frame of a Mammal Fighting a DinosaurIt’s like a man-bites-dog story from prehistoric times, although researchers had to take steps to verify that it was not a forgery. By Kate GolembiewskiPhotoCreditDepartment of Special Collections, Hesburgh Libraries of Notre DameWhat Benjamin Franklin Learned While Fighting CounterfeitersLong before there were Benjamins in circulation, the founding father was all about experimenting with printing techniques as he worked on securing colonial printed currency. By Veronique GreenwoodOriginsMore in Origins ›PhotoCreditBizarre Sea Creatures Illuminate the Dawn of the Animal KingdomA new study bolsters the idea that the first animals were surprisingly complex, perhaps equipped with muscles and a nervous system. By Carl ZimmerPhotoCreditNico Garstman/Naturalis Biodiversity CenterScience Museums Take Stock of 1.1 Billion Objects From Around the WorldNatural history museums have joined forces to produce a global digital inventory of their prized collections, from pinned butterflies to dinosaur skulls. By Carl ZimmerPhotoCreditJürgen Vogel, LVR-LandesMuseum BonnAncient DNA Reveals History of Hunter-Gatherers in EuropeLooking at DNA gleaned from ancient remains, researchers identified at least eight previously unknown populations of early Europeans. By Carl ZimmerPhotoCreditBeth ZaikenOldest Known DNA Offers Glimpse of a Once-Lush ArcticIn Greenland’s permafrost, scientists discovered two-million-year-old genetic material from scores of plant and animal species, including mastodons, geese, lemmings and ants. By Carl ZimmerPhotoCreditSteve Gschmeissner/Science SourceÓmicron cumple un año. Así ha evolucionadoAl cumplirse el aniversario del descubrimiento de la variante, los expertos en virología siguen intentando ponerse al día con la rápida transformación de ómicron. By Carl ZimmerAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTClimate and EnvironmentMore in Climate and Environment ›PhotoCreditNatacha Pisarenko/Associated PressHeat Wave Grips Portions of South America in the Middle of WinterAn unusual winter heat wave has brought record high temperatures to cities across Argentina, Chile and Paraguay this week, triggering concerns about the impacts of climate change. By Jesus Jiménez and Natalie AlcobaPhotoCreditThe New York TimesAntarctic Sea Ice Is at a ‘Very Concerning’ Record LowIt’s winter in Antarctica, when sea ice cover typically grows. But this year’s sea ice is way behind, reaching record lows with implications for the planet. By Delger Erdenesanaa and Leanne AbrahamPhotoCreditA Desperate Push to Save Florida’s Coral: Get It Out of the SeaTeams dedicated to ocean restoration are urgently moving samples to tanks on land as a marine heat wave devastates entire reefs. By Catrin Einhorn and Jason GulleyPhotoCreditMaddie McGarvey for The New York TimesIt’s Official: Stores Can No Longer Sell Most Incandescent LightsNew efficiency rules, more than a decade in the making, have taken effect, relegating Edison’s glowing orbs to the history books. By Hiroko TabuchiPhotoCreditSeiji MatsumotoThis Guide Can Help You Save Money and Fight Climate ChangeWhether you are renovating your home, upgrading appliances or buying an electric car, this guide can help you take advantage of savings from the Inflation Reduction Act. By Nadja Popovich and Elena ShaoLatestSearchSearchClear this text input‘It’s Crazy’: The Scramble for Ancient Treasures After Ukraine’s Dam DisasterAfter the Kakhovka dam was blown up in June, the reservoir above it quickly drained, revealing a bonanza of artifacts that has electrified Ukrainian archaeologists.By Jeffrey Gettleman and Finbarr O’Reilly Medical Group Backs Youth Gender Treatments, but Calls for Research ReviewThe American Academy of Pediatrics renewed its support of gender care for minors while commissioning a fresh look at the evidence.By Azeen Ghorayshi Leprosy May Be Endemic in Central Florida, Scientists ReportStill, there are fewer than 200 cases nationally each year, and the numbers have fallen significantly from the peak decades ago.By Apoorva Mandavilli Amid Signs of a Covid Uptick, Researchers Brace for the ‘New Normal’Infections remain very low, despite signs of a slight increase. Now, experts are looking for clues to what living with the coronavirus will be like this winter and beyond.By Apoorva Mandavilli Alan Roland, 93, Psychoanalyst Who Cautioned Against Western Bias, DiesIn “In Search of Self” and other books, he emphasized the role of cultural influences in a patient’s life.By Neil Genzlinger NASA’s Voyager 2 Is Out of Contact but Not Lost in SpaceThe aging spacecraft’s antenna was misdirected by a glitch, although officials say the distant probe appears to be functioning as intended.By Katrina Miller Saving Lives at the Grand Canyon, One Salty Snack at a TimeIn a summer of deadly heat for hikers in the Southwest, rangers at Grand Canyon National Park use a pioneering approach of aggressive messaging and outreach to prevent disaster on the trails.By Rowan Moore Gerety Scenes From a City That Only Hands Out Tickets for Using FentanylOregon’s experiment to curb overdoses by decriminalizing small amounts of illicit drugs is in its third year, and life has changed for most everyone in the city of Portland.By Jordan Gale and Jan Hoffman Profiles in ScienceMauricio Diazgranados Is a Botanist in a HurryFor the first time, the New York Botanical Garden has a chief scientist who hails from the same region as so much of its collections.By Jennie Erin SmithLeer en español Is It an E-Bike, or a Motorcycle for Children?With a throttle and no pedals, Super73’s new “electric balance bike” blurs the lines of regulation and safety. “No license, registration or insurance required,” its marketing promises.By Matt Richtel AdvertisementSKIP title: Health - The New York Times
body: Skip to contentSkip to site indexSearch & Section NavigationSection NavigationSEARCHHealth Today’s PaperAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTSupported bySKIP ADVERTISEMENTHealthHealth PolicyGlobal HealthThe New Old AgeScienceWellCovid PandemicHighlightsPhotoCreditFrederic J. Brown/Agence France-Presse — Getty ImagesThree Shots for Fall: What You Need to KnowHere’s what we know about who should get the flu, Covid and R.S.V. vaccines, and when. By Apoorva MandavilliPhotoCreditRory Doyle for The Washington Post, via Getty ImagesMedical Group Backs Youth Gender Treatments, but Calls for Research ReviewThe American Academy of Pediatrics renewed its support of gender care for minors while commissioning a fresh look at the evidence. By Azeen GhorayshiPhotoCreditErika P. Rodriguez for The New York TimesAmid Signs of a Covid Uptick, Researchers Brace for the ‘New Normal’Infections remain very low, despite signs of a slight increase. Now, experts are looking for clues to what living with the coronavirus will be like this winter and beyond. By Apoorva MandavilliPhotoCreditSteve Gschmeissner/Science SourceLeprosy May Be Endemic in Central Florida, Scientists ReportStill, there are fewer than 200 cases nationally each year, and the numbers have fallen significantly from the peak decades ago. By Apoorva MandavilliPhotoCreditJordan Gale for The New York TimesScenes From a City That Only Hands Out Tickets for Using FentanylOregon’s experiment to curb overdoses by decriminalizing small amounts of illicit drugs is in its third year, and life has changed for most everyone in the city of Portland. By Jordan Gale and Jan HoffmanPhotoCreditAlisha Jucevic for The New York TimesIs It an E-Bike, or a Motorcycle for Children?With a throttle and no pedals, Super73’s new “electric balance bike” blurs the lines of regulation and safety. “No license, registration or insurance required,” its marketing promises. By Matt RichtelPhotoCreditAriana Drehsler for The New York Times‘A Dangerous Combination’: Teenagers’ Accidents Expose E-Bike RisksThe e-bike industry is booming, but many vehicles are not legal for teenagers, and accidents are on the rise. By Matt RichtelPhotoCreditJames Gathany, Centers for Disease Control and PreventionA Half-Million Americans May Have Tick-Linked Meat Allergy, C.D.C. SaysMany doctors said that they were unfamiliar with the condition, known as alpha-gal syndrome, the agency found. By Emily AnthesPhotoCreditRedmond O. Durrell/AlamyBlood of Young Mice Extends Life in the OldInfusions of youthful blood led older mice to live 6 to 9 percent longer, a new study found. By Carl ZimmerAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTFrom WellMore in From Well ›PhotoCreditYael Malka for The New York TimesThe Joy of May-December FriendshipThese BFFs have learned that a 40- or 50-year age gap is no deterrent to connection. By Catherine PearsonPhotoCreditIllustration by Nicolás Ortega; Photograph by Getty ImagesIt’s OK to Be a Summer GrinchYou might be hot, sweaty and tired. But there are things you can do to manage. By Jancee DunnPhotoCreditKarsten Moran for The New York TimesAlcohol-Related Deaths Are Rising Among WomenThe gap between male and female fatalities is narrowing, including for people 65 and older. Here’s how to know if you need to cut back on your drinking. By Dani BlumPhotoCreditCaitlin O'Hara for The New York TimesDive Into an Open-Water WorkoutSwimming in a lake or the ocean is an exhilarating alternative to your usual pool routine. Here’s how to get started. By Amanda LoudinPhotoCreditEric Helgas for The New York TimesIs Menopause Changing My Hair?Shifting hormones can make hair go haywire. Experts say there are ways to manage it. By Alisha Haridasani GuptaThe Covid-19 PandemicMore in The Covid-19 Pandemic ›PhotoCreditIllustration by Jules JulienThe Ongoing Mystery of Covid’s OriginWe still don’t know how the pandemic started. Here's what we do know — and why it matters. By David QuammenPhotoCreditAn Inside Look at Covid’s Lasting Damage to the LungsThis 3-D reconstruction of lung scans reveals damage that has lingered for years in patients who became severely ill early in the pandemic. By Jeremy White, Pam Belluck, Noah Bassetti-Blum, Eleanor Lutz and Hang Do Thi DucPhotoCreditPhoto illustration by Ina JangHer Symptoms Suggested Long Covid. But Was That Too Obvious?Doctors make assumptions about a case — and those assumptions can sometimes cloud their judgment. By Lisa Sanders, M.D.PhotoCreditMark Schiefelbein/Associated PressCovid Is Coming Back in China; Lockdowns Are NotThe authorities say that cases are up, and one doctor estimates that there could soon be 65 million cases a week. But China appears determined to move on. By Chris BuckleyPhotoCreditRuth Fremson/The New York TimesU.S. Ends Last Covid Travel Barrier, Vaccine Mandate for Foreign ArrivalsInternational travelers entering the country are no longer required to be vaccinated, removing the last of the restrictions on travel put in place beginning in 2020. By Ceylan YeginsuAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTLatestSearchSearchClear this text inputEnslaved African Americans in Maryland Linked to 42,000 Living RelativesThe analysis marks the first time historical DNA has been used to trace the descendants and distant cousins of enslaved people, researchers said.By Carl Zimmer This Ancient Whale May Have Been the Heaviest Animal EverPerucetus drifted through shallow seas like a gigantic manatee, scientists suspect.By Carl Zimmer ScreenlandWhat I Saw When I Looked Inside My Own BodyModern medicine is constantly showing us our guts and bones. Why doesn’t it feel more profound?By B.D. McClay Family of Henrietta Lacks Settles With Biotech Company That Used Her CellsMs. Lacks’s family had accused Thermo Fisher Scientific of profiting from her cells, which have contributed to revolutionary advances in medicine, without seeking their permission.By Amanda Holpuch OriginsA Theory of Childbirth’s Evolution May Not Be What You’re ExpectingScientists are revisiting an influential theory that the evolution of big brains made human childbirth risky.By Carl ZimmerLeer en español What Is an E-Bike, and How Safe Are They?Surprisingly tricky questions about an increasingly popular vehicle.By Matt Richtel AIDS Relief Program Under Threat as G.O.P. Insists on Abortion RestrictionA decades-old program created by President George W. Bush to combat AIDS around the world is at risk of being sucked into a partisan dispute over abortion, with some Republicans threatening to block its renewal.By Sheryl Gay Stolberg The EthicistMy Friend Is Trapped in a Nursing Home. What Can I Do?The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on helping people who are institutionalized against their will.By Kwame Anthony Appiah Louise Levy, Who Was Studied for Her Very Long Life, Is Dead at 112She was one of hundreds of people, all of them Ashkenazi Jews, whose good health and cognitive ability at extreme old age were the subject of genetic research.By Richard Sandomir 16 People Sickened in Salmonella Outbreak Linked to Ground BeefPeople who became ill reported eating lean ground beef that was sold at ShopRite locations in New Jersey, New York and Connecticut, the C.D.C. said.By Rebecca Carballo AdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTFollow Us@nythealthtwitter page for @nythealthNYTimesSciencefacebook page for NYTimesScienceWellNYTfacebook page for WellNYT@nytimeswelltwitter page for @nytimeswellAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTSite IndexSite Information Navigation© 2023 The New York Times CompanyNYTCoContact UsAccessibilityWork with usAdvertiseT Brand StudioYour Ad ChoicesPrivacy PolicyTerms of ServiceTerms of SaleSite MapCanadaInternationalHelpSubscriptions

时报普利策获奖作品











中国火箭军高层剧变
人事震荡或令习近平核武雄心短暂受挫
储百亮 
火箭军控制着中国几乎所有核武器，其两名高官被突然撤换引发猜测。习近平急于加强自己对这一敏感军种的支配地位，高层动荡或导致中国核武雄心暂时受挫。






两名美国海军水手被指控向中国泄密
 ADAM GOLDMAN, JILL COWAN 13:34 





两人在南加州被捕，被控向中国情报官员提供军事机密和敏感信息。美国近来持续指责中国大范围窃取美国企业和国家安全机密。


前副总统彭斯成特朗普案核心人物
 SHANE GOLDMACHER, MAGGIE ASTOR, LUKE BROADWATER 15:08 





彭斯曾是特朗普最忠实的副手，他将在明年的共和党初选中与之针锋相对，上演一场前副总统挑战其总统靠山的历史性对决。


国会暴乱事件中，彭斯的惊魂一日





特朗普因试图推翻总统大选结果被起诉
 ALAN FEUER,MAGGIE HABERMAN  





特朗普面临欺骗美国等四宗罪。这标志着美国历史上一个非同寻常的时刻：在新一轮大选展开之际，一位前总统被指控试图颠覆民主。


报告指太阳能行业仍与新疆有大量关联
 ANA SWANSON, IVAN PENN  





数百家公司承诺保证其供应链不存在强迫劳动，但新报告发现，几家最大制造商的业务仍与新疆高度关联，它们的总部均位于中国。


中国政府出台促进消费措施
 KEITH BRADSHER  





中国复苏乏力让政府急于提振经济。但随着青年失业率高企、消费者信心不足，人们对政府推出的刺激措施是否有效持怀疑态度。





 人工智能聊天机器人训练指南 

 杭州动物园否认“人扮熊”传言 

 北京遭暴雨和洪水袭击，至少11人亡 

 《隐入尘烟》：令人心痛的爱与坚韧 

 拜登政府搜寻中国恶意计算机代码 

 法官拒对《愿荣光归香港》颁布禁令 











Doug Mills/The New York Times


特朗普对试图推翻大选结果相关指控表示不认罪
GLENN THRUSH 11:50
这是特朗普四个月以来第三次因刑事指控出庭，他对四项指控均表示不认罪。听证会结束后，他发表讲话称自己是拜登政府的“迫害”对象，这“对美国来说是非常悲哀的一天”。


特朗普因试图推翻总统大选结果被起诉







新闻分析
特朗普2024：竞选总统，反击控罪
 LISA LERER, REID J. EPSTEIN 12:46 





特朗普一直以来都很清楚：法庭可以裁决他的案件，但只有选民才能决定是否让他重新掌权。他已明确表示，如果重新入主白宫，将行使权力终止针对他的诉讼。






讣告
日本作家森村诚一去世，作品曾揭露731部队暴行
 RICHARD SANDOMIR 14:36 





森村是推理小说作家和和平主义者，代表作之一《恶魔的饱食》详细描述了日军在占领中国后进行的秘密生物战项目。他表示自己写这本书的目的是为了平衡日本对战争的描述。

书评
《等着在夜里被逮捕》：当日常生活变成一场噩梦
 BARBARA DEMICK 15:44 





维吾尔诗人伊兹格尔的新回忆录《等着在夜里被逮捕》是人权书籍中的异类。书中没有酷刑的场景，没有暴力，但它如同一部心理惊悚片，在克制的叙述背后，恐怖如期而至。


镇压、恐惧与创伤：一位维吾尔诗人笔下的新疆
 TIFFANY MAY  





知名诗人和导演伊兹格尔出版回忆录《等着在夜里被逮捕》，描述了中国政府在新疆对维吾尔人实施的镇压和大规模拘禁，以及这些政策给当地人带来的恐惧和创伤。


原子弹争议难消，“芭本海默”在日本引发愤怒
 BEN DOOLEY, HISAKO UENO  





《芭比》的美国宣传账号在社交媒体上推广“芭本海默”米姆，转发了一张使用核爆背景的影迷自制海报，引发日本用户的强烈不满。《奥本海默》尚未确定在日本的上映日期。










      观点与评论 • OPINION



 为何女性会选择战略性“示弱”
 ADAM GRANT 





试探性语言似乎是女性避免性别刻板成见带来的不公正后果的一种策略。我们应该将“弱势语言”正常化，成为一种表达关心和谦逊的有力方式。

 台湾女性不再退让：“我们不要就这么算了”
 VICKIE WANG 





台湾仍是一个父权制和等级制社会，女性要屈从于当权者。“算了吧”是个体面的做法。但这次不行。我们厌倦了听之任之，厌倦了退缩。





 我家乡新疆的悲剧可能发生在任何地方

 朝韩“统一”梦想的褪色和幻灭










镜头 • LENS












 




图片中的2022年（上）

for president made a surprise trip to meet with President Volodymyr Zelensky.By The Associated Press TimesVideoUkrainian Maritime Drone Hits Russian WarshipVideo released by the Ukrainian military shows a Ukrainian drone attack on a Russian naval ship in the port of Novorossiysk.By Storyful What to Know About Novorossiysk, the Russian Port Attacked by UkraineThe seaport is one of Russia’s largest by volume and among the biggest in Europe, crucial to the export of Russian grain, oil, and other products to countries around the world.By Paul Sonne TimesVideoTo Spare Beijing, China Diverts Floodwaters Toward Nearby CitiesSome residents of Zhuozhou in Hebei Province say they did not get enough of a warning from local officials before the water was rerouted.By Shawn Paik Why TSMC Will Keep Its Roots in Taiwan, Even as It Goes GlobalIn an interview, the chip maker’s chairman, Mark Liu, explained why TSMC’s top tech would stay in Taiwan, despite growing threats from China and worries from the United States.By John Liu and Paul Mozur TrilobitesNew Antarctic Starfish Are Doting Parents and Vicious PredatorsA close examination of a collection of starfish in the Smithsonian revealed even more starfish inside those starfish.By Darren Incorvaia Japan’s Enduring ‘Sound of Summer’Created 75 years ago for the country’s prestigious high school baseball tournament, Yuji Koseki’s “The Crown Will Shine on You” stirs memories as it inspires new ones.By Brad Lefton The Chip Titan Whose Life’s Work Is at the Center of a Tech Cold WarAt 92, Morris Chang, the founder of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, can no longer stay in the shadows.By Paul Mozur and John Liu Jailed Russian Opposition Leader Navalny Receives a New 19-Year SentenceAleksei A. Navalny, who is already in prison, was sentenced for supporting “extremism,” amid intensified suppression of dissent in Russia.By Paul Sonne and Valeriya Safronova Friday BriefingDonald Trump’s day in court.By Natasha Frost AdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTSite IndexSite Information Navigation© 2023 The New York Times CompanyNYTCoContact UsAccessibilityWork with usAdvertiseT Brand StudioYour Ad ChoicesPrivacy PolicyTerms of ServiceTerms of SaleSite MapCanadaInternationalHelpSubscriptions

title: Today's Paper - The New York Times
body: Skip to contentSkip to site indexSearch & Section NavigationSection NavigationSEARCHToday's paper Today’s PaperAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTSupported bySKIP ADVERTISEMENTToday’s PaperThe Times in Print ForThe Front PageInternationalNationalObituariesEditorials, Op-Ed and LettersBusiness DaySports FridayWeekend ArtsPages A2-A3 and Corrections The Front PageHighlightsPhotoCreditDoug Mills/The New York TimesTrump, Arraigned on Election Charges, Pleads Not GuiltyThe former president appeared in federal court in Washington after being indicted over his efforts to overturn his defeat in 2020. His first pretrial hearing was set for Aug. 28. By Glenn Thrush and Charlie SavagePhotoCreditJason Andrew for The New York TimesThe Charges That Were Notably Absent From the Trump IndictmentAn indictment this week did not accuse former President Donald Trump of inciting the mob that attacked the Capitol, but it did show that some close to him knew violence might be coming. By Alan FeuerPhotoCreditMaddie McGarvey for The New York TimesNews AnalysisTrump’s 2024 Campaign Seeks to Make Voters the Ultimate JuryDonald J. Trump has long understood the stakes in the election: The courts may decide his cases, but only voters can decide whether to return him to power. By Lisa Lerer and Reid J. EpsteinPhotoCreditBrendan Hoffman for The New York TimesPastor or Traitor? Ukrainians Shun a Church Seen as a Kremlin Tool.The village parishioners’ decision to oust their priest reflects a broader push within Ukraine to reduce the influence of an Orthodox church that answers to Moscow. By Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Yurii ShyvalaThis Jazz Artist Makes Pro Football Hall of Fame Speeches SingWhen the Pro Football Hall of Fame’s inductees began to ramble, executives turned to Jezra Kaye to help them rein it in.By Ken BelsonPage A1What Can You Do When A.I. Lies About You?People have little protection or recourse when the technology creates and spreads falsehoods about them.By Tiffany HsuPage A1Trump Leads G.O.P. in Iowa, but His Hold Is Less DominantBy Jonathan WeismanPage A11New York City Will Make Outdoor Dining Permanent, With CaveatsBy Emma G. FitzsimmonsPage A8Larry Fink’s Bet on Saudi Oil Money Is Also His Latest E.S.G. WoeBy Maureen FarrellPage B1I Gave Up on Boxing, Not on This BoxerBy Kurt Streeter and Erin SchaffPage B6Satchmo’s Wonderful World: Louis Armstrong Center Amplifies An Artist’s VisionBy Melena RyzikPage C1TODAYS FRONT PAGESEdition:New YorkNationalInternationalEnlarge This ImageAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTInternational‘Not Another Coup as Usual’: What to Know About Niger’s CrisisBy Declan WalshPage A4Colombia and Rebel Group Begin Cease-Fire After Decades of CombatBy Genevieve GlatskyPage A4Hundreds Fall Ill From Heat at Scout Gathering in South KoreaBy John YoonPage A5Show More in InternationalNationalNew York City Will Make Outdoor Dining Permanent, With CaveatsBy Emma G. FitzsimmonsPage A8The Next Affirmative Action Battle May Be at West PointBy Anemona HartocollisPage A8District Attorney’s Investigations Burrow Into Adams’s Circle of SupportBy Jonah E. Now, He’s Beginning Another Long Comeback.New York Times CookingRecipes, advice and inspiration for any occasion.Recommendations From WirecutterIndependent reviews for thousands of products.AdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTNew York Times GamesDaily word and visual games, plus more.WordleGuess the 5-letter word with 6 chances.Today’s Wordle ReviewOur columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. title: New York - The New York Times
body: Skip to contentSkip to site indexSearch & Section NavigationSection NavigationSEARCHNew York Today’s PaperAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTSupported bySKIP ADVERTISEMENTNew YorkEric AdamsKathy HochulBig CityMetropolitan DiarySunday RoutineHighlightsPhotoCreditDavid Dee Delgado for The New York TimesDancer Stabbed to Death Was a Shy Boy Turned Proud, Exuberant ManO’Shae Sibley was determined to succeed in New York, where he had joined a community of artists and performers who pushed him to strive. By Maria Cramer and Wesley ParnellPhotoCreditProsecutors Identify Human Remains Found in 2011 Near Gilgo BeachThe skull belonged to Karen Vergata, who had disappeared in 1996. Other parts of her body had been found on Fire Island years before. By Maria Cramer and Nate SchweberPhotoCreditAssociated PressBig CITYCrime Is Down. So Why Don’t New Yorkers Feel Safe?Crime isn’t what it was in the 1980s. But a new podcast about the Bernhard Goetz subway shootings suggests that even then, the fear of crime outpaced reality. By Ginia BellafantePhotoCreditCari Vander YachtTake the Quiz! Pick the Worst New York City Summer Plagues.Roaches. Aphids. Rats. How many scourges can one city have? Lately, old annoyances have been joined by new terrors. In this quiz, you get to choose your own nightmare! By Dodai StewartPhotoCreditDave Sanders for The New York TimesLeft-Leaning Democrats Meet in Secret to Find a Challenger to Eric AdamsA group of progressives held an early strategy meeting on Staten Island to discuss how they might defeat Mr. Adams in 2025. It won’t be easy. By Emma G. Fitzsimmons, Nicholas Fandos and Jeffery C. MaysPhotoCreditJefferson Siegel for The New York TimesProfessor Charged in Scheme to Lure Women to New York and Rape ThemOver the course of a decade, Jorge Alberto Ramos paid for at least three women to travel from El Salvador to his home in the Bronx, where he sexually abused them, according to prosecutors. By Lola FaduluNew York TodayPhotoCreditSpencer Platt/Getty ImagesSome of the Things You’ll Be Paying More ForGas and electric bills are going up, and so are bridge and tunnel tolls, not to mention subway fares. By James BarronPhotoCreditStephanie Keith for The New York TimesDistrict Attorney’s Investigations Burrow Into Adams’s Circle of SupportMayor Eric Adams has not been implicated in any wrongdoing, but District Attorney Alvin L. Bragg has targeted people who are in the mayor’s circle. By Jonah E. Bromwich and William K. RashbaumPhotoCreditThe New York TimesWhen Help Shows Up After a House Fire, It Might Be Gang MembersProsecutors say a former leader of the Bloods has single-handedly remade the emergency mitigation industry in New York through intimidation and brute force. By Michael WilsonAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTLatestSearchSearchClear this text inputGiuliani Maligns Jews and Women in Transcript Filed in Harassment CaseRudolph Giuliani, the former mayor and presidential lawyer, faces a variety of legal troubles and has been identified as a co-conspirator in Donald Trump’s indictment.By Jonah E. Bromwich Former Head of Police Sergeants Union Sentenced to 2 Years for FraudEdward D. Mullins, who had drawn attention for vulgar insults of city leaders, stole hundreds of thousands of dollars from union members.By Chelsia Rose Marcius Myron Goldfinger, 90, Architect of Monumental Modernist Homes, DiesHis houses, which dot the Hamptons and other parts of the New York region, include a residence featured in “The Wolf of Wall Street.”By Clay Risen Satchmo’s Wonderful World: Louis Armstrong Center Amplifies An Artist’s VisionNew jazz and exhibition spaces, and an inaugural show curated by Jason Moran, feature the trumpeter’s history, collaged onto the walls.By Melena Ryzik New York City Will Make Outdoor Dining Permanent, With CaveatsNew rules passed by the City Council on Thursday will organize the haphazard but popular outdoor dining structures, but will force their removal in the winter.By Emma G. Fitzsimmons On the MarketHomes for Sale in Manhattan and QueensThis week’s properties are in Hell’s Kitchen, the financial district and Astoria.By Heather Senison New York TodayArmories, Hotels, Offices: Where New York Could House MigrantsThere are no easy answers for officials trying to find shelter beds, but “everything is on the table,” a deputy mayor said.By James Barron What Happens When New York’s Shelters Run Out of Room?As migrants sleep on sidewalks outside a Midtown hotel, the city is struggling to avoid a homelessness crisis that resembles those in Los Angeles or San Francisco.By Nicole Hong ‘A Nice Bike, When It Works’: Riders Fret After E-Bike Maker Goes BustVanMoof’s sleek electric bikes attracted fans, but the Dutch company’s demise has left owners unable to get repairs and worried that app-enabled functions may stop working.By Claire Moses New York Covid Cases Are Rising Slightly, Officials WarnA small uptick in Covid cases has led to more hospitalizations, but the numbers, about 800 statewide, are still far below previous waves.By Joseph Goldstein AdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTFollow Us@NYTMetrotwitter page for @NYTMetroAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTSite IndexSite Information Navigation© 2023 The New York Times CompanyNYTCoContact UsAccessibilityWork with usAdvertiseT Brand StudioYour Ad ChoicesPrivacy PolicyTerms of ServiceTerms of SaleSite MapCanadaInternationalHelpSubscriptions

title: U.S. Politics - The New York Times
body: Skip to contentSkip to site indexSearch & Section NavigationSection NavigationSEARCHPolitics Today’s PaperAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTSupported bySKIP ADVERTISEMENTU.S.U.S. PoliticsJoe Biden2022 Midterm ElectionsHighlightsPhotoCreditAshley WuTrump Leads G.O.P. in Iowa, but His Hold Is Less DominantNew polling suggests that Gov. Ron DeSantis’s efforts in Iowa have been having an effect, but that the challenge of defeating Mr. Trump there is complicated by multiple factors. By Jonathan WeismanPhotoCreditDoug Mills/The New York TimesFact-Checking the Defenses of Trump After His Latest IndictmentFormer President Donald Trump’s supporters have made inaccurate claims about the judge presiding over his case and misleadingly compared his conduct to that of other politicians. By Linda QiuPhotoCreditJordan Gale for The New York TimesMike Pence Has Reached His Fork in the RoadThe former vice president and Jan. 6 witness is campaigning to persuade voters. But is he also trying to warn them? By Matt FlegenheimerPhotoCreditChristopher Smith for The New York TimesDeSantis Dismisses Trump’s 2020 Election Theories as FalseAfter long hedging, the Florida governor went further than he has before in acknowledging that the election was not stolen. By Nicholas Nehamas and Lisa LererAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTLatestSearchSearchClear this text inputTimesVideoPolice Identify ‘Fire Island Jane Doe’The authorities identified human remains found near Gilgo Beach in 2011, and on Fire Island years before, as those of Karen Vergata, who was 34 when she went missing in 1996.By The Associated Press DeSantis Dismisses Trump’s 2020 Election Theories as FalseAfter long hedging, the Florida governor went further than he has before in acknowledging that the election was not stolen.By Nicholas Nehamas and Lisa Lerer Chris Christie Meets With Ukrainian President in Surprise Trip to KyivMr. Christie is the second 2024 G.O.P. hopeful to visit the war-torn nation, signaling his support for Ukraine in its effort to repel Russia.By Charles Homans Mike Pence Has Reached His Fork in the RoadThe former vice president and Jan. 6 witness is campaigning to persuade voters. But is he also trying to warn them?By Matt Flegenheimer Is Trump Leaving an Opening in Iowa?The former president’s poll numbers are still strong. But the caucuses could be his rivals’ best chance to make him look vulnerable.By Nate Cohn Trump Leads G.O.P. in Iowa, but His Hold Is Less DominantNew polling suggests that Gov. Ron DeSantis’s efforts in Iowa have been having an effect, but that the challenge of defeating Mr. Trump there is complicated by multiple factors.By Jonathan Weisman Appeals Court Allows Biden’s Asylum Restrictions to Continue for NowA federal judge had struck down the policy last week, but his ruling had not yet taken effect.By Michael D. Shear Trump, Arraigned on Election Charges, Pleads Not GuiltyThe former president appeared in federal court in Washington after being indicted over his efforts to overturn his defeat in 2020. His first pretrial hearing was set for Aug. 28.By Glenn Thrush and Charlie Savage Trump’s day in court included another encounter with Jack Smith, but no eye contact.This time the seriousness of the charges facing the former president gave the proceedings a sense of historical weight.By Glenn Thrush Four takeaways from Trump’s court appearance.A quick proceeding that was mostly straightforward.By Daniel Victor AdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTFollow Usnytpoliticstwitter page for nytpoliticsnytpoliticsfacebook page for nytpoliticsSite IndexSite Information Navigation© 2023 The New York Times CompanyNYTCoContact UsAccessibilityWork with usAdvertiseT Brand StudioYour Ad ChoicesPrivacy PolicyTerms of ServiceTerms of SaleSite MapCanadaInternationalHelpSubscriptions

KimGuest EssayDown the Rabbit Hole Into Donald Trump’s BrainCan prosecutors convince a jury Trump means every bonkers thing he says? By Michael WolffPhotoCreditDavid Maxwell/EPA, via ShutterstockMichelle GoldbergThe Critical Election Republicans Are Hoping You Won’t NoticeAbortion opponents in Ohio are counting on low turnout next Tuesday. By Michelle GoldbergPhotoCreditDebora SzpilmanDavid FrenchI Don’t See a ‘Rogue’ Supreme CourtBehold the last federal bastion of the pre-Trump right. By David FrenchGuest EssayPhotoCreditKristian HammerstadFrom Taylor Swift to Beyoncé, Concerts Are Turning Into Something NewYes, the cost of concert tickets is exceptionally high. But for spectacle-starved fans, the memories are priceless. By Elamin AbdelmahmoudGuest EssayPhotoCreditSammy HarkhamHow QAnon and Jan. 6 Ripped the Conspiracy Theory World ApartThe internet-native theory and the riot it helped spawn have left even Sept. 11 truthers and those who believe in U.F.O. cover-ups deeply unsettled about the future of conspiracy culture. By Annie KellyRoss DouthatPhotoCreditGabriel Alcala‘Oppenheimer’ and the Shadow of StalinWhat the film doesn’t say about the sources of anti-communism. By Ross DouthatPaul KrugmanPhotoCreditDamon Winter/The New York TimesWhat’s the Matter With Miami?The dream of becoming the new New York is fading. By Paul KrugmanGuest EssayPhotoCreditPhilip Keith for The New York TimesWhat Our Beech Tree Teaches Us About the Possibility of the FutureThe idea of a “new normal” steals from us the possibility of being transformed, for better or worse. By Elizabeth RushAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTLatestSearchSearchClear this text inputPeter CoyThe Unsettled Debate at the Heart of the Henrietta Lacks CaseDo we own our bodies? The answer, according to many legal experts, is no.By Peter Coy Paul KrugmanWonking Out: Is a U.S. Debt Crisis Looming? Also: Anti-Trump Republicans; racial disparities in the pool; multitasking; dog behavior. Guest EssayHow QAnon and Jan. 6 Ripped the Conspiracy Theory World ApartThe internet-native theory and the riot it helped spawn have left even Sept. 11 truthers and those who believe in U.F.O. cover-ups deeply unsettled about the future of conspiracy culture.By Annie Kelly Guest EssayFrom Taylor Swift to Beyoncé, Concerts Are Turning Into Something NewYes, the cost of concert tickets is exceptionally high. title: The New York Times en Español - The New York Times
body: Skip to contentSkip to site indexSearch & Section NavigationSection NavigationSEARCHU.S.InternationalCanadaEspañol中文 Today’s PaperSíguenos: FacebookTwitterNew York Times HomepageSection NavigationWorldU.S.PoliticsN.Y.BusinessOpinionScienceHealthSportsArtsBooksStyleFoodTravelMagazineReal EstateCookingThe AthleticWirecutterGamesNewsWorldBusinessArtsLifestyleOpinionCookingGamesWirecutterThe AthleticHighlightsPhotoCreditAgence France-Presse — Getty Images‘No se trata de otro golpe como los de siempre’: lo que hay que saber de la crisis en NígerEn medio de un golpe militar impredecible, los países vecinos han amenazado con entrar en guerra, algunos para frustrar la toma del poder y otros para garantizar su éxito. Por Declan WalshPhotoCreditAlana Paterson for The New York Times; Nasuna Stuart-Ulin for The New York TimesLos cambiaron al nacer: dos canadienses descubren sus raícesDurante 65 años, cada hombre tuvo la vida del otro. Por un lado, una infancia difícil complicada por las brutales políticas canadienses hacia los indígenas; por el otro, una educación despreocupada, impregnada de la cultura católica ucraniana. Por Norimitsu OnishiPhotoCreditJefferson Siegel para The New York TimesUn profesor es acusado de atraer mujeres a Nueva York y violarlasA lo largo de una década, Jorge Alberto Ramos le envió dinero al menos a tres mujeres para que viajaran desde El Salvador hasta el Bronx, donde abusó sexualmente de ellas, según la fiscalía. Por Lola FaduluPhotoCreditNicole RifkinOrígenesSurgen cuestionamientos a una teoría sobre la evolución del parto humanoLos científicos están revisando una influyente teoría que argumentaba que la evolución de los cerebros grandes en bebés y pelvis estrechas en mujeres lo volvía arriesgado. Por Carl ZimmerPhotoCreditAmit Elkayam for The New York Times¿Quién pagó por una misteriosa herramienta de espionaje? El FBI, según una investigación del FBITras un reportaje del Times, la agencia canceló su contrato con un contratista del gobierno. Pero sigue habiendo interrogantes. By Mark Mazzetti, Ronen Bergman y Adam GoldmanPhotoCreditLars LeetaruElon Musk quiere convertir a X en una ‘aplicación para todo’Al menos desde el año pasado, el magnate de la tecnología ha expresado su ambición de crear una aplicación integral, al estilo de las que se usan en Asia. By Ryan MacPhotoCreditGetty ImagesEl peso mexicano está fuerte. ¿Qué significa para tu economía?Para los mexicanos que trabajan en EE. UU. y otros países, un peso fuerte ha significado que el dinero que mandan a casa ya no rinde tanto como antes. Queremos saber tu experiencia. By J. Edward MorenoPhotoCreditMichael Sohn/Agence France-Presse — Getty ImagesAlemania enfrenta un desafío para lograr su independencia energética: bombas de conflictos pasadosLa complicada labor de encontrar y limpiar municiones antiguas y sin explotar se ha convertido en una rutina en la costa norte alemana. By Catie EdmondsonEnsayo invitadoPhotoCreditIlustración por Shoshana Schultz/The New York TimesEl poder del ‘lenguaje débil’ de las mujeresEn lugar de castigar a las mujeres por desafiar los estereotipos, deberíamos cuestionar esos estereotipos. By Adam GrantAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTOpiniónMás en Opinión ›PhotoCreditFelipe Dana/Associated PressHaeryun KangCorea del Norte y Corea del Sur se distancian cada día másSetenta años después del armisticio de la Guerra de Corea, el Norte y el Sur están más lejos de la unificación que nunca. By Haeryun KangPhotoCreditIlustración por Akshita Chandra/The New York Times; imágenes por Barbara Alper, Shelly Still/Getty ImagesJessica BennettVi ‘Barbie’ con una de las feministas más importantes del mundo. Y tiene una teoríaSusan Faludi, autora del clásico ‘Backlash’, tiene algunas ideas sobre la película de Greta Gerwig. By Jessica BennettPhotoCreditNatalie Keyssar para The New York TimesBret StephensLo que aprendí en UcraniaViajé al país y comprendí que los ucranianos hacen su vida cotidiana como si no hubiera guerra mientras hacen la guerra como si no hubiera vida cotidiana. By Bret StephensPhotoCreditAssociated PressKai BirdLa verdadera tragedia de OppenheimerLa historia del “padre de la bomba atómica”, como muestra la película de Christopher Nolan, es relevante para nuestros predicamentos políticos actuales. By Kai BirdPhotoCreditErnesto Ryan/Getty ImagesGuillermo GaratMontevideo se quedó sin agua dulce. ¿Pasará lo mismo en tu ciudad?Todas las ciudades del mundo tienen que empezar a planificar escenarios de sequías y en priorizar su agua potable. By Guillermo GaratEspecialMás en Especial ›PhotoCreditUniversal Pictures ("Oppenheimer"); Warner Bros. ("Barbie")‘Barbieheimer’: los entusiastas del cine están listos para una doble funciónAlgunos de los amantes del cine que planean ver el mismo día los estrenos de “Barbie” y “Oppenheimer” disfrutan de la incongruencia entre los dos estrenos. By Christopher KuoPhotoCreditAssociated PressLa verdadera tragedia de OppenheimerLa historia del “padre de la bomba atómica”, como muestra la película de Christopher Nolan, es relevante para nuestros predicamentos políticos actuales. By Kai BirdPhotoCreditRobert Alexander/Getty ImagesLo que ‘Oppenheimer’ no cuenta sobre la prueba de la bomba nuclearLa película aborda solo una parte de la historia del Proyecto Manhattan y no explora las consecuencias de la decisión de detonar el arma en un lugar donde mi familia y muchas otras habían vivido por generaciones. By Tina CordovaPhotoCreditEddie Adams/Associated PressQuién es quién en ‘Oppenheimer’: una guía de las personas y los hechos realesEl complejo drama de Christopher Nolan describe el desarrollo de la bomba nuclear y las maquinaciones políticas de mediados del siglo pasado. Este es el trasfondo. By Christopher KuoAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTWell: Notas de bienestarMás en Well: Notas de bienestar ›PhotoCreditEric Helgas for The New York Times¿El estrés puede provocar la caída del cabello?Si tu cabello se está volviendo más delgado durante momentos particularmente tensos, los expertos tienen algunas ideas sobre lo que podría estar pasando. By Melinda Wenner MoyerPhotoCreditJohn P. DessereauEste es el número que debería guíar tus decisiones de salud (y no es tu edad)La esperanza de vida figura cada vez más en los cálculos sobre si las pruebas de detección y los tratamientos son apropiados. Aquí te mostramos cómo averiguar la tuya. By Paula SpanPhotoCreditCarmen CasadoSi buscas una crema antiarrugas, el protector solar es tu mejor opciónLos rayos del sol causan la mayoría de los cambios en la piel que envejece. Te decimos cómo prevenirlos. By Dana G. SmithPhotoCreditJam Dong¿Es verdad que el azúcar alimenta a las células cancerosas?Muchos pacientes dicen que evitan los dulces para ayudar a combatir la enfermedad. Pero si bien una dieta saludable es importante, no se puede “matar de hambre a un tumor”. By Connie ChangPhotoCreditLars Klove para The New York TimesLo que deben saber los hombres antes de teñirse el cabelloPara muchos hombres, pintarse las canas puede ser la oportunidad de lucir una nueva apariencia o de señalar que están disponibles otra vez. A continuación, algunos consejos para hacerlo con dignidad. By Frank RojasEstados UnidosMás en Estados Unidos ›PhotoCreditMaddie McGarvey para The New York TimesLa acusación contra Trump desafía la democracia de EE. UU.La tercera acusación contra el expresidente aborda uno de los grandes temas de su presidencia: ¿Un mandatario puede difundir mentiras para mantenerse en el poder incluso si los votantes decidieron en las urnas lo contrario? By Peter BakerPhotoCreditKirsten Luce for The New York TimesLa explotación laboral de niños migrantes aumentó en el último año en EE. UU.Alrededor de 300.000 menores han llegado al país sin compañía desde 2021, lo que ha impulsado un aumento marcado en el trabajo infantil entre migrantes. By Hannah DreierPhotoCreditHaiyun Jiang para The New York Times; Desiree Rios para The New York Times¿A qué edad deberían retirarse los políticos?Dos momentos preocupantes que involucraron a los senadores Dianne Feinstein y Mitch McConnell provocaron preguntas sobre el envejecimiento de los líderes electos. By Lisa Lerer y Reid J. EpsteinPhotoCreditJames Devaney/GC Images vía Getty ImagesLa muy privada vida de Melania TrumpMientras su marido busca regresar a la Casa Blanca y se enfrenta a un riesgo legal cada vez mayor, la ex primera dama ha decidido mantenerse fuera del ojo público. By Lisa Lerer y Katie RogersPhotoCreditTrump es acusado por su papel en el asalto al Capitolio y la interferencia en las elecciones de 2020El expresidente, que está en campaña para regresar a la Casa Blanca, ha sido imputado por sus intentos de usar los mecanismos del Estado para permanecer en el poder. By Alan Feuer y Maggie HabermanAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTLo más recienteBuscarBuscarClear this text inputUn expresidente y tres acusacionesCuatro cargos contra Donald Trump, narcotanques en México y más para el fin de semana.Por Elda Cantú Lizzo es demandada por acoso y ambiente laboral hostilTres bailarinas aseguran que ir de gira con la ganadora del Grammy significó trabajar en una “atmósfera abiertamente sexual” y sus acusaciones parecen disputar la reputación de la cantante como defensora de la positividad corporal.Por Lauren McCarthyRead in English The MorningMéxico, un enemigo para algunos republicanosMiembros del Partido Republicano han planteado planes de intervención militar contra los cárteles mexicanos, lo que sería un acto de guerra contra uno de los aliados más cercanos de EE. UU.Por German LopezRead in English Ucrania y LatinoaméricaLa región ante la guerra, las consecuencias del “superpeso” mexicano y más.Por Elda Cantú Tech Fix¿ChatGPT te ha dado respuestas erróneas? Tal vez lo estás usando malSi guiamos a los chatbots de inteligencia artificial a fuentes confiables, reducimos el riesgo de que nos entreguen respuestas con datos erróneos.Por Brian X. ChenRead in English Los ‘narcotanques’ revelan el nivel de violencia de los cárteles en MéxicoLos grupos del crimen organizado están modificando camionetas con torretas armadas, refuerzos de acero y arietes, llevando el concepto de los camiones monstruo a nuevos niveles de letalidad.Por Simon Romero y Emiliano Rodríguez MegaRead in English Perfiles de la cienciaUn botánico con prisaDirigió la construcción del invernadero más grande de América y creó un programa para Colombia en los Jardines de Kew. El primer director latinoamericano del Jardín Botánico de Nueva York dice que es hora de que los jardines “empiecen a aportar soluciones al mundo”.Por Jennie Erin SmithRead in English Un peso mexicano fuerte plantea un desafío para quienes trabajan en el exteriorEl alza del peso significa que las remesas de los mexicanos en Estados Unidos no alcanzan para tanto como antes.Por J. Edward MorenoRead in English El Atlántico podría rebasar un ‘punto crítico’ de calentamiento en este sigloEl sistema de corrientes oceánicas que regula el clima de una franja del planeta podría colapsar antes de lo esperado, según un nuevo análisis.Por Raymond ZhongRead in English Hace 70 años se firmó el armisticio de la Guerra de Corea. Los combates terminaron; la guerra, noA lo largo de la zona desmilitarizada de Corea, los soldados de ambos lados están listos para enfrentarse. Las familias enfrentan décadas de separación, los turistas van a presenciar una historia viva y los sueños de reconciliación se desvanecen.Por Chang W. Lee y Choe Sang-HunRead in English AdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTSite IndexSite Information Navigation© 2023 The New York Times CompanyNYTCoContact UsAccessibilityWork with usAdvertiseT Brand StudioYour Ad ChoicesPrivacy PolicyTerms of ServiceTerms of SaleSite MapCanadaInternationalHelpSubscriptions

title: U.S. News - The New York Times
body: Skip to contentSkip to site indexSearch & Section NavigationSection NavigationSEARCHU.S. News Today’s PaperAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTSupported bySKIP ADVERTISEMENTU.S. NewsWildfire and Air Quality TrackerCalifornia TodayRace/RelatedHighlightsPhotoCreditRuth Fremson/The New York TimesMichigan Republicans Charged in False Elector Scheme Appear in CourtThe hearing in state court came in the same week that former President Donald J. Trump pleaded not guilty to federal charges connected to efforts to overturn the 2020 election. By Mitch Smith and Julie BosmanPhotoCreditWillie J. Allen Jr./Orlando Sentinel, via Associated PressThe College Board Says A.P. Psychology Is ‘Effectively Banned’ in FloridaThe nonprofit said it would not remove a section on gender and sexual orientation, as Florida had requested, and advised districts not to offer the course. By Sarah MervoshPhotoCreditMeredith Seaver/College Station Eagle, via Associated PressTexas A&M Agrees to $1 Million Settlement With Journalism ProfessorA university report found that fears of a conservative backlash botched the effort to hire a Black professor, Kathleen McElroy, to run its journalism program. By Stephanie SaulPhotoCreditJacob Langston for The New York TimesNew Florida Immigration Rules Start to Strain Some BusinessesSome employers said they were losing workers because of the new law, which was championed by Gov. Ron DeSantis. By Miriam JordanAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTLatestSearchSearchClear this text inputOfficers Hold Family at Gunpoint After License Plate Mix-UpA family was headed to a youth basketball tournament when they were stopped in Frisco, Texas, after officers made a typo while running their plates. The department later apologized.By Rebecca Carballo Leah Remini, Vocal Scientology Critic, Files Suit Against ChurchThe lawsuit, which alleges a pattern of harassment and defamation, is a culmination of a decade of criticism of Scientology by Ms. Remini, an actress, since she broke publicly with the church.By Christine Hauser and Remy Tumin Michigan Republicans Charged in False Elector Scheme Appear in CourtThe hearing in state court came in the same week that former President Donald J. Trump pleaded not guilty to federal charges connected to efforts to overturn the 2020 election.By Mitch Smith and Julie Bosman DeSantis Dismisses Trump’s 2020 Election Theories as FalseAfter long hedging, the Florida governor went further than he has before in acknowledging that the election was not stolen.By Nicholas Nehamas and Lisa Lerer New Florida Immigration Rules Start to Strain Some BusinessesSome employers said they were losing workers because of the new law, which was championed by Gov. Ron DeSantis.By Miriam Jordan 4,000 Rescued Beagles, Bred for Research, Found Homes and Best FriendsThe dogs, held in cages at a breeding and research facility, were bound for labs. About 4,000 were saved and, almost a year later, many are thriving with their families.By Lauren McCarthy and Johnny Diaz California TodayWhat Happens When California Clears Its Homeless Encampments?A conversation with Livia Albeck-Ripka, who recently wrote about the closure of a camp in Oakland, one of the state’s largest.By Soumya Karlamangla Chris Christie Meets With Ukrainian President in Surprise Trip to KyivMr. Christie is the second 2024 G.O.P. hopeful to visit the war-torn nation, signaling his support for Ukraine in its effort to repel Russia.By Charles Homans Mike Pence Has Reached His Fork in the RoadThe former vice president and Jan. 6 witness is campaigning to persuade voters. But is he also trying to warn them?By Matt Flegenheimer Trump Leads G.O.P. in Iowa, but His Hold Is Less DominantNew polling suggests that Gov. Ron DeSantis’s efforts in Iowa have been having an effect, but that the challenge of defeating Mr. Trump there is complicated by multiple factors.By Jonathan Weisman AdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTSite IndexSite Information Navigation© 2023 The New York Times CompanyNYTCoContact UsAccessibilityWork with usAdvertiseT Brand StudioYour Ad ChoicesPrivacy PolicyTerms of ServiceTerms of SaleSite MapCanadaInternationalHelpSubscriptions

title: Business - The New York Times
body:
Skip to contentSkip to site indexSearch & Section NavigationSection NavigationSEARCHBusiness Today’s PaperAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTSupported bySKIP ADVERTISEMENTBusinessTechEconMediaMoneyDealBookHighlightsPhotoCreditKarl RussellU.S. Extends Job Growth Streak Even as Economy CoolsEmployers added 187,000 workers in July, a slower pace than the recent norm, but “more sustainable,” one economist said. By Lydia DePillisPhotoCreditWang Zhao/Agence France-Presse — Getty ImagesChina Wants Children to Spend Less Time on Their SmartphonesA proposal from the country’s internet regulator would require app developers and device makers to adopt a “minor mode” to limit screen time and content for young people. By Yan Zhuang and Siyi ZhaoPhotoCreditGabriella Angotti-Jones for The New York TimesThe Recovery Left Nevada Behind. Can the State Change Its Luck?Nevada has the highest unemployment rate in the country at 5.4 percent as officials insist the economy must move away from its focus on gambling. By Kurtis LeePhotoCreditLam Yik Fei for The New York TimesWhy TSMC Will Keep Its Roots in Taiwan, Even as It Goes GlobalIn an interview, the chip maker’s chairman, Mark Liu, explained why TSMC’s top tech would stay in Taiwan, despite growing threats from China and worries from the United States. By John Liu and Paul MozurPhotoCreditLam Yik Fei for The New York TimesThe Chip Titan Whose Life’s Work Is at the Center of a Tech Cold WarAt 92, Morris Chang, the founder of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, can no longer stay in the shadows. By Paul Mozur and John LiuStrategiesPhotoCreditMinet KimThe Risks Hidden in Public Pension FundsAttracted by promises of high returns, many public pension funds have been loading up on private equity but may not fully appreciate the dangers, our columnist says. By Jeff SommerPhotoCreditIllustration by Zak Bickel/The New York Times; images by ShutterstockSo What Do We Call Twitter Now Anyway?With Elon Musk’s rebranding of the app, is Twitter’s name really retired? What about tweets? We unravel the terminology puzzle. By Kate CongerPhotoCreditKarsten Moran for The New York TimesAmazon Posts 11% Rise in Revenue as Growth ImprovesThe retailer also swung to a profit in the second quarter. By David StreitfeldPhotoCreditIlvy Njiokiktjien for The New York TimesWhat Can You Do When A.I. Lies About You?People have little protection or recourse when the technology creates and spreads falsehoods about them. By Tiffany HsuAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTLatestSearchSearchClear this text inputWilliam H. Dilday Jr., First Black TV Station Manager in U.S., Dies at 85Hired to run a troubled Mississippi affiliate of NBC, he turned it into a respected and highly profitable operation, with a more diverse staff.By Clay Risen Shares of Carl Icahn’s Firm Tank After It Cuts DividendBowing to pressure from a short seller, Mr. Icahn halved his company’s quarterly dividend and said he would return to the style of investing that made him famous.By Maureen Farrell Digital Replicas, a Fear of Striking Actors, Already Fill ScreensThe technology for morphing flesh-and-blood performers into virtual avatars has been improving for years. Now it has become an issue in the actors’ strike.By Marc Tracy The Big Number: $15 MillionGeorge Clooney and Meryl Streep have helped raise $15 million for striking actorsBy Marie Solis 4,000 Rescued Beagles, Bred for Research, Found Homes and Best FriendsThe dogs, held in cages at a breeding and research facility, were bound for labs. About 4,000 were saved and, almost a year later, many are thriving with their families.By Lauren McCarthy and Johnny Diaz DealBook NewsletterApple’s and Amazon’s Report Cards for the Global EconomyThe companies’ latest earnings reports provide insight into the state of consumers and businesses, including where they’re willing to spend — and cut costs.By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni Anger Builds in Towns Deliberately Flooded, in Part, to Save BeijingA provincial leader set off an outcry by urging cities to serve as a “moat” for the capital, as diverted floodwaters sent scores of residents fleeing.By Keith Bradsher ‘You Have to Work Extra to Hire People’: What Companies Have Been Saying About JobsSome executives said they were not expanding their payrolls as quickly as they had, while others were more concerned about wage growth, which has remained robust.By J. Edward Moreno Travel 101Jet Lag: Get Back in the RhythmInsomnia, drowsiness and brain fog can all take some of the fun out of your first few days in a faraway place. You can’t avoid jet lag, but you can follow some tips to bounce back faster.By Julie Weed Shop Talk‘Going Concern,’ Going BustThe term, which refers to a company that will continue to operate for at least a year, is rarely used unless a company is in trouble.By Jason Karaian AdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTBusiness Delivered to Your Inbox


Sign up for one of our daily or weekly newsletters.


DealBook
The news driving the markets and the conversation. (Daily)




Your Money
Tips on retirement, paying for college, credit cards and the right way to invest. (Weekly)

title: Style - The New York Times
body: Skip to contentSkip to site indexSearch & Section NavigationSection NavigationSEARCHStyle Today’s PaperAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTSupported bySKIP ADVERTISEMENTStyleFashionLoveSelf-CareHighlightsPhotoCreditAnna Moneymaker/Agence France-Presse — Getty ImagesDoes Anyone Care About Justin Trudeau’s Separation?A stable marriage (publicly at least) used to be a cornerstone of any world leader’s résumé. Not in 2023. By Elizabeth PatonPhotoCreditKyle GordonIt Happened OnlineA Mystery on the ‘Planet of the Bass’Is the ’90s Eurodance parody an ironic hit — or just a hit? By Callie Holtermann and Madison Malone KircherPhotoCreditMichelle V. Agins/The New York TimesThe Jell-O Shot RenaissanceAcross the country, bars are serving jiggly, alcoholic concoctions that are nothing like the college party version. By Alyson KruegerPhotoCreditClive Brunskill/Getty ImagesRoger Federer Is Having Fun in RetirementThe tennis star and Jonathan Anderson have teamed up with Uniqlo to create a sports-inspired fashion collection. By Alyson KruegerStyles Group ChatPhotoCreditCraig Blankenhorn/Max‘And Just Like That …’ Episode 8 Fashion: Losing the SpanxIn the new episode, Carrie and Aidan lean into their relationship, and Charlotte and Miranda start new jobs. By The Styles DeskPhotoCreditvia CameoStriking Actors Are Turning to Cameo for Extra CashOthers are using the service, through which fans can pay for personalized videos, to engage with followers while not publicly promoting work. By Perri Ormont BlumbergPhotoCreditUnderwood Archives/Getty ImagesBefore There Was Pee-wee, There Was PinkyPaul Reubens’s trademark style took plenty of its inspiration from a performer long forgotten. By Guy TrebaySocial Q’sPhotoCreditMiguel PorlanMy New Boyfriend Is a Dud at Buying Gifts. What Can I Do?A reader asks whether she should be more blunt about her wish for birthday and anniversary presents from a man who isn’t the gift-giving type. By Philip GalanesPhotoCreditWhat We Saw on the Beyoncé ExpressDressed in their “Renaissance” best, fans flooded New Jersey Transit to catch the superstar’s pair of performances at MetLife Stadium this weekend. By Callie Holtermann and Amir HamjaAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTIt Happened OnlineMore in It Happened Online ›PhotoCreditAlain Jocard/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images‘X’ Marks the SpotElon Musk’s decision to ditch the Twitter brand is confusing on many levels. By Madison Malone KircherPhotoCreditJenna Schoenefeld for The New York TimesAre Influencers on Strike Too?The Hollywood work stoppage could shake up your For You page. By Madison Malone KircherPhotoCreditDado Ruvic/ReutersThreads: An Early Vibe CheckIt’s early days, but more than 30 million users have signed up. PhotoCreditYuichi Yamazaki/Agence France-Presse — Getty ImagesShein’s Influencer FiascoHow the brand’s use of creators triggered a backlash. PhotoCredit@ahrenfnThe TikTok Search for the Titanic SubTragedies can be good business on social media. LoveMore in Love ›PhotoCreditKayleigh Taylor PhotographyWhile Navigating Life’s Changes, a Teenage Romance EnduresNeither Olivia Amitrano nor Nicholas Vazquez are afraid to change their minds, whether it’s about living off the grid, work or a wedding dress. By Jenny BlockPhotoCreditTrene' Forbes PhotographyHow to Find Wedding Vendors That Celebrate InclusionFor many couples, working with businesses that share their values and support people from diverse backgrounds is an important part of the planning process. By Sadiba HasanPhotoCreditDanielle HeinsonThe Looming Crisis in the Bridal Industry? Not Enough Seamstresses.The skilled professionals who work on wedding dress alterations play a crucial role for brides, but their numbers are dwindling. By Shannon SimsPhotoCreditB. Frohman Imaging and DesignA Recipe for Love? Add ‘Water and Sunlight.’Before meeting Jennifer Ziegler, Rebecca Woodfork said she was always “looking down and getting through life.” One month together in Boston and a trip to St. Lucia changed that. By Valeriya SafronovaPhotoCreditSerge GrenierFor Luck in Love, Couples Are Breaking Plates (On Purpose)In Germany, smashing porcelain plates is a time-honored wedding custom that is said to bring good fortune and harmony to newlyweds. By Alix StraussAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTLatestSearchSearchClear this text inputLove Letter: Honoring O’Shae Sibley at the Stonewall Inn“He was just a beautiful spirit, a wonderful person, just exercising his freedom to be alive.”By Miya Lee How To: Decorate an outdoor spaceIt’s August Already: Are You Making the Most of Your Patio or Terrace?Designers Christine and John Gachot should know how to furnish an outdoor space: Their rental has six. Here’s their step-by-step guide.By Tim McKeough Japan’s Enduring ‘Sound of Summer’Created 75 years ago for the country’s prestigious high school baseball tournament, Yuji Koseki’s “The Crown Will Shine on You” stirs memories as it inspires new ones.By Brad Lefton How to Decorate an Outdoor SpaceDesigners Christine and John Gachot offer a step-by-step guide to decorating an outdoor space.By Tim McKeough Modern LoveWould Marrying Her Be a Giant Mistake?I was warned not to marry outside my faith, but when Jillian was asleep in my bed, I would cry, unable to imagine a world without her.By Istiaq Mian mini-vowsThe Unlikely Run-In That Blossomed Into MoreDancers and musicians rarely cross paths at Juilliard, so a drag queen and a T-shirt brought Christopher Reynolds and John Hewitt together.By Aamina Khan mini-vowsHow Sure of Love? 100 Percent, and Then Some.Anne Huntington was producing a podcast about dating — all while avoiding commitment. Tyler DePatis, on the other hand, was “110 percent” sure about her.By Anna Grace Lee mini-vowsWas It a Job Interview or a Date? She Soon Found Out.Ashutosh Upreti asked Katherine Maher out for drinks after they met at a friend’s Seder. At first, she mistakenly thought their get-together was for a job and began interviewing him.By Rosalie R. Radomsky Take the Quiz! Pick the Worst New York City Summer Plagues.Roaches. Aphids. Rats. How many scourges can one city have? Lately, old annoyances have been joined by new terrors. In this quiz, you get to choose your own nightmare!By Dodai Stewart ‘Birds Are My Eyesight’For some blind birders, avian soundscapes are a way to map the world around them. Increasing noise pollution is imperiling that navigation.By Alexandra Marvar AdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTFollow UsNYTimesStylesfacebook page for NYTimesStylesNYTStylestwitter page for NYTStylesNYTFashiontwitter page for NYTFashionNYTimesFashioninstagram page for NYTimesFashionAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTSite IndexSite Information Navigation© 2023 The New York Times CompanyNYTCoContact UsAccessibilityWork with usAdvertiseT Brand StudioYour Ad ChoicesPrivacy PolicyTerms of ServiceTerms of SaleSite MapCanadaInternationalHelpSubscriptions
