title: Book Review - The New York Times
body:
Skip to contentSkip to site indexSearch & Section NavigationSection NavigationSEARCHBook Review Today’s PaperAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTSupported bySKIP ADVERTISEMENTArtsBook ReviewWhat to ReadStaff CriticsBest SellersBy the BookBook Review PodcastChildren's BooksHighlightsPhotoCreditNoah Van SciverChildren’s BooksHow One Adman Created the American Fantasy of Paul BunyanIn W.B. Laughead’s 1916 logging industry pamphlet, a minor Midwestern folk hero underwent a major growth spurt. By Patricia Nelson LimerickPhotoCreditEditors’ choice9 New Books We Recommend This WeekSuggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times. PhotoCreditDavid M. Rubenstein Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Duke UniversityNonfictionThe Sea Captain Who Ran From Abraham LincolnIn “Shipwrecked,” the historian Jonathan W. White tells the story of an outlaw mariner who worked for the Confederacy and against the Klan. By Dorothy WickendenPhotoCreditBrian KimsleyInside the best-seller ListJennette McCurdy Now Qualifies as a Veteran Best SellerSome publishers balked at the title but, just shy of its first birthday, “I’m Glad My Mom Died” has stood the test of time. By Elisabeth EganVisualsPhotoCreditIn an Open Loft in Gowanus, Six Authors and Artists Collaborate and CommuneFor the children’s book creators Doug Salati, Brian Floca, Sophie Blackall, Rowboat Watkins, Johnny Marciano and Dasha Tolstikova, the light-filled space has become much more than just a place to work. By Elizabeth A. Harris and Adrianna GlavianoPhotoCreditRaphaelle MacaronRead Your Way Through HanoiHanoi, long a city of storytellers, has been devastated and reborn time and time again. Nguyễn Phan Quế Mai guides readers through the literature that has played a part in that renewal. By Nguyễn Phan Quế MaiPhotoCreditAlex Eben MeyerA.I.’s Inroads in Publishing Touch Off Fear, and CreativityThe technology has the potential to affect nearly every aspect of how books are produced — even the act of writing itself. By Elizabeth A. Harris and Alexandra AlterPhotoCreditWhat Book Should You Read Next?Finding a book you’ll love can be daunting. Let us help. By The New York Times Books StaffPhotoCredit14 New Books Coming in AugustNovels from Ann Patchett and James McBride, a biography of the Chinese American movie star Anna May Wong and a handful of edgy thrillers — including one about a scuba driver swallowed by a whale. By The New York Times Books StaffAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTBooks of The TimesMore in Books of The Times ›PhotoCreditHow Four Female Philosophers Responded to a Dire Decade“The Visionaries,” by Wolfram Eilenberger, examines the divergent theories of self and other developed in a time of crisis by Hannah Arendt, Simone de Beauvoir, Ayn Rand and Simone Weil. By Jennifer SzalaiPhotoCreditOwen Gent‘Tom Lake’ Finds Ann Patchett in a Chekhovian MoodThis time the celebrated novelist spins the cozy tale of a former actress, her three daughters and their rueful memories. There’s a cherry orchard, too. By Alexandra JacobsPhotoCreditStories Like Norman Rockwell Paintings, if Rockwell Painted GuillotinesIn his new story collection, “Disruptions,” Steven Millhauser reveals the bizarre within the mundane. By Dwight GarnerPhotoCreditTony Luong for The New York TimesA New Arrival in ‘The Country of the Blind’In his memoir, Andrew Leland discovers that slowly losing one’s sight offers a special understanding of vision — and its limits. By Alexandra JacobsPhotoCreditDiego MalloAfter a Great Flood, a Struggle Between Faith and ReasonKhaled Khalifa’s new novel follows two friends through disaster and religious tension in early-20th-century Syria. By Dwight GarnerLatestSearchSearchClear this text inputA Poem About Dance and the Hard Work of TranscendenceThe lessons of Rita Dove’s “American Smooth,” one of the best-loved poems of the last two decades.By Dwight Garner Ann Patchett on Summer Love and Her New NovelThe author discusses “Tom Lake,” bookstore secrets and the play “Our Town.” Paperback Row6 Paperbacks to Read This Week Selected paperbacks from the Book Review, including Paul Newman's memoir and novels by James Hannaham and Adam Levin.By Shreya Chattopadhyay Seiichi Morimura, 90, Who Exposed Japanese Wartime Atrocities, DiesIn a widely read book, he detailed gruesome biological experiments on people at a secret Imperial Army site in occupied China before and during World War II.By Richard Sandomir阅读简体中文版閱讀繁體中文版 Book ExcerptThe Playwright Who Changed the Face of American TheaterIn this excerpt from “August Wilson: A Life,” the playwright, on the cusp of stardom, is polishing off his latest play, “Fences,” at the O’Neill writers’ conference.By Patti Hartigan ‘The Notebook’ Musical to Land on Broadway in the SpringThe adaptation of the popular Nicholas Sparks romance novel, with music and lyrics by Ingrid Michaelson, had a well-reviewed run last year in Chicago.By Sarah Bahr The Art of Telling Forbidden Stories in ChinaMany writers are looking for ways to capture the everyday realities that the government keeps hidden — sometimes at their own peril.By Han Zhang By the BookEdan Lepucki’s Favorite Place to Read Is in the Tub“Have you ever smoked a joint and read Toni Morrison’s ‘Sula’ in a very hot bath, reveling in a single, rich paragraph for what feels like an hour?” says the novelist, whose new book is “Time’s Mouth.” “If not, may I suggest you try it?” Poem: Powerless Self-JudgementWill Alexander’s visionary work achieves its effect through sound, not image.By Will Alexander and Anne Boyer Bidding for Simon & Schuster Draws to a CloseThe move to acquire the publisher, one of the five largest in the country, comes after the government blocked a deal last year on antitrust concerns.By Benjamin Mullin, Elizabeth A. Harris and Lauren Hirsch AdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTBest Sellers

title: Science - The New York Times
body: Skip to contentSkip to site indexSearch & Section NavigationSection NavigationSEARCHScience Today’s PaperAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTSupported bySKIP ADVERTISEMENTScienceClimateSpace & AstronomyHealthTrilobitesMatterOut ThereCovid PandemicHighlightsPhotoCreditChristopher MahTrilobitesNew Antarctic Starfish Are Doting Parents and Vicious PredatorsA close examination of a collection of starfish in the Smithsonian revealed even more starfish inside those starfish. By Darren IncorvaiaPhotoCreditCatoctin Furnace Historical SocietyEnslaved African Americans in Maryland Linked to 42,000 Living RelativesThe analysis marks the first time historical DNA has been used to trace the descendants and distant cousins of enslaved people, researchers said. By Carl ZimmerPhotoCreditHyun-Tak KimLK-99 Is the Superconductor of the SummerSocial media users are excited about what would be a breakthrough in solid state physics, but many experts in the field are cautiously skeptical. By Kenneth ChangPhotoCreditEve ThomasonTrilobitesElectrocution Isn’t the Main Thing Killing Birds Along Power LinesA survey of power lines in four Western states found bullet fragments and shotgun pellets in most of the dead birds that were collected. By Carolyn WilkePhotoCreditAlberto GennariThis Ancient Whale May Have Been the Heaviest Animal EverPerucetus drifted through shallow seas like a gigantic manatee, scientists suspect. By Carl ZimmerTrilobitesPhotoCreditChristian McCall505-Million-Year-Old Jellyfish Fossils May Be the Oldest Ever FoundThe specimens are evidence of how little the squishy, tentacled predators have changed over the history of life on Earth. By Jack TamisieaPhotoCreditSteve Ruark/Associated PressFamily of Henrietta Lacks Settles With Biotech Company That Used Her CellsMs. Lacks’s family had accused Thermo Fisher Scientific of profiting from her cells, which have contributed to revolutionary advances in medicine, without seeking their permission. By Amanda HolpuchPhotoCreditHaas, et al., Science Advances 2020Move Over, Men: Women Were Hunters, TooAnthropologists are finding that women in modern foraging societies have played a major role in catching game. By Katrina MillerPhotoCredit6 Great Space Images From JulyA star with two faces, boulders cast into the void, space junk on a beach and more out of this world scenes. By Michael RostonAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTTrilobitesMore in Trilobites ›PhotoCreditPeter NickolausA Pancaked Turtle Fossil’s 150-Million-Year-Old TaleA beautifully preserved shelled reptile recovered from a Bavarian limestone deposit helps tell the story of how turtles first took to the seas. By Asher ElbeinPhotoCreditAleksey Suvorov/AlamyWhen Ancient Eruptions Pumped Diamonds to Earth’s SurfaceA new study offers clues to the mysteries of kimberlite eruptions, the source of most of the diamonds mined on Earth today. By Maya Wei-HaasPhotoCreditJustine Hudson/Fisheries and Oceans CanadaThe Prize for the Longest Pregnancy in Mammals May Go to This WhaleBowhead whales may carry their babies for as long as 23 months, although more research is needed to confirm the finding. By Miriam FauziaPhotoCreditMichael SkrepnickThis Fossil Is a Freeze-Frame of a Mammal Fighting a DinosaurIt’s like a man-bites-dog story from prehistoric times, although researchers had to take steps to verify that it was not a forgery. By Kate GolembiewskiPhotoCreditDepartment of Special Collections, Hesburgh Libraries of Notre DameWhat Benjamin Franklin Learned While Fighting CounterfeitersLong before there were Benjamins in circulation, the founding father was all about experimenting with printing techniques as he worked on securing colonial printed currency. By Veronique GreenwoodOriginsMore in Origins ›PhotoCreditBizarre Sea Creatures Illuminate the Dawn of the Animal KingdomA new study bolsters the idea that the first animals were surprisingly complex, perhaps equipped with muscles and a nervous system. By Carl ZimmerPhotoCreditNico Garstman/Naturalis Biodiversity CenterScience Museums Take Stock of 1.1 Billion Objects From Around the WorldNatural history museums have joined forces to produce a global digital inventory of their prized collections, from pinned butterflies to dinosaur skulls. By Carl ZimmerPhotoCreditJürgen Vogel, LVR-LandesMuseum BonnAncient DNA Reveals History of Hunter-Gatherers in EuropeLooking at DNA gleaned from ancient remains, researchers identified at least eight previously unknown populations of early Europeans. By Carl ZimmerPhotoCreditBeth ZaikenOldest Known DNA Offers Glimpse of a Once-Lush ArcticIn Greenland’s permafrost, scientists discovered two-million-year-old genetic material from scores of plant and animal species, including mastodons, geese, lemmings and ants. By Carl ZimmerPhotoCreditSteve Gschmeissner/Science SourceÓmicron cumple un año. Así ha evolucionadoAl cumplirse el aniversario del descubrimiento de la variante, los expertos en virología siguen intentando ponerse al día con la rápida transformación de ómicron. By Carl ZimmerAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTClimate and EnvironmentMore in Climate and Environment ›PhotoCreditNatacha Pisarenko/Associated PressHeat Wave Grips Portions of South America in the Middle of WinterAn unusual winter heat wave has brought record high temperatures to cities across Argentina, Chile and Paraguay this week, triggering concerns about the impacts of climate change. By Jesus Jiménez and Natalie AlcobaPhotoCreditThe New York TimesAntarctic Sea Ice Is at a ‘Very Concerning’ Record LowIt’s winter in Antarctica, when sea ice cover typically grows. But this year’s sea ice is way behind, reaching record lows with implications for the planet. By Delger Erdenesanaa and Leanne AbrahamPhotoCreditA Desperate Push to Save Florida’s Coral: Get It Out of the SeaTeams dedicated to ocean restoration are urgently moving samples to tanks on land as a marine heat wave devastates entire reefs. By Catrin Einhorn and Jason GulleyPhotoCreditMaddie McGarvey for The New York TimesIt’s Official: Stores Can No Longer Sell Most Incandescent LightsNew efficiency rules, more than a decade in the making, have taken effect, relegating Edison’s glowing orbs to the history books. By Hiroko TabuchiPhotoCreditSeiji MatsumotoThis Guide Can Help You Save Money and Fight Climate ChangeWhether you are renovating your home, upgrading appliances or buying an electric car, this guide can help you take advantage of savings from the Inflation Reduction Act. By Nadja Popovich and Elena ShaoLatestSearchSearchClear this text input‘It’s Crazy’: The Scramble for Ancient Treasures After Ukraine’s Dam DisasterAfter the Kakhovka dam was blown up in June, the reservoir above it quickly drained, revealing a bonanza of artifacts that has electrified Ukrainian archaeologists.By Jeffrey Gettleman and Finbarr O’Reilly Medical Group Backs Youth Gender Treatments, but Calls for Research ReviewThe American Academy of Pediatrics renewed its support of gender care for minors while commissioning a fresh look at the evidence.By Azeen Ghorayshi Leprosy May Be Endemic in Central Florida, Scientists ReportStill, there are fewer than 200 cases nationally each year, and the numbers have fallen significantly from the peak decades ago.By Apoorva Mandavilli Amid Signs of a Covid Uptick, Researchers Brace for the ‘New Normal’Infections remain very low, despite signs of a slight increase. Now, experts are looking for clues to what living with the coronavirus will be like this winter and beyond.By Apoorva Mandavilli Alan Roland, 93, Psychoanalyst Who Cautioned Against Western Bias, DiesIn “In Search of Self” and other books, he emphasized the role of cultural influences in a patient’s life.By Neil Genzlinger NASA’s Voyager 2 Is Out of Contact but Not Lost in SpaceThe aging spacecraft’s antenna was misdirected by a glitch, although officials say the distant probe appears to be functioning as intended.By Katrina Miller Saving Lives at the Grand Canyon, One Salty Snack at a TimeIn a summer of deadly heat for hikers in the Southwest, rangers at Grand Canyon National Park use a pioneering approach of aggressive messaging and outreach to prevent disaster on the trails.By Rowan Moore Gerety Scenes From a City That Only Hands Out Tickets for Using FentanylOregon’s experiment to curb overdoses by decriminalizing small amounts of illicit drugs is in its third year, and life has changed for most everyone in the city of Portland.By Jordan Gale and Jan Hoffman Profiles in ScienceMauricio Diazgranados Is a Botanist in a HurryFor the first time, the New York Botanical Garden has a chief scientist who hails from the same region as so much of its collections.By Jennie Erin SmithLeer en español Is It an E-Bike, or a Motorcycle for Children?With a throttle and no pedals, Super73’s new “electric balance bike” blurs the lines of regulation and safety. “No license, registration or insurance required,” its marketing promises.By Matt Richtel AdvertisementSKIP title: Sports - The New York Times
body: Skip to contentSkip to site indexSearch & Section NavigationSection NavigationSEARCHSports Today’s PaperAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTSupported bySKIP ADVERTISEMENTSportsM.L.B.N.F.L.College FootballN.B.A.W.N.B.A.College BasketballN.H.L.SoccerGolfTennisScoreboardsM.L.B.N.F.L.College FootballN.B.A.W.N.B.A.College BasketballN.H.L.GolfTennisHighlightsPhotoCreditMarty Melville/Agence France-Presse — Getty ImagesOn SoccerAt the World Cup, the Field Thins and the Contenders ExpandAfter 48 games, half of the teams have been sent home. And yet it feels as if the field of potential winners is bigger than it was at the start. By Rory SmithPhotoCreditJenna Watson/Usa Today SportsInside U.S. Team, a Campaign to Avert Disaster Gets PersonalBlocking out criticism they call “noise,” Lindsey Horan and other veterans are taking a one-on-one approach to turning around their World Cup fortunes. By Juliet MacurPhotoCreditKyodo News, via Getty ImagesJapan’s Enduring ‘Sound of Summer’Created 75 years ago for the country’s prestigious high school baseball tournament, Yuji Koseki’s “The Crown Will Shine on You” stirs memories as it inspires new ones. By Brad LeftonPhotoCreditAshley Landis/Associated PressSimone Biles Set to Compete for First Time Since Tokyo OlympicsBiles, the decorated American gymnast, is making her return to elite competition on Saturday at the U.S. Classic. The field also includes Sunisa Lee, the reigning Olympic all-around champion. By Carla CorreaQ. And A.PhotoCreditArmando Babani/EPA, via ShutterstockJan Frodeno Begins His Triathlon Farewell Tour. Up Next? More Risky Sports.Frodeno, 41, has dominating the triathlon since winning Olympic gold in 2008. This will be his last competitive season. By Matthew FuttermanOn SoccerPhotoCreditMaja Hitij/FIFA, via Getty ImagesSpain’s Team Went to War. Now It Has to Win the Peace.A failed rebellion against Coach Jorge Vilda ended with a dozen players dropped for the Women’s World Cup. Those who remain might be good enough to win it. By Rory SmithPhotoCreditTertius Pickard/Associated PressWomen’s World Cup: South Korea Sends Germany Out, Letting Morocco Move OnColombia and Morocco will advance after one of the craziest finishes to a group stage in the history of the tournament. Sports of The TimesPhotoCreditI Gave Up on Boxing, Not on This BoxerDecades after turning away from the sport because of its violence, our columnist revisited Seniesa Estrada’s journey to becoming a champion — and wondered if it was worth the risk. By Kurt Streeter and Erin SchaffPhotoCreditHector Vivas/Getty ImagesGiven Plenty of Space, Lionel Messi Is Putting on a ShowMessi is scoring in bunches and last-place Inter Miami is a contender in the Leagues Cup. Could an M.L.S. playoff push be next? By Victor MatherPhotoCreditPhelan M. Ebenhack/Associated PressOrlando Magic’s Political Donation Is ‘Alarming,’ Players’ Union SaysThe team donated $50,000 to a super PAC supportive of Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida. The union said that does not mean Magic players support him. By Sopan DebPhotoCreditAmir Hamja/The New York TimesThis Jazz Artist Makes Pro Football Hall of Fame Speeches SingWhen the Pro Football Hall of Fame’s inductees began to ramble, executives turned to Jezra Kaye to help them rein it in. By Ken BelsonOn BaseballPhotoCreditPaul Sancya/Associated PressIn New York, One Team Is Lost and the Other Is Targeting 2025The middling Yankees have no idea who they are. The Mets’ sell-off gives them a clearer identity. By Tyler KepnerPhotoCreditAllen Kee/ESPNHow ESPN Went From Disney’s Financial Engine to Its ProblemThe sports juggernaut continues to earn billions of dollars for Disney, but profits are down and opportunities for growth have dwindled. By Kevin Draper and Brooks BarnesPhotoCreditDoug Mills/The New York TimesTiger Woods Joins PGA Tour Board in Concession to Player DemandsWith the addition of Woods, players will outnumber independent directors, giving them the final say in the tour’s plan to form a partnership with Saudi Arabia’s sovereign wealth fund. By Kevin Draper, Alan Blinder and Lauren HirschAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTWomen’s World CupPhotoCreditWomen’s World Cup Bracket: The Knockout StageIt’s “win or go home” time in the Women’s World Cup knockout stage. Follow the latest scores and the bracket here. By The New York TimesPhotoCreditWomen's World Cup Schedule PromoWomen’s World Cup Schedule: Teams, Kickoff Times and TVPrepare for some late nights and some math: The Women’s World Cup will take place in multiple time zones in two countries. PhotoCreditAllison McCannWhy U.S. Players Will Get the Most Prize Money, Even if They LoseFIFA recommended a share of the pot for all World Cup players. But the U.S. women will outpace them all because of an agreement with U.S. Soccer. By Allison McCannPhotoCreditIllustration by Madison KetchamThe Curse Stalking Women’s SoccerThe World Cup is missing some of the sport’s biggest stars because of a knee injury epidemic. No one can say for sure why it’s happening, or how to fix it. By Rory SmithPhotoCreditAbbie Parr/Associated PressCovering the Women’s World Cup Takes Stamina and CoffeeJuliet Macur, a Sports reporter, is chasing the story of the U.S. national women’s soccer team at this year’s tournament. By Emmett LindnerLatestSearchSearchClear this text input‘Winning Time’ Is Back. Here’s What to Know Ahead of Season 2Season 1 of HBO’s series about the 1980s Lakers came with drama, in more ways than one. Expect more for Season 2. An N.B.A. reporter takes a look.By Tania Ganguli ‘Air Bud: World Pup’ Keeps Winning Fans for the 1999 World Cup StarsThe 2000 movie used the franchise’s furry hero along with members of the actual U.S. women’s team to reimagine the penalty shootout that led to the win.By Claire Fahy Morocco Wins, Then Waits, and Then Starts CelebratingMorocco had never won a game in the Women’s World Cup a week ago but now has won two in a row to advance to the knockout rounds.By Aida Alami and Andrew Das Colombia and Germany try to lock down the last two round of 16 places.By Claire Fahy on pro basketballThe N.B.A. and Its Owners Fight for Change. But Not Necessarily the Same Change.The league embraces progressive causes supported by players. But some team owners pull in the opposite direction, as apparent in the Orlando Magic’s donation to Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida.By Sopan Deb Roger Federer Is Having Fun in RetirementThe tennis star and Jonathan Anderson have teamed up with Uniqlo to create a sports-inspired fashion collection.By Alyson Krueger The Rays Plan to Keep Calm and Carry OnA red-hot start followed by a brutal July knocked Tampa Bay out of first place, but the Rays believe they are back on track.By Matt Martell The Knockout-Stage Showdown Between Sweden and the U.S. Is OnSweden and the U.S. teams have history. The Americans have the better of that, but Sweden has been stronger in this tournament.By Andrew Das Two spots are up for grabs in Group F with three teams tightly chasing them.By Claire Fahy Astros Pitcher Faces the Minimum in No-Hitter Against ClevelandFramber Valdez allowed one walk, and had that runner erased on a double-play in a dominant effort against the Guardians.By Evan Easterling AdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTFollow UsNYTSportstwitter page for NYTSportsAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTSite IndexSite Information Navigation© 2023 The New York Times CompanyNYTCoContact UsAccessibilityWork with usAdvertiseT Brand StudioYour Ad ChoicesPrivacy PolicyTerms of ServiceTerms of SaleSite MapCanadaInternationalHelpSubscriptions

title: Food - The New York Times
body: Skip to contentSkip to site indexSearch & Section NavigationSection NavigationSEARCHFood Today’s PaperAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTSupported bySKIP ADVERTISEMENTFoodWine, Beer & CocktailsRestaurant ReviewsHighlightsPhotoCreditAsh Ponders for The New York Times130 Degrees and Rising: How Kitchen Workers Are Dealing With Record HeatWith punishing temperatures across many states, restaurants are adapting to a new climate reality. By Christina MoralesPhotoCreditTwo Robbers Seltzer Co.Welcome to the Age of Hard JuiceOnce considered only a passable mixer, juice is finding its way into canned alcoholic drinks. By Joshua M. BernsteinPhotoCreditDavid Malosh for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Simon Andrews.11 Easy Vegetarian Summer DinnersBountiful meals for the most bountiful time of year. By Tanya SichynskyPhotoCreditJohnny Miller for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Rebecca Jurkevich.Good Eggplant Parmesan Takes Time. But It Doesn’t Have to Take Forever.This streamlined version of the Italian American classic skips the frying for a recipe you’ll make over and over again. By Eric KimPhotoCreditArmando Rafael for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Cyd Raftus McDowell.When It Comes to Micheladas, Start With Beer, Lime and SaltThe ice-cold cocktail is delicious in its simplest form — and it’s also endlessly customizable. By Rebekah PepplerA Good AppetitePhotoCreditDavid Malosh for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Simon Andrews.Peach Cobbler as You’ve Never Seen ItMelissa Clark flips the classic on its head, letting flaky biscuits serve as a base for juicy, caramelized peaches. By Melissa ClarkPhotoCreditClay Williams for The New York TimesRestaurant Review: Elegantly Dressed Peruvian Cuisine Makes Landfall in TriBeCaAt Artesano, the chef Rodrigo Fernandini is making artful versions of ceviches, tiraditos and other dishes. By Pete WellsPhotoCreditTony Cenicola/The New York TimesWhat Happened to Diamond Crystal Kosher Salt?With minimalist branding and a higher price point, the salt brand is now chasing after “the aspiring home chef.” By Marnie HanelPhotoCreditDavid Malosh for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Simon Andrews.A Soup and Salad That Beat the HeatCapped off with a raspberry-nectarine icebox cake, this menu from David Tanis is cool enough for the hottest of days. By David TanisPhotoCreditAlex Lau for The New York Times Summer Party Spread (Pork Chops with Plum Sauce, Baked Feta Dip with Spicy Tomatoes, Grilled Fish and Blueberry CrispA Summer Dinner Party That’s Actually Fast and EasyThe New York Times Food columnists share their favorite simple dishes for a gorgeous spread. By Genevieve KoPhotoCreditBrittainy Newman for The New York TimesMeet the Latest Dining Aesthetic: Darkroom-CoreRestaurants across the United States are opting for red lighting as a way to sell intimacy, danger and, sure, food. By Ella QuittnerThe PourPhotoCreditEmilio Parra Doiztua for The New York TimesWhere to Drink Wine in MadridThis warm, generous city overflows with great wine lists in restaurants and wine and tapas bars. Here are nine places you should try. By Eric AsimovFront BurnerPhotoCreditEmon Hassan for The New York TimesShop by Taste at This Brooklyn Wine StoreTaste56 opens in Dumbo, Brooklyn, with a rotating selection of wine, Kwame Onwuachi and more join Flavors of the Open, and more food news. By Florence FabricantWhat to CookPhotoCreditChris Simpson for The New York Times. Food stylist: Maggie Ruggiero. Prop stylist: Sophia Pappas.Recipes That Meet You Where You AreChilaquiles verdes for when you want to get lost in your kitchen, and kimchi carbonara for when you don’t. By Sam SiftonAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTLatestSearchSearchClear this text inputThe 213An L.A. Diner That’s Been Obsessing Over Its Burgers and Pies Since 1947The Apple Pan, a no-frills fixture on the city’s West Side, is a time machine that still runs like clockwork.By Rico Gagliano Four Levels of Vegetarian SandwichesFrom the simple (furikake tomato sandwich) to the cheffy (Superiority Burger’s crispy fried tofu sandwich).By Tanya Sichynsky Isabella Rossellini’s Mama Farm Introduces a Knitwear CollaborationPlus: obscure Surrealist literature, a virtual South African art gallery — and more recommendations from T Magazine. 36 Hours36 Hours in Ho Chi Minh City, VietnamVietnam’s biggest city is transforming with new highrises, bars and boutiques, but still offers old-world charm and chaotic fun.By Patrick Scott A Stylish (but Stress-Free) Summer Dinner PartyMix and match recipes from our NYT Cooking columnists: Yewande Komolafe’s coconut-dill salmon, Eric Kim’s grilled chops with plum BBQ sauce, Genevieve Ko’s deeply purple blueberry crisp.By Melissa Clark EatThe Best Chilaquiles You’ve Ever HadThe perfect breakfast of fried corn tortillas in salsa is always the one you just ate. This recipe is no exception.By Bryan Washington Where to Eat After Visiting the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and More Reader QuestionsAn Italian restaurant with a little elbow room? No problem.By Nikita Richardson off the menuYemen Café, a Brooklyn Standby, Expands to Staten IslandA former Gallaghers chef opens a sandwich shop, a wine series pops up at the Noortwyck, and more restaurant news.By Florence Fabricant Summer Done Simply: Sheet-Pan Chicken With Basil and Spicy CornMarinate your chicken thighs in pickled jalapeño brine, then toss the peppers with fresh summer corn and lime for a dinner that’s spicy, sweet, salty and sour.By Emily Weinstein A Fast, Fresh Pasta for Those Perfect Peak TomatoesGrating your tomatoes preserves their juicy acidity, which sings when swirled into hot garlic oil with handfuls of basil.By Melissa Clark AdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTCooking NewsletterGet regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice. body: Skip to contentSkip to site indexSearch & Section NavigationSection NavigationSEARCHArts Today’s PaperAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTSupported bySKIP ADVERTISEMENTArtsArt & DesignBooksDanceMoviesMusicTelevisionTheaterPop CultureWhat to WatchAwards SeasonHighlightsPhotoCredit“I am a rainbow in the sky!” the campers yelled last weekend at Camp Realize Your Beauty in Estes Park, Colo.Amid the Mountains, They Can Be ‘Open Without Being Judged’A four-day summer camp in Colorado promotes body positivity and empowerment through theater. By Lisa Kennedy and Shelby KnowlesPhotoCreditNetflix/Samuel DoreL.G.B.T.Q. Teens on ‘Heartstopper’: ‘I’m Fine With It Not Being Perfect’Three British 16-year-olds took an advance look at Season 2. There was popcorn, giggling and more than a little eye-rolling. By Simran HansPhotoCreditMichael Stravato for The New York TimesOpera Star David Daniels Pleads Guilty to Sexual AssaultThe countertenor and his husband, Scott Walters, pleaded guilty to sexually assaulting a young singer in Houston in 2010, in a deal that will spare them jail time. By Dianna Wray and Javier C. HernándezPhotoCreditSara Krulwich/The New York Times‘Back to the Future’ Review: The DeLorean Crash Lands on BroadwayThe addition of 17 songs turns the 1985 sci-fi classic into a big “why?” musical with a big wow factor. By Jesse GreenPhotoCreditSony PicturesHow the ‘Spider-Verse’ Movies Have Changed Animation for the BetterThe new Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles movie and other C.G.I. cartoons are taking a looser, imperfect approach. The style represents a shift made possible by Spidey’s success. By Esther ZuckermanPhotoCreditSara Krulwich/The New York TimesWhat to Know About the Opera Star David Daniels’s Sexual Assault TrialThe countertenor and his husband, Scott Walters, each face a charge of aggravated sexual assault in Texas. By Javier C. HernándezPhotoCreditSara Krulwich/The New York TimesEverybody Dance Now! ‘Here Lies Love’ Dictates Your Moves.Engaging viewers’ bodies is central to this Broadway musical, a rare production that sets its audience in motion on the dance floor. By Brian SeibertPhotoCreditKuzui Enterprises, via Kino LorberThanks to Carol Burnett and Dolly Parton, New Life for a 1988 Film“Tokyo Pop,” starring Carrie Hamilton, a daughter of the comedian, was a critical hit that had fallen into obscurity and has now been restored. By Ben KenigsbergPhotoCreditDreamWorks PicturesThe 50 Best Movies on Netflix Right NowMovies upon movies await, and you don’t even have to drill down to find them. By Jason BaileyPhotoCreditUncork’d EntertainmentFive Science Fiction Movies to Stream NowDinosaurs, androids, darkness and superheroes factor into this months sci-fi picks. By Elisabeth VincentelliPhotoCreditBalarama Heller for The New York TimesHow Phish’s Lighting Designer Jams With the BandChris Kuroda has brought more than 1,750 of the group’s shows to life since 1989, handling one of the most complex gigs in the business: responding in real time, without a set list. By Marc TracyPhotoCreditIke Edeani for The New York TimesSatchmo’s Wonderful World: Louis Armstrong Center Amplifies An Artist’s VisionNew jazz and exhibition spaces, and an inaugural show curated by Jason Moran, feature the trumpeter’s history, collaged onto the walls. By Melena RyzikPhotoCreditNetflixFive Children’s Movies to Stream NowThis month’s picks include a stereotype-defying shape-shifter, superpowered shelter pets and the newest “Guardians of the Galaxy” adventure. By Dina GachmanPhotoCreditClifton Prescod/NetflixWhat to Do in New York City in AugustLooking for something to do in New York? Catch the comedian Ali Wong at the Beacon, or enjoy a silent movie at MoMA. By The New York TimesAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTLatestSearchSearchClear this text inputA Poem About Dance and the Hard Work of TranscendenceThe lessons of Rita Dove’s “American Smooth,” one of the best-loved poems of the last two decades.By Dwight Garner Leny Andrade, ‘First Lady of Brazilian Jazz,’ Dies at 80With her soulful, cigarette-tinged contralto and emotive “bossa-jazz” stylings, she mesmerized audiences and critics alike.By Alex Williams Mark Margolis, Scene Stealer from ‘Breaking Bad,’ Dies at 83His character, an ex-drug lord in a wheelchair, was unable to speak, but the actor, who also appeared in the prequel “Better Call Saul,” didn’t need dialogue to wield fearsome power.By Alex Williams A (Sad) Playlist for the 2023 New York MetsFifteen songs that tell the tale of a rough season. Jess Search, a Force in the Documentary Genre, Dies at 54As one of the leaders of Doc Society, she supported countless filmmakers, with an emphasis on underrepresented groups and unconventional stories.By Neil Genzlinger The PlaylistMitski’s Beautifully Moody Meditation, and 11 More New SongsHear tracks by Jorja Smith, Towa Bird, Wilco and others.By Jon Pareles, Giovanni Russonello and Lindsay Zoladz ‘Winning Time’ Is Back. Here’s What to Know Ahead of Season 2Season 1 of HBO’s series about the 1980s Lakers came with drama, in more ways than one. Expect more for Season 2. An N.B.A. reporter takes a look.By Tania Ganguli Digital Replicas, a Fear of Striking Actors, Already Fill ScreensThe technology for morphing flesh-and-blood performers into virtual avatars has been improving for years. Now it has become an issue in the actors’ strike.By Marc Tracy The Big Number: $15 MillionGeorge Clooney and Meryl Streep have helped raise $15 million for striking actorsBy Marie Solis Ask a Showrunner‘The Lincoln Lawyer’ Is on the Road AgainThe popular Netflix legal thriller just released a batch of new episodes. title: Health - The New York Times
body: Skip to contentSkip to site indexSearch & Section NavigationSection NavigationSEARCHHealth Today’s PaperAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTSupported bySKIP ADVERTISEMENTHealthHealth PolicyGlobal HealthThe New Old AgeScienceWellCovid PandemicHighlightsPhotoCreditFrederic J. Brown/Agence France-Presse — Getty ImagesThree Shots for Fall: What You Need to KnowHere’s what we know about who should get the flu, Covid and R.S.V. vaccines, and when. By Apoorva MandavilliPhotoCreditRory Doyle for The Washington Post, via Getty ImagesMedical Group Backs Youth Gender Treatments, but Calls for Research ReviewThe American Academy of Pediatrics renewed its support of gender care for minors while commissioning a fresh look at the evidence. By Azeen GhorayshiPhotoCreditErika P. Rodriguez for The New York TimesAmid Signs of a Covid Uptick, Researchers Brace for the ‘New Normal’Infections remain very low, despite signs of a slight increase. Now, experts are looking for clues to what living with the coronavirus will be like this winter and beyond. By Apoorva MandavilliPhotoCreditSteve Gschmeissner/Science SourceLeprosy May Be Endemic in Central Florida, Scientists ReportStill, there are fewer than 200 cases nationally each year, and the numbers have fallen significantly from the peak decades ago. By Apoorva MandavilliPhotoCreditJordan Gale for The New York TimesScenes From a City That Only Hands Out Tickets for Using FentanylOregon’s experiment to curb overdoses by decriminalizing small amounts of illicit drugs is in its third year, and life has changed for most everyone in the city of Portland. By Jordan Gale and Jan HoffmanPhotoCreditAlisha Jucevic for The New York TimesIs It an E-Bike, or a Motorcycle for Children?With a throttle and no pedals, Super73’s new “electric balance bike” blurs the lines of regulation and safety. “No license, registration or insurance required,” its marketing promises. By Matt RichtelPhotoCreditAriana Drehsler for The New York Times‘A Dangerous Combination’: Teenagers’ Accidents Expose E-Bike RisksThe e-bike industry is booming, but many vehicles are not legal for teenagers, and accidents are on the rise. By Matt RichtelPhotoCreditJames Gathany, Centers for Disease Control and PreventionA Half-Million Americans May Have Tick-Linked Meat Allergy, C.D.C. SaysMany doctors said that they were unfamiliar with the condition, known as alpha-gal syndrome, the agency found. By Emily AnthesPhotoCreditRedmond O. Durrell/AlamyBlood of Young Mice Extends Life in the OldInfusions of youthful blood led older mice to live 6 to 9 percent longer, a new study found. By Carl ZimmerAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTFrom WellMore in From Well ›PhotoCreditYael Malka for The New York TimesThe Joy of May-December FriendshipThese BFFs have learned that a 40- or 50-year age gap is no deterrent to connection. By Catherine PearsonPhotoCreditIllustration by Nicolás Ortega; Photograph by Getty ImagesIt’s OK to Be a Summer GrinchYou might be hot, sweaty and tired. But there are things you can do to manage. By Jancee DunnPhotoCreditKarsten Moran for The New York TimesAlcohol-Related Deaths Are Rising Among WomenThe gap between male and female fatalities is narrowing, including for people 65 and older. Here’s how to know if you need to cut back on your drinking. By Dani BlumPhotoCreditCaitlin O'Hara for The New York TimesDive Into an Open-Water WorkoutSwimming in a lake or the ocean is an exhilarating alternative to your usual pool routine. Here’s how to get started. By Amanda LoudinPhotoCreditEric Helgas for The New York TimesIs Menopause Changing My Hair?Shifting hormones can make hair go haywire. Experts say there are ways to manage it. By Alisha Haridasani GuptaThe Covid-19 PandemicMore in The Covid-19 Pandemic ›PhotoCreditIllustration by Jules JulienThe Ongoing Mystery of Covid’s OriginWe still don’t know how the pandemic started. Here's what we do know — and why it matters. By David QuammenPhotoCreditAn Inside Look at Covid’s Lasting Damage to the LungsThis 3-D reconstruction of lung scans reveals damage that has lingered for years in patients who became severely ill early in the pandemic. By Jeremy White, Pam Belluck, Noah Bassetti-Blum, Eleanor Lutz and Hang Do Thi DucPhotoCreditPhoto illustration by Ina JangHer Symptoms Suggested Long Covid. But Was That Too Obvious?Doctors make assumptions about a case — and those assumptions can sometimes cloud their judgment. By Lisa Sanders, M.D.PhotoCreditMark Schiefelbein/Associated PressCovid Is Coming Back in China; Lockdowns Are NotThe authorities say that cases are up, and one doctor estimates that there could soon be 65 million cases a week. But China appears determined to move on. By Chris BuckleyPhotoCreditRuth Fremson/The New York TimesU.S. Ends Last Covid Travel Barrier, Vaccine Mandate for Foreign ArrivalsInternational travelers entering the country are no longer required to be vaccinated, removing the last of the restrictions on travel put in place beginning in 2020. By Ceylan YeginsuAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTLatestSearchSearchClear this text inputEnslaved African Americans in Maryland Linked to 42,000 Living RelativesThe analysis marks the first time historical DNA has been used to trace the descendants and distant cousins of enslaved people, researchers said.By Carl Zimmer This Ancient Whale May Have Been the Heaviest Animal EverPerucetus drifted through shallow seas like a gigantic manatee, scientists suspect.By Carl Zimmer ScreenlandWhat I Saw When I Looked Inside My Own BodyModern medicine is constantly showing us our guts and bones. Why doesn’t it feel more profound?By B.D. McClay Family of Henrietta Lacks Settles With Biotech Company That Used Her CellsMs. Lacks’s family had accused Thermo Fisher Scientific of profiting from her cells, which have contributed to revolutionary advances in medicine, without seeking their permission.By Amanda Holpuch OriginsA Theory of Childbirth’s Evolution May Not Be What You’re ExpectingScientists are revisiting an influential theory that the evolution of big brains made human childbirth risky.By Carl ZimmerLeer en español What Is an E-Bike, and How Safe Are They?Surprisingly tricky questions about an increasingly popular vehicle.By Matt Richtel AIDS Relief Program Under Threat as G.O.P. Insists on Abortion RestrictionA decades-old program created by President George W. Bush to combat AIDS around the world is at risk of being sucked into a partisan dispute over abortion, with some Republicans threatening to block its renewal.By Sheryl Gay Stolberg The EthicistMy Friend Is Trapped in a Nursing Home. What Can I Do?The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on helping people who are institutionalized against their will.By Kwame Anthony Appiah Louise Levy, Who Was Studied for Her Very Long Life, Is Dead at 112She was one of hundreds of people, all of them Ashkenazi Jews, whose good health and cognitive ability at extreme old age were the subject of genetic research.By Richard Sandomir 16 People Sickened in Salmonella Outbreak Linked to Ground BeefPeople who became ill reported eating lean ground beef that was sold at ShopRite locations in New Jersey, New York and Connecticut, the C.D.C. said.By Rebecca Carballo AdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTFollow Us@nythealthtwitter page for @nythealthNYTimesSciencefacebook page for NYTimesScienceWellNYTfacebook page for WellNYT@nytimeswelltwitter page for @nytimeswellAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTSite IndexSite Information Navigation© 2023 The New York Times CompanyNYTCoContact UsAccessibilityWork with usAdvertiseT Brand StudioYour Ad ChoicesPrivacy PolicyTerms of ServiceTerms of SaleSite MapCanadaInternationalHelpSubscriptions

时报普利策获奖作品











中国火箭军高层剧变
人事震荡或令习近平核武雄心短暂受挫
储百亮 
火箭军控制着中国几乎所有核武器，其两名高官被突然撤换引发猜测。习近平急于加强自己对这一敏感军种的支配地位，高层动荡或导致中国核武雄心暂时受挫。






两名美国海军水手被指控向中国泄密
 ADAM GOLDMAN, JILL COWAN 13:34 





两人在南加州被捕，被控向中国情报官员提供军事机密和敏感信息。美国近来持续指责中国大范围窃取美国企业和国家安全机密。


前副总统彭斯成特朗普案核心人物
 SHANE GOLDMACHER, MAGGIE ASTOR, LUKE BROADWATER 15:08 





彭斯曾是特朗普最忠实的副手，他将在明年的共和党初选中与之针锋相对，上演一场前副总统挑战其总统靠山的历史性对决。


国会暴乱事件中，彭斯的惊魂一日





特朗普因试图推翻总统大选结果被起诉
 ALAN FEUER,MAGGIE HABERMAN  





特朗普面临欺骗美国等四宗罪。这标志着美国历史上一个非同寻常的时刻：在新一轮大选展开之际，一位前总统被指控试图颠覆民主。


报告指太阳能行业仍与新疆有大量关联
 ANA SWANSON, IVAN PENN  





数百家公司承诺保证其供应链不存在强迫劳动，但新报告发现，几家最大制造商的业务仍与新疆高度关联，它们的总部均位于中国。


中国政府出台促进消费措施
 KEITH BRADSHER  





中国复苏乏力让政府急于提振经济。但随着青年失业率高企、消费者信心不足，人们对政府推出的刺激措施是否有效持怀疑态度。





 人工智能聊天机器人训练指南 

 杭州动物园否认“人扮熊”传言 

 北京遭暴雨和洪水袭击，至少11人亡 

 《隐入尘烟》：令人心痛的爱与坚韧 

 拜登政府搜寻中国恶意计算机代码 

 法官拒对《愿荣光归香港》颁布禁令 











Doug Mills/The New York Times


特朗普对试图推翻大选结果相关指控表示不认罪
GLENN THRUSH 11:50
这是特朗普四个月以来第三次因刑事指控出庭，他对四项指控均表示不认罪。听证会结束后，他发表讲话称自己是拜登政府的“迫害”对象，这“对美国来说是非常悲哀的一天”。


特朗普因试图推翻总统大选结果被起诉







新闻分析
特朗普2024：竞选总统，反击控罪
 LISA LERER, REID J. EPSTEIN 12:46 





特朗普一直以来都很清楚：法庭可以裁决他的案件，但只有选民才能决定是否让他重新掌权。他已明确表示，如果重新入主白宫，将行使权力终止针对他的诉讼。






讣告
日本作家森村诚一去世，作品曾揭露731部队暴行
 RICHARD SANDOMIR 14:36 





森村是推理小说作家和和平主义者，代表作之一《恶魔的饱食》详细描述了日军在占领中国后进行的秘密生物战项目。他表示自己写这本书的目的是为了平衡日本对战争的描述。

书评
《等着在夜里被逮捕》：当日常生活变成一场噩梦
 BARBARA DEMICK 15:44 





维吾尔诗人伊兹格尔的新回忆录《等着在夜里被逮捕》是人权书籍中的异类。书中没有酷刑的场景，没有暴力，但它如同一部心理惊悚片，在克制的叙述背后，恐怖如期而至。


镇压、恐惧与创伤：一位维吾尔诗人笔下的新疆
 TIFFANY MAY  





知名诗人和导演伊兹格尔出版回忆录《等着在夜里被逮捕》，描述了中国政府在新疆对维吾尔人实施的镇压和大规模拘禁，以及这些政策给当地人带来的恐惧和创伤。


原子弹争议难消，“芭本海默”在日本引发愤怒
 BEN DOOLEY, HISAKO UENO  





《芭比》的美国宣传账号在社交媒体上推广“芭本海默”米姆，转发了一张使用核爆背景的影迷自制海报，引发日本用户的强烈不满。《奥本海默》尚未确定在日本的上映日期。










      观点与评论 • OPINION



 为何女性会选择战略性“示弱”
 ADAM GRANT 





试探性语言似乎是女性避免性别刻板成见带来的不公正后果的一种策略。我们应该将“弱势语言”正常化，成为一种表达关心和谦逊的有力方式。

 台湾女性不再退让：“我们不要就这么算了”
 VICKIE WANG 





台湾仍是一个父权制和等级制社会，女性要屈从于当权者。“算了吧”是个体面的做法。但这次不行。我们厌倦了听之任之，厌倦了退缩。





 我家乡新疆的悲剧可能发生在任何地方

 朝韩“统一”梦想的褪色和幻灭

Yes, but Only With Some Help.For some young people, a path to homeownership often involves a mix of diligent saving combined with assistance from family or government loans and programs. By Jessica FuStrategiesPhotoCreditMinet KimThe Risks Hidden in Public Pension FundsAttracted by promises of high returns, many public pension funds have been loading up on private equity but may not fully appreciate the dangers, our columnist says. By Jeff SommerDealBook NewsletterPhotoCreditJ. Their authors claim to be renowned travel writers, but are they A.I. inventions? And how big is the problem?By Seth Kugel and Stephen Hiltner They Make Some of New York’s Best Food. They Want the Right to Sell It.New York City officials cracked down on Corona Plaza, a celebrated Queens hub for Latin American street vendors. Its merchants are fighting to legitimize their businesses.By Stefanos Chen and Raúl Vilchis For the First Time, There’s a Pill for Postpartum DepressionBecause the pill works faster than other antidepressants and is taken for only two weeks, it may encourage more treatment of the debilitating condition.By Pam Belluck 3 Factors Keeping Americans From New Weight-Loss DrugsA survey showed that many Americans were interested in obesity treatments like Wegovy but lost interest when confronted with the price and other factors.By Gina Kolata Billionaire Parts With Group Behind Israel’s Judicial OverhaulArthur Dantchik announced that he would no longer donate money to the Kohelet Policy Forum, the brains behind the highly polarizing plan.By David Segal William H. Reporters asked about pardons. Mike Pence was heckled. Republicans found it’s not easy to escape the fallout from Donald J. Trump’s legal peril. By Lisa Lerer and Nicholas NehamasPhotoCreditMaddie McGarvey for The New York TimesJan. 6 Prosecutors Ask for Protective Order, Citing Threatening Trump PostIn seeking a judge’s order, the government was drawing attention to the former president’s longstanding habit of attacking those involved in criminal cases against him. By Alan Feuer and Maggie HabermanAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTLatestSearchSearchClear this text inputJan. 6 Prosecutors Ask for Protective Order, Citing Threatening Trump PostIn seeking a judge’s order, the government was drawing attention to the former president’s longstanding habit of attacking those involved in criminal cases against him.By Alan Feuer and Maggie Haberman On the Campaign Trail, an Impossible Task: Ignoring Trump’s Latest ChargesVoters pressed them to weigh in. Reporters asked about pardons. Mike Pence was heckled. Republicans found it’s not easy to escape the fallout from Donald J. Trump’s legal peril.By Lisa Lerer and Nicholas Nehamas Trump’s Legal Team Is Enmeshed in a Tangle of Possible ConflictsFormer President Donald J. Trump’s growing cast of lawyers is marked by a web of overlapping interests encompassing witnesses, co-defendants and potential targets.By Alan Feuer, Ben Protess and Maggie Haberman Key Witness Doesn’t Back Up G.O.P.’s Biggest Allegations on BidensThe testimony of Devon Archer, a Hunter Biden associate, paints an unflattering portrait of Hunter’s business dealings, but contradicts reports of bribes or material involvement by the president.By Luke Broadwater News AnalysisHow Jack Smith Structured the Trump Election Indictment to Reduce RisksThe special counsel layered varied charges atop the same facts, while sidestepping a free-speech question by not charging incitement.By Charlie Savage Oklahoma Man Pleads Guilty to Threatening DeSantis, Cruz and Other RepublicansTyler Jay Marshall, 37, threatened on social media to shoot a number of Republican politicians. He faces up to five years in prison.By Orlando Mayorquin news analysisA Rising Tide Lifts Many Boats, but So Far Not Biden’sThe president is experiencing a flurry of good news on the economy, crime, immigration and other areas, but voters so far have not given the president much credit.By Peter Baker Trump Indictment Presents New Obstacle in Spending Fight as Shutdown LoomsThe far right is pushing to cut funding for the F.B.I. and the Justice Department, another complication for Speaker Kevin McCarthy as he seeks to avoid a government shutdown.By Carl Hulse TimesVideoPolice Identify ‘Fire Island Jane Doe’The authorities identified human remains found near Gilgo Beach in 2011, and on Fire Island years before, as those of Karen Vergata, who was 34 when she went missing in 1996.By The Associated Press DeSantis Dismisses Trump’s 2020 Election Theories as FalseThe Florida governor went further than he has before in acknowledging that the election was not stolen as a major donor pressured him to appeal to moderates.By Nicholas Nehamas and Lisa Lerer AdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTFollow Usnytpoliticstwitter page for nytpoliticsnytpoliticsfacebook page for nytpoliticsSite IndexSite Information Navigation© 2023 The New York Times CompanyNYTCoContact UsAccessibilityWork with usAdvertiseT Brand StudioYour Ad ChoicesPrivacy PolicyTerms of ServiceTerms of SaleSite MapCanadaInternationalHelpSubscriptions

title: New York - The New York Times
body: Skip to contentSkip to site indexSearch & Section NavigationSection NavigationSEARCHNew York Today’s PaperAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTSupported bySKIP ADVERTISEMENTNew YorkEric AdamsKathy HochulBig CityMetropolitan DiarySunday RoutineHighlightsPhotoCreditJanice Chung for The New York TimesThey Make Some of New York’s Best Food. They Want the Right to Sell It.New York City officials cracked down on Corona Plaza, a celebrated Queens hub for Latin American street vendors. Its merchants are fighting to legitimize their businesses. By Stefanos Chen and Raúl VilchisPhotoCreditTop left, zz/NDZ/STAR MAX/IPx via Associated Press; top right, José A. Alvarado Jr. for The NYT; bottom right, Eduardo Munoz/Reuters; bottom left, Jeenah Moon for The NYTFor Mayor Adams, Any Day Has the Makings of Flag DayFrom Belgium to the Bahamas, Mayor Eric Adams has raised the flags of at least 31 countries since taking office, a civic gesture with political benefits. By Dana RubinsteinPhotoCreditBess Adler for The New York TimesSunday RoutineHow the Artistic Director at SummerStage Spends Her SundaysRain or shine, Erika Elliott drives from borough to borough to check in on the performances happening in city parks as part of the annual music festival. By Alix StraussPhotoCreditDave Sanders for The New York TimesNew Commissioner Forces at Least Four Top Cops to Retire From N.Y.P.D.The resignations include Chief James Essig, the head of detectives, and Chief Kim Royster, who headed transportation. By Maria Cramer and William K. RashbaumPhotoCreditJeenah Moon for The New York TimesYouTube Streamer Faces Riot Charge After Union Square Park Erupts in ChaosThousands of people descended on the Manhattan park after Kai Cenat, a popular YouTube and Twitch streamer, promised to hand out free game consoles. By Ed Shanahan and Wesley ParnellBig CITYPhotoCreditAssociated PressCrime Is Down. So Why Don’t New Yorkers Feel Safe?Crime isn’t what it was in the 1980s. But a new podcast about the Bernhard Goetz subway shootings suggests that even then, the fear of crime outpaced reality. By Ginia BellafantePhotoCreditProsecutors Identify Human Remains Found in 2011 Near Gilgo BeachThe skull belonged to Karen Vergata, who had disappeared in 1996. Other parts of her body had been found on Fire Island years before. By Maria Cramer and Nate SchweberPhotoCreditDave Sanders for The New York TimesLeft-Leaning Democrats Meet in Secret to Find a Challenger to Eric AdamsA group of progressives held an early strategy meeting on Staten Island to discuss how they might defeat Mr. Adams in 2025. It won’t be easy. By Emma G. Fitzsimmons, Nicholas Fandos and Jeffery C. MaysPhotoCreditDavid Dee Delgado for The New York TimesDancer Stabbed to Death Was a Shy Boy Turned Proud, Exuberant ManO’Shae Sibley was determined to succeed in New York, where he had joined a community of artists and performers who pushed him to strive. By Maria Cramer and Wesley ParnellAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTLatestSearchSearchClear this text inputJan. 6 Prosecutors Ask for Protective Order, Citing Threatening Trump PostIn seeking a judge’s order, the government was drawing attention to the former president’s longstanding habit of attacking those involved in criminal cases against him.By Alan Feuer and Maggie Haberman New York TodaySome of the Things You’ll Be Paying More ForGas and electric bills are going up, and so are bridge and tunnel tolls, not to mention subway fares.By James Barron Take the Quiz! Pick the Worst New York City Summer Plagues.Roaches. Aphids. Rats. How many scourges can one city have? Lately, old annoyances have been joined by new terrors. In this quiz, you get to choose your own nightmare!By Dodai Stewart District Attorney’s Investigations Burrow Into Adams’s Circle of SupportMayor Eric Adams has not been implicated in any wrongdoing, but District Attorney Alvin L. Bragg has targeted people who are in the mayor’s circle.By Jonah E. Bromwich and William K. Rashbaum Giuliani Maligns Jews and Women in Transcript Filed in Harassment CaseRudolph Giuliani, the former mayor and presidential lawyer, faces a variety of legal troubles and has been identified as a co-conspirator in Donald Trump’s indictment.By Jonah E. Bromwich Professor Charged in Scheme to Lure Women to New York and Rape ThemOver the course of a decade, Jorge Alberto Ramos paid for at least three women to travel from El Salvador to his home in the Bronx, where he sexually abused them, according to prosecutors.By Lola FaduluLeer en español Former Head of Police Sergeants Union Sentenced to 2 Years for FraudEdward D. Mullins, who had drawn attention for vulgar insults of city leaders, stole hundreds of thousands of dollars from union members.By Chelsia Rose Marcius Myron Goldfinger, 90, Architect of Monumental Modernist Homes, DiesHis houses, which dot the Hamptons and other parts of the New York region, include a residence featured in “The Wolf of Wall Street.”By Clay Risen Satchmo’s Wonderful World: Louis Armstrong Center Amplifies An Artist’s VisionNew jazz and exhibition spaces, and an inaugural show curated by Jason Moran, feature the trumpeter’s history, collaged onto the walls.By Melena Ryzik New York City Will Make Outdoor Dining Permanent, With CaveatsNew rules passed by the City Council on Thursday will organize the haphazard but popular outdoor dining structures, but will force their removal in the winter.By Emma G. It’s also a luxury motor coach that was funded by someone else’s money.13 min readUkraine Starts New Diplomatic Push to Weaken RussiaSome 40 countries that have remained on the sidelines of the war were invited to talks in Saudi Arabia, as Ukraine redoubles efforts to isolate Moscow.5 min readRussia said Ukraine struck an oil tanker off the coast of Crimea, the second sea drone assault on one of its ships in two days.2 min readUkrainians criticized Pope Francis for not chiding Russia at a pilgrimage in Portugal.5 min readAlexander Demyanchuk/Sputnik, via ReutersMan of the People? Jolted by Mutiny, Putin Works the Crowds.President Vladimir Putin is out and about among the Russian people, trying to show that his pandemic-era isolation is over and his public support is strong.5 min readA Global Web of Chinese Propaganda Leads to a U.S. Tech MogulThe Times unraveled a financial network that stretches from Chicago to Shanghai and uses American nonprofits to push Chinese talking points worldwide.12 min readNeville Roy Singham, right, in 2016 with the activist Jodie Evans. In 2017, they married and he sold his tech firm. Jim Spellman/WireImage, via Getty ImagesThe Great ReadHow a Sexual Assault in a School Bathroom Became a Political WeaponIt was an explosive claim — that a Virginia school district covered up crime in a girls’ bathroom in order to protect transgender rights. But was it true?36 min readModel and photograph by Nix + GerberTaylor Swift Conquered the World With Her Eras TourThe pop star’s record-breaking show has dominated the summer, whipping up demand at a level thought unachievable in a fragmented age.6 min readJutharat Pinyodoonyachet for The New York TimesAn Israeli City Where Compromise and Division Swim Side by SideAt a time when Israeli Jews can seem irreconcilably divided, an unusual swimming center illustrates the compromises that many make daily.6 min readAmit Elkayam for The New York TimesBig Tech Rebounds and Preps for Transformative A.I. InvestmentsAs the tech giants found their financial footing last quarter, they doubled down on A.I., which has been a boon to companies like Nvidia.4 min readChristie Hemm Klok for The New York Times

title: The New York Times en Español - The New York Times
body: Skip to contentSkip to site indexSearch & Section NavigationSection NavigationSEARCHU.S.InternationalCanadaEspañol中文 Today’s PaperSíguenos: FacebookTwitterNew York Times HomepageSection NavigationWorldU.S.PoliticsN.Y.BusinessOpinionScienceHealthSportsArtsBooksStyleFoodTravelMagazineReal EstateCookingThe AthleticWirecutterGamesNewsWorldBusinessArtsLifestyleOpinionCookingGamesWirecutterThe AthleticHighlightsPhotoCreditUna medida desesperada para salvar los corales: sacarlos del océanoEn Florida, equipos dedicados a la restauración de los océanos están trasladando urgentemente muestras a tanques en tierra, mientras una ola de calor marina devasta arrecifes enteros. Por Catrin Einhorn y Jason GulleyPhotoCreditHector Vivas/Getty ImagesMessi ha revolucionado el Inter Miami pero ¿podrá lograr que mejore en la MLS?Messi ha tenido mucho más espacio para maniobrar que en Europa y la calidad de los defensas a los que se enfrenta es de un nivel menor al que estaba acostumbrado. Por Victor MatherPhotoCreditAlfonso Duran para The New York Times¿Acaso el inglés de Miami es un dialecto?Un profesor de lingüística descubrió que incluso los miamenses que no dominan el español usan o entienden frases que son traducciones directas de ese idioma. Por Patricia MazzeiPhotoCreditBrian ReaModern LoveDeseo más que un ‘Gracias, ¡que pase el siguiente!’Hacer audiciones para conseguir un papel en una serie o película tiene mucho en común con buscar una amistad o una pareja, sobre todo cuando te rechazan. Por Jenny GorelickPhotoCreditAgence France-Presse — Getty Images‘No se trata de otro golpe como los de siempre’: lo que hay que saber de la crisis en NígerEn medio de un golpe militar impredecible, los países vecinos han amenazado con entrar en guerra, algunos para frustrar la toma del poder y otros para garantizar su éxito. By Declan WalshPhotoCreditErika P. Rodriguez para The New York TimesHay indicios de un repunte de covid y los científicos anticipan una ‘nueva normalidad’Las infecciones siguen siendo muy bajas, a pesar de los signos de un ligero aumento. En Estados Unidos, los expertos están buscando pistas sobre cómo será vivir con el coronavirus este invierno y en adelante. By Apoorva MandavilliPhotoCreditAlana Paterson for The New York Times; Nasuna Stuart-Ulin for The New York TimesLos cambiaron al nacer: dos canadienses descubren sus raícesDurante 65 años, cada hombre tuvo la vida del otro. Por un lado, una infancia difícil complicada por las brutales políticas canadienses hacia los indígenas; por el otro, una educación despreocupada, impregnada de la cultura católica ucraniana. By Norimitsu OnishiPhotoCreditJefferson Siegel para The New York TimesUn profesor es acusado de atraer mujeres a Nueva York y violarlasA lo largo de una década, Jorge Alberto Ramos le envió dinero al menos a tres mujeres para que viajaran desde El Salvador hasta el Bronx, donde abusó sexualmente de ellas, según la fiscalía. By Lola FaduluOrígenesPhotoCreditNicole RifkinSurgen cuestionamientos a una teoría sobre la evolución del parto humanoLos científicos están revisando una influyente teoría que argumentaba que la evolución de los cerebros grandes en bebés y pelvis estrechas en mujeres lo volvía arriesgado. By Carl ZimmerAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTOpiniónMás en Opinión ›PhotoCreditFelipe Dana/Associated PressHaeryun KangCorea del Norte y Corea del Sur se distancian cada día másSetenta años después del armisticio de la Guerra de Corea, el Norte y el Sur están más lejos de la unificación que nunca. By Haeryun KangPhotoCreditIlustración por Akshita Chandra/The New York Times; imágenes por Barbara Alper, Shelly Still/Getty ImagesJessica BennettVi ‘Barbie’ con una de las feministas más importantes del mundo. Y tiene una teoríaSusan Faludi, autora del clásico ‘Backlash’, tiene algunas ideas sobre la película de Greta Gerwig. By Jessica BennettPhotoCreditNatalie Keyssar para The New York TimesBret StephensLo que aprendí en UcraniaViajé al país y comprendí que los ucranianos hacen su vida cotidiana como si no hubiera guerra mientras hacen la guerra como si no hubiera vida cotidiana. By Bret StephensPhotoCreditAssociated PressKai BirdLa verdadera tragedia de OppenheimerLa historia del “padre de la bomba atómica”, como muestra la película de Christopher Nolan, es relevante para nuestros predicamentos políticos actuales. By Kai BirdPhotoCreditErnesto Ryan/Getty ImagesGuillermo GaratMontevideo se quedó sin agua dulce. ¿Pasará lo mismo en tu ciudad?Todas las ciudades del mundo tienen que empezar a planificar escenarios de sequías y en priorizar su agua potable. By Guillermo GaratEspecialMás en Especial ›PhotoCreditUniversal Pictures ("Oppenheimer"); Warner Bros. ("Barbie")‘Barbieheimer’: los entusiastas del cine están listos para una doble funciónAlgunos de los amantes del cine que planean ver el mismo día los estrenos de “Barbie” y “Oppenheimer” disfrutan de la incongruencia entre los dos estrenos. By Christopher KuoPhotoCreditAssociated PressLa verdadera tragedia de OppenheimerLa historia del “padre de la bomba atómica”, como muestra la película de Christopher Nolan, es relevante para nuestros predicamentos políticos actuales. By Kai BirdPhotoCreditRobert Alexander/Getty ImagesLo que ‘Oppenheimer’ no cuenta sobre la prueba de la bomba nuclearLa película aborda solo una parte de la historia del Proyecto Manhattan y no explora las consecuencias de la decisión de detonar el arma en un lugar donde mi familia y muchas otras habían vivido por generaciones. By Tina CordovaPhotoCreditEddie Adams/Associated PressQuién es quién en ‘Oppenheimer’: una guía de las personas y los hechos realesEl complejo drama de Christopher Nolan describe el desarrollo de la bomba nuclear y las maquinaciones políticas de mediados del siglo pasado. Este es el trasfondo. By Christopher KuoAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTWell: Notas de bienestarMás en Well: Notas de bienestar ›PhotoCreditEric Helgas for The New York Times¿El estrés puede provocar la caída del cabello?Si tu cabello se está volviendo más delgado durante momentos particularmente tensos, los expertos tienen algunas ideas sobre lo que podría estar pasando. By Melinda Wenner MoyerPhotoCreditJohn P. DessereauEste es el número que debería guíar tus decisiones de salud (y no es tu edad)La esperanza de vida figura cada vez más en los cálculos sobre si las pruebas de detección y los tratamientos son apropiados. Aquí te mostramos cómo averiguar la tuya. By Paula SpanPhotoCreditCarmen CasadoSi buscas una crema antiarrugas, el protector solar es tu mejor opciónLos rayos del sol causan la mayoría de los cambios en la piel que envejece. Te decimos cómo prevenirlos. By Dana G. SmithPhotoCreditJam Dong¿Es verdad que el azúcar alimenta a las células cancerosas?Muchos pacientes dicen que evitan los dulces para ayudar a combatir la enfermedad. Pero si bien una dieta saludable es importante, no se puede “matar de hambre a un tumor”. By Connie ChangPhotoCreditLars Klove para The New York TimesLo que deben saber los hombres antes de teñirse el cabelloPara muchos hombres, pintarse las canas puede ser la oportunidad de lucir una nueva apariencia o de señalar que están disponibles otra vez. A continuación, algunos consejos para hacerlo con dignidad. By Frank RojasEstados UnidosMás en Estados Unidos ›PhotoCreditAmit Elkayam for The New York Times¿Quién pagó por una misteriosa herramienta de espionaje? El FBI, según una investigación del FBITras un reportaje del Times, la agencia canceló su contrato con un contratista del gobierno. Pero sigue habiendo interrogantes. By Mark Mazzetti, Ronen Bergman y Adam GoldmanPhotoCreditMaddie McGarvey para The New York TimesLa acusación contra Trump desafía la democracia de EE. UU.La tercera acusación contra el expresidente aborda uno de los grandes temas de su presidencia: ¿Un mandatario puede difundir mentiras para mantenerse en el poder incluso si los votantes decidieron en las urnas lo contrario? By Peter BakerPhotoCreditKirsten Luce for The New York TimesLa explotación laboral de niños migrantes aumentó en el último año en EE. UU.Alrededor de 300.000 menores han llegado al país sin compañía desde 2021, lo que ha impulsado un aumento marcado en el trabajo infantil entre migrantes. By Hannah DreierPhotoCreditHaiyun Jiang para The New York Times; Desiree Rios para The New York Times¿A qué edad deberían retirarse los políticos?Dos momentos preocupantes que involucraron a los senadores Dianne Feinstein y Mitch McConnell provocaron preguntas sobre el envejecimiento de los líderes electos. By Lisa Lerer y Reid J. EpsteinPhotoCreditJames Devaney/GC Images vía Getty ImagesLa muy privada vida de Melania TrumpMientras su marido busca regresar a la Casa Blanca y se enfrenta a un riesgo legal cada vez mayor, la ex primera dama ha decidido mantenerse fuera del ojo público. By Lisa Lerer y Katie RogersAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTLo más recienteBuscarBuscarClear this text inputUn expresidente y tres acusacionesCuatro cargos contra Donald Trump, narcotanques en México y más para el fin de semana.Por Elda Cantú El peso mexicano está fuerte. ¿Qué significa para tu economía?Para los mexicanos que trabajan en EE. UU. y otros países, un peso fuerte ha significado que el dinero que mandan a casa ya no rinde tanto como antes. Queremos saber tu experiencia.Por J. Edward Moreno Ensayo invitadoEl poder del ‘lenguaje débil’ de las mujeresEn lugar de castigar a las mujeres por desafiar los estereotipos, deberíamos cuestionar esos estereotipos.Por Adam GrantRead in English Elon Musk quiere convertir a X en una ‘aplicación para todo’Al menos desde el año pasado, el magnate de la tecnología ha expresado su ambición de crear una aplicación integral, al estilo de las que se usan en Asia.Por Ryan MacRead in English Alemania enfrenta un desafío para lograr su independencia energética: bombas de conflictos pasadosLa complicada labor de encontrar y limpiar municiones antiguas y sin explotar se ha convertido en una rutina en la costa norte alemana.Por Catie EdmondsonRead in English Lizzo es demandada por acoso y ambiente laboral hostilTres bailarinas aseguran que ir de gira con la ganadora del Grammy significó trabajar en una “atmósfera abiertamente sexual” y sus acusaciones parecen disputar la reputación de la cantante como defensora de la positividad corporal.Por Lauren McCarthyRead in English The MorningMéxico, un enemigo para algunos republicanosMiembros del Partido Republicano han planteado planes de intervención militar contra los cárteles mexicanos, lo que sería un acto de guerra contra uno de los aliados más cercanos de EE. UU.Por German LopezRead in English Trump es acusado por su papel en el asalto al Capitolio y la interferencia en las elecciones de 2020El expresidente, que está en campaña para regresar a la Casa Blanca, ha sido imputado por sus intentos de usar los mecanismos del Estado para permanecer en el poder.Por Alan Feuer y Maggie HabermanRead in English Ucrania y LatinoaméricaLa región ante la guerra, las consecuencias del “superpeso” mexicano y más.Por Elda Cantú Tech Fix¿ChatGPT te ha dado respuestas erróneas? Tal vez lo estás usando malSi guiamos a los chatbots de inteligencia artificial a fuentes confiables, reducimos el riesgo de que nos entreguen respuestas con datos erróneos.Por Brian X. ChenRead in English AdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTSite IndexSite Information Navigation© 2023 The New York Times CompanyNYTCoContact UsAccessibilityWork with usAdvertiseT Brand StudioYour Ad ChoicesPrivacy PolicyTerms of ServiceTerms of SaleSite MapCanadaInternationalHelpSubscriptions
