title: World News - The New York Times
body: Skip to contentSkip to site indexSearch & Section NavigationSection NavigationSEARCHWorld News Today’s PaperAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTSupported bySKIP ADVERTISEMENTWorld NewsAfricaAmericasAsiaAustraliaCanadaEuropeMiddle EastHighlightsPhotoCreditPatricia De Melo Moreira/Agence France-Presse — Getty ImagesUkrainians Dismayed as Pope Declines to Condemn Russia at World Youth Day“It’s not enough just to listen — he has to do something,” said Dmytro Bohak, one of about 500 young Ukrainian pilgrims who attended the event and staged a demonstration. By Jason HorowitzPhotoCreditJim Spellman/WireImage, via Getty ImagesA Global Web of Chinese Propaganda Leads to a U.S. Tech MogulThe Times unraveled a financial network that stretches from Chicago to Shanghai and uses American nonprofits to push Chinese talking points worldwide. By Mara Hvistendahl, David A. Fahrenthold, Lynsey Chutel and Ishaan JhaveriPhotoCreditAlexander Demyanchuk/Sputnik, via ReutersMan of the People? Jolted by a Mutiny, Putin Works the Crowds.His contained interactions with crowds this summer are a noticeable change for the Russian leader, who disdains retail politics and operated in extreme seclusion during the pandemic. By Paul SonnePhotoCreditK.M. Chaudary/Associated PressImran Khan Sentenced to Prison, Likely Dashing Hopes of Political ComebackThe former prime minister of Pakistan was taken into custody, sentenced to three years after a court found him guilty of illegally selling state gifts and concealing the assets. By Salman Masood and Christina GoldbaumPhotoCreditAgence France-Presse — Getty ImagesA Shrinking Footprint in Africa for France, the Former Colonizer That StayedA recent military takeover in Niger has thrown into uncertainty the future of France’s presence in West and Central Africa, raising doubts about the future of U.S. military involvement there, too. By Elian PeltierRehovot dispatchPhotoCreditAmit Elkayam for The New York TimesAn Israeli City Where Compromise and Division Swim Side by SideAt a time when Israeli Jews can seem irreconcilably divided, an unusual swimming center in the city of Rehovot illustrates the compromises that many Israelis make daily. By Patrick Kingsley and Gabby SobelmanPhotoCreditSaudi Press Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty ImagesUkraine Starts New Diplomatic Push to Weaken RussiaSome 40 countries that have largely remained on the sidelines of the war were invited to talks on Saturday in Saudi Arabia, as Ukraine redoubles international efforts to isolate Moscow. By Marc Santora, Vivian Nereim and David PiersonPhotoCreditKim-Yeol/Newsis, via Associated PressThousands of Scouts Are Leaving Heat-Plagued Jamboree EarlyThe British, Singaporean and U.S. scouting organizations cited health concerns for their departure from a much-anticipated youth event in South Korea. By John YoonPhotoCreditPlanet Labs PBC, via Associated PressBattle at Sea Intensifies as Ukraine Drone Hits 2nd Russian Ship in 2 DaysIn addition to the strike on an oil tanker, Ukraine issued a warning that commercial ships using any of six Russian Black Sea ports would be considered military targets. By Marc Santora and Christiaan TriebertPhotoCreditEvelyn Hockstein/ReutersNiger’s Coup Leaders Sever Ties With France, as Detained President Pleads for HelpThe military junta that ousted the president in the West African nation of Niger last week also dismissed Niger’s ambassadors to key partners: the United States, France and Nigeria. By Elian PeltierPhotoCreditFinbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times‘It’s Crazy’: The Scramble for Ancient Treasures After Ukraine’s Dam DisasterAfter the Kakhovka dam was blown up in June, the reservoir above it quickly drained, revealing a bonanza of artifacts that has electrified Ukrainian archaeologists. By Jeffrey Gettleman and Finbarr O’ReillyThe Saturday ProfilePhotoCreditSaumya Khandelwal for The New York TimesWhere ‘No One Wanted Girls,’ a Dad in India Takes On the PatriarchyA delivery room epiphany transformed a village headman into an unlikely and highly successful campaigner against prenatal sex testing, which often led to aborting female fetuses. By Sameer YasirPhotoCreditAndreea Alexandru/Associated PressAndrew Tate Is Released From House Arrest in RomaniaThe online influencer and his brother, Tristan Tate, must remain in the country while they await trial on charges of human trafficking, a court in Bucharest ruled. By Jenny Gross and Matei BarbulescuPhotoCreditLouiza Vradi/ReutersAcropolis Will Limit Visitor Numbers as Europe Tackles a Tourist CrushGreece is trying to curb overcrowding and prevent damage at its most popular archaeological site. Other European destinations are also cracking down. By Niki Kitsantonis and Isabella KwaiAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTDispatchesMore in Dispatches ›PhotoCreditGianni Cipriano for The New York Times‘We Are a Romantic Country’: On the Set of a Steamy Hit in ItalyItaly falls for “Mare Fuori,” a television melodrama about the inmates of a juvenile detention center who pass the time making out — when not scowling at or occasionally stabbing one another. By Jason HorowitzPhotoCreditChristina Simons for The New York TimesA Yiddish Haven Thrives in AustraliaAustralia has the largest proportion of Holocaust survivors of any country besides Israel. In Melbourne, some of their descendants are leading the way to preserve the Yiddish language. By Natasha FrostPhotoCreditSamuel Aranda for The New York TimesOn the Front Line of a War Over Bullfighting TraditionsOpponents of Spain’s comic shows at bullfights by people with dwarfism say they are banned by a new law. But performers say the show must go on. By Jason HorowitzPhotoCreditAndrew Testa for The New York TimesAt This Brewery, Blessings Are as Important as Barley and HopsAt Mount Saint Bernard Abbey, the monks help make Britain’s only Trappist beer, a full-bodied brew that has won fans since its launch five years ago. By Stephen CastlePhotoCreditLaura Boushnak for The New York TimesIn Tuna-Obsessed Tunisia, a Favorite Food Becomes a Lot Less AffordableTunisians put canned tuna on pizza, pastries and pretty much everything else. Don’t even ask for a tuna-free sandwich. But inflation risks turning an everyday essential into a luxury out of reach. By Vivian YeeRead The Times in SpanishMore in Read The Times in Spanish ›PhotoCreditAgence France-Presse — Getty Images‘No se trata de otro golpe como los de siempre’: lo que hay que saber de la crisis en NígerEn medio de un golpe militar impredecible, los países vecinos han amenazado con entrar en guerra, algunos para frustrar la toma del poder y otros para garantizar su éxito. By Declan WalshPhotoCreditAlana Paterson for The New York Times; Nasuna Stuart-Ulin for The New York TimesLos cambiaron al nacer: dos canadienses descubren sus raícesDurante 65 años, cada hombre tuvo la vida del otro. Por un lado, una infancia difícil complicada por las brutales políticas canadienses hacia los indígenas; por el otro, una educación despreocupada, impregnada de la cultura católica ucraniana. By Norimitsu OnishiPhotoCreditGetty ImagesEl peso mexicano está fuerte. ¿Qué significa para tu economía?Para los mexicanos que trabajan en EE. UU. y otros países, un peso fuerte ha significado que el dinero que mandan a casa ya no rinde tanto como antes. Queremos saber tu experiencia. By J. Edward MorenoPhotoCreditMichael Sohn/Agence France-Presse — Getty ImagesAlemania enfrenta un desafío para lograr su independencia energética: bombas de conflictos pasadosLa complicada labor de encontrar y limpiar municiones antiguas y sin explotar se ha convertido en una rutina en la costa norte alemana. By Catie EdmondsonPhotoCreditDaniel Berehulak para The New York TimesLos ‘narcotanques’ revelan el nivel de violencia de los cárteles en MéxicoLos grupos del crimen organizado están modificando camionetas con torretas armadas, refuerzos de acero y arietes, llevando el concepto de los camiones monstruo a nuevos niveles de letalidad. By Simon Romero and Emiliano Rodríguez MegaAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTThe Saturday ProfileMore in The Saturday Profile ›PhotoCreditNoriko Hayashi for The New York TimesIn Rare Move, Japanese Pop Star Comes Out Publicly as Gay“I don’t want people to struggle like me,” said Shinjiro Atae, making an announcement that is extremely unusual in conservative Japan. By Motoko Rich and Hikari HidaPhotoCreditA Burnout in Korea, She’s a Superstar in Latin AmericaFleeing the strictures of modern life in a hypercompetitive South Korea, a young woman found a calmer way of life in Mexico — and millions of social media followers. By Elda Cantú and Marian CarrasqueroPhotoCreditDmitry Kostyukov for The New York TimesA French Music Maker Lost His Voice. A Comedian Helped Get It Back.The rap producer known as Pone, who has A.L.S., speaks through a computer that makes him sound robotic. He asked a comic impersonator to try to recapture his distinctive sound. By Aurelien Breeden and Dmitry KostyukovPhotoCreditAlexia Webster for The New York TimesMillions Danced Joyfully to Her Song. She Drew on Her Pain to Write It.Nomcebo Zikode, the South African singer of the pandemic hit “Jerusalema” that inspired a global dance challenge, wrote the chorus while battling her own depression. By Lynsey ChutelPhotoCreditUlet Ifansasti for The New York TimesAncient Art or Fashion Forward? Both, Says a Top Batik DesignerJosephine Komara has redefined a cultural expression that was intricate and lovely but so locked in tradition it bordered on staid. “Tradition is the way we are,” she says. “Modern is the way we think.” By Hannah BeechLatestSearchSearchClear this text inputTheir Rooftop Photos Are Stunning. Their Subculture Has Its Critics.“Rooftoppers” get a thrill from taking photos atop skyscrapers and sharing them on social media. Detractors call them reckless.By Mike Ives, Juliette Guéron-Gabrielle and Tiffany May Canada Moves Forward With New Tech TaxAn international overhaul to tax tech companies is at a standstill, so Canada is forging ahead with another plan.By Vjosa Isai Police Arrest 7 Over Murder Threats at Seoul Subway StationsPosts online in the wake of recent stabbing assaults specified sites for copycat attacks. They prompted swift police action in a nation rattled by the random violence.By John Yoon Ukraine Hits a Distant Russian Ship, Showing Reach of Naval DronesThe attack damaged the warship hundreds of miles from Ukrainian-held territory, as Kyiv increasingly tries to bring the war home to Russia.By Marc Santora and Christiaan Triebert TimesVideoChris Christie Visits War Sites in UkraineThe Republican former New Jersey governor who is running for president made a surprise trip to meet with President Volodymyr Zelensky.By The Associated Press Young Catholics Come Together, if Not Their ViewsAs young Catholics gathered from around the world in Portugal, their desires for the future of the church were as varied as the countries they came from.By Jason Horowitz TimesVideoUkrainian Maritime Drone Hits Russian WarshipVideo released by the Ukrainian military shows a Ukrainian drone attack on a Russian naval ship in the port of Novorossiysk.By Storyful India’s Top Court Clears Way for Rahul Gandhi’s Return to ParliamentIndia’s main opposition leader was kicked out of the legislature after a defamation case that his allies called politically motivated. He can also now run in next year’s elections.By Alex Travelli What to Know About Novorossiysk, the Russian Port Attacked by UkraineThe seaport is one of Russia’s largest by volume and among the biggest in Europe, crucial to the export of Russian grain, oil, and other products to countries around the world.By Paul Sonne Anger Builds in Towns Deliberately Flooded, in Part, to Save BeijingA provincial leader set off an outcry by urging cities to serve as a “moat” for the capital, as diverted floodwaters sent scores of residents fleeing.By Keith Bradsher AdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTSite IndexSite Information Navigation© 2023 The New York Times CompanyNYTCoContact UsAccessibilityWork with usAdvertiseT Brand StudioYour Ad ChoicesPrivacy PolicyTerms of ServiceTerms of SaleSite MapCanadaInternationalHelpSubscriptions

title: The New York Times en Español - The New York Times
body: Skip to contentSkip to site indexSearch & Section NavigationSection NavigationSEARCHU.S.InternationalCanadaEspañol中文 Today’s PaperSíguenos: FacebookTwitterNew York Times HomepageSection NavigationWorldU.S.PoliticsN.Y.BusinessOpinionScienceHealthSportsArtsBooksStyleFoodTravelMagazineReal EstateCookingThe AthleticWirecutterGamesNewsWorldBusinessArtsLifestyleOpinionCookingGamesWirecutterThe AthleticHighlightsPhotoCreditUna medida desesperada para salvar los corales: sacarlos del océanoEn Florida, equipos dedicados a la restauración de los océanos están trasladando urgentemente muestras a tanques en tierra, mientras una ola de calor marina devasta arrecifes enteros. Por Catrin Einhorn y Jason GulleyPhotoCreditHector Vivas/Getty ImagesMessi ha revolucionado el Inter Miami pero ¿podrá lograr que mejore en la MLS?Messi ha tenido mucho más espacio para maniobrar que en Europa y la calidad de los defensas a los que se enfrenta es de un nivel menor al que estaba acostumbrado. Por Victor MatherPhotoCreditAlfonso Duran para The New York Times¿Acaso el inglés de Miami es un dialecto?Un profesor de lingüística descubrió que incluso los miamenses que no dominan el español usan o entienden frases que son traducciones directas de ese idioma. Por Patricia MazzeiPhotoCreditBrian ReaModern LoveDeseo más que un ‘Gracias, ¡que pase el siguiente!’Hacer audiciones para conseguir un papel en una serie o película tiene mucho en común con buscar una amistad o una pareja, sobre todo cuando te rechazan. Por Jenny GorelickPhotoCreditAgence France-Presse — Getty Images‘No se trata de otro golpe como los de siempre’: lo que hay que saber de la crisis en NígerEn medio de un golpe militar impredecible, los países vecinos han amenazado con entrar en guerra, algunos para frustrar la toma del poder y otros para garantizar su éxito. By Declan WalshPhotoCreditErika P. Rodriguez para The New York TimesHay indicios de un repunte de covid y los científicos anticipan una ‘nueva normalidad’Las infecciones siguen siendo muy bajas, a pesar de los signos de un ligero aumento. En Estados Unidos, los expertos están buscando pistas sobre cómo será vivir con el coronavirus este invierno y en adelante. By Apoorva MandavilliPhotoCreditAlana Paterson for The New York Times; Nasuna Stuart-Ulin for The New York TimesLos cambiaron al nacer: dos canadienses descubren sus raícesDurante 65 años, cada hombre tuvo la vida del otro. Por un lado, una infancia difícil complicada por las brutales políticas canadienses hacia los indígenas; por el otro, una educación despreocupada, impregnada de la cultura católica ucraniana. By Norimitsu OnishiPhotoCreditJefferson Siegel para The New York TimesUn profesor es acusado de atraer mujeres a Nueva York y violarlasA lo largo de una década, Jorge Alberto Ramos le envió dinero al menos a tres mujeres para que viajaran desde El Salvador hasta el Bronx, donde abusó sexualmente de ellas, según la fiscalía. By Lola FaduluOrígenesPhotoCreditNicole RifkinSurgen cuestionamientos a una teoría sobre la evolución del parto humanoLos científicos están revisando una influyente teoría que argumentaba que la evolución de los cerebros grandes en bebés y pelvis estrechas en mujeres lo volvía arriesgado. By Carl ZimmerAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTOpiniónMás en Opinión ›PhotoCreditFelipe Dana/Associated PressHaeryun KangCorea del Norte y Corea del Sur se distancian cada día másSetenta años después del armisticio de la Guerra de Corea, el Norte y el Sur están más lejos de la unificación que nunca. By Haeryun KangPhotoCreditIlustración por Akshita Chandra/The New York Times; imágenes por Barbara Alper, Shelly Still/Getty ImagesJessica BennettVi ‘Barbie’ con una de las feministas más importantes del mundo. Y tiene una teoríaSusan Faludi, autora del clásico ‘Backlash’, tiene algunas ideas sobre la película de Greta Gerwig. By Jessica BennettPhotoCreditNatalie Keyssar para The New York TimesBret StephensLo que aprendí en UcraniaViajé al país y comprendí que los ucranianos hacen su vida cotidiana como si no hubiera guerra mientras hacen la guerra como si no hubiera vida cotidiana. By Bret StephensPhotoCreditAssociated PressKai BirdLa verdadera tragedia de OppenheimerLa historia del “padre de la bomba atómica”, como muestra la película de Christopher Nolan, es relevante para nuestros predicamentos políticos actuales. By Kai BirdPhotoCreditErnesto Ryan/Getty ImagesGuillermo GaratMontevideo se quedó sin agua dulce. ¿Pasará lo mismo en tu ciudad?Todas las ciudades del mundo tienen que empezar a planificar escenarios de sequías y en priorizar su agua potable. By Guillermo GaratEspecialMás en Especial ›PhotoCreditUniversal Pictures ("Oppenheimer"); Warner Bros. ("Barbie")‘Barbieheimer’: los entusiastas del cine están listos para una doble funciónAlgunos de los amantes del cine que planean ver el mismo día los estrenos de “Barbie” y “Oppenheimer” disfrutan de la incongruencia entre los dos estrenos. By Christopher KuoPhotoCreditAssociated PressLa verdadera tragedia de OppenheimerLa historia del “padre de la bomba atómica”, como muestra la película de Christopher Nolan, es relevante para nuestros predicamentos políticos actuales. By Kai BirdPhotoCreditRobert Alexander/Getty ImagesLo que ‘Oppenheimer’ no cuenta sobre la prueba de la bomba nuclearLa película aborda solo una parte de la historia del Proyecto Manhattan y no explora las consecuencias de la decisión de detonar el arma en un lugar donde mi familia y muchas otras habían vivido por generaciones. By Tina CordovaPhotoCreditEddie Adams/Associated PressQuién es quién en ‘Oppenheimer’: una guía de las personas y los hechos realesEl complejo drama de Christopher Nolan describe el desarrollo de la bomba nuclear y las maquinaciones políticas de mediados del siglo pasado. Este es el trasfondo. By Christopher KuoAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTWell: Notas de bienestarMás en Well: Notas de bienestar ›PhotoCreditEric Helgas for The New York Times¿El estrés puede provocar la caída del cabello?Si tu cabello se está volviendo más delgado durante momentos particularmente tensos, los expertos tienen algunas ideas sobre lo que podría estar pasando. By Melinda Wenner MoyerPhotoCreditJohn P. DessereauEste es el número que debería guíar tus decisiones de salud (y no es tu edad)La esperanza de vida figura cada vez más en los cálculos sobre si las pruebas de detección y los tratamientos son apropiados. Aquí te mostramos cómo averiguar la tuya. By Paula SpanPhotoCreditCarmen CasadoSi buscas una crema antiarrugas, el protector solar es tu mejor opciónLos rayos del sol causan la mayoría de los cambios en la piel que envejece. Te decimos cómo prevenirlos. By Dana G. SmithPhotoCreditJam Dong¿Es verdad que el azúcar alimenta a las células cancerosas?Muchos pacientes dicen que evitan los dulces para ayudar a combatir la enfermedad. Pero si bien una dieta saludable es importante, no se puede “matar de hambre a un tumor”. By Connie ChangPhotoCreditLars Klove para The New York TimesLo que deben saber los hombres antes de teñirse el cabelloPara muchos hombres, pintarse las canas puede ser la oportunidad de lucir una nueva apariencia o de señalar que están disponibles otra vez. A continuación, algunos consejos para hacerlo con dignidad. By Frank RojasEstados UnidosMás en Estados Unidos ›PhotoCreditAmit Elkayam for The New York Times¿Quién pagó por una misteriosa herramienta de espionaje? El FBI, según una investigación del FBITras un reportaje del Times, la agencia canceló su contrato con un contratista del gobierno. Pero sigue habiendo interrogantes. By Mark Mazzetti, Ronen Bergman y Adam GoldmanPhotoCreditMaddie McGarvey para The New York TimesLa acusación contra Trump desafía la democracia de EE. UU.La tercera acusación contra el expresidente aborda uno de los grandes temas de su presidencia: ¿Un mandatario puede difundir mentiras para mantenerse en el poder incluso si los votantes decidieron en las urnas lo contrario? By Peter BakerPhotoCreditKirsten Luce for The New York TimesLa explotación laboral de niños migrantes aumentó en el último año en EE. UU.Alrededor de 300.000 menores han llegado al país sin compañía desde 2021, lo que ha impulsado un aumento marcado en el trabajo infantil entre migrantes. By Hannah DreierPhotoCreditHaiyun Jiang para The New York Times; Desiree Rios para The New York Times¿A qué edad deberían retirarse los políticos?Dos momentos preocupantes que involucraron a los senadores Dianne Feinstein y Mitch McConnell provocaron preguntas sobre el envejecimiento de los líderes electos. By Lisa Lerer y Reid J. EpsteinPhotoCreditJames Devaney/GC Images vía Getty ImagesLa muy privada vida de Melania TrumpMientras su marido busca regresar a la Casa Blanca y se enfrenta a un riesgo legal cada vez mayor, la ex primera dama ha decidido mantenerse fuera del ojo público. By Lisa Lerer y Katie RogersAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTLo más recienteBuscarBuscarClear this text inputUn expresidente y tres acusacionesCuatro cargos contra Donald Trump, narcotanques en México y más para el fin de semana.Por Elda Cantú El peso mexicano está fuerte. ¿Qué significa para tu economía?Para los mexicanos que trabajan en EE. UU. y otros países, un peso fuerte ha significado que el dinero que mandan a casa ya no rinde tanto como antes. Queremos saber tu experiencia.Por J. Edward Moreno Ensayo invitadoEl poder del ‘lenguaje débil’ de las mujeresEn lugar de castigar a las mujeres por desafiar los estereotipos, deberíamos cuestionar esos estereotipos.Por Adam GrantRead in English Elon Musk quiere convertir a X en una ‘aplicación para todo’Al menos desde el año pasado, el magnate de la tecnología ha expresado su ambición de crear una aplicación integral, al estilo de las que se usan en Asia.Por Ryan MacRead in English Alemania enfrenta un desafío para lograr su independencia energética: bombas de conflictos pasadosLa complicada labor de encontrar y limpiar municiones antiguas y sin explotar se ha convertido en una rutina en la costa norte alemana.Por Catie EdmondsonRead in English Lizzo es demandada por acoso y ambiente laboral hostilTres bailarinas aseguran que ir de gira con la ganadora del Grammy significó trabajar en una “atmósfera abiertamente sexual” y sus acusaciones parecen disputar la reputación de la cantante como defensora de la positividad corporal.Por Lauren McCarthyRead in English The MorningMéxico, un enemigo para algunos republicanosMiembros del Partido Republicano han planteado planes de intervención militar contra los cárteles mexicanos, lo que sería un acto de guerra contra uno de los aliados más cercanos de EE. UU.Por German LopezRead in English Trump es acusado por su papel en el asalto al Capitolio y la interferencia en las elecciones de 2020El expresidente, que está en campaña para regresar a la Casa Blanca, ha sido imputado por sus intentos de usar los mecanismos del Estado para permanecer en el poder.Por Alan Feuer y Maggie HabermanRead in English Ucrania y LatinoaméricaLa región ante la guerra, las consecuencias del “superpeso” mexicano y más.Por Elda Cantú Tech Fix¿ChatGPT te ha dado respuestas erróneas? Tal vez lo estás usando malSi guiamos a los chatbots de inteligencia artificial a fuentes confiables, reducimos el riesgo de que nos entreguen respuestas con datos erróneos.Por Brian X. ChenRead in English AdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTSite IndexSite Information Navigation© 2023 The New York Times CompanyNYTCoContact UsAccessibilityWork with usAdvertiseT Brand StudioYour Ad ChoicesPrivacy PolicyTerms of ServiceTerms of SaleSite MapCanadaInternationalHelpSubscriptions

title: Science - The New York Times
body: Skip to contentSkip to site indexSearch & Section NavigationSection NavigationSEARCHScience Today’s PaperAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTSupported bySKIP ADVERTISEMENTScienceClimateSpace & AstronomyHealthTrilobitesMatterOut ThereCovid PandemicHighlightsPhotoCreditATLAS/University of Hawaii Institute for Astronomy/NASAKiller Asteroid-Spotting Software Could Help Save the WorldHelioLinc3D, which was developed for the Vera Rubin Observatory in Chile, showed its potential after finding an overlooked space rock that will make a close path of Earth. By Robin George AndrewsPhotoCreditDeep Space Network/NASANASA Reaches Voyager 2 With a Last-Ditch ‘Shout’ Across the VoidAfter an erroneous command sent the spacecraft’s antenna askew, mission specialists hatched a plan to point it back toward Earth. By Katrina MillerPhotoCreditChristopher MahTrilobitesNew Antarctic Starfish Are Doting Parents and Vicious PredatorsA close examination of a collection of starfish in the Smithsonian revealed even more starfish inside those starfish. By Darren IncorvaiaPhotoCreditCatoctin Furnace Historical SocietyEnslaved African Americans in Maryland Linked to 42,000 Living RelativesThe analysis marks the first time historical DNA has been used to trace the descendants and distant cousins of enslaved people, researchers said. By Carl ZimmerPhotoCreditHyun-Tak KimLK-99 Is the Superconductor of the SummerSocial media users are excited about what would be a breakthrough in solid state physics, but many experts in the field are cautiously skeptical. By Kenneth ChangTrilobitesPhotoCreditEve ThomasonElectrocution Isn’t the Main Thing Killing Birds Along Power LinesA survey of power lines in four Western states found bullet fragments and shotgun pellets in most of the dead birds that were collected. By Carolyn WilkePhotoCreditAlberto GennariThis Ancient Whale May Have Been the Heaviest Animal EverPerucetus drifted through shallow seas like a gigantic manatee, scientists suspect. By Carl ZimmerTrilobitesPhotoCreditChristian McCall505-Million-Year-Old Jellyfish Fossils May Be the Oldest Ever FoundThe specimens are evidence of how little the squishy, tentacled predators have changed over the history of life on Earth. By Jack TamisieaPhotoCreditSteve Ruark/Associated PressFamily of Henrietta Lacks Settles With Biotech Company That Used Her CellsMs. Lacks’s family had accused Thermo Fisher Scientific of profiting from her cells, which have contributed to revolutionary advances in medicine, without seeking their permission. By Amanda HolpuchAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTTrilobitesMore in Trilobites ›PhotoCreditPeter NickolausA Pancaked Turtle Fossil’s 150-Million-Year-Old TaleA beautifully preserved shelled reptile recovered from a Bavarian limestone deposit helps tell the story of how turtles first took to the seas. By Asher ElbeinPhotoCreditAleksey Suvorov/AlamyWhen Ancient Eruptions Pumped Diamonds to Earth’s SurfaceA new study offers clues to the mysteries of kimberlite eruptions, the source of most of the diamonds mined on Earth today. By Maya Wei-HaasPhotoCreditJustine Hudson/Fisheries and Oceans CanadaThe Prize for the Longest Pregnancy in Mammals May Go to This WhaleBowhead whales may carry their babies for as long as 23 months, although more research is needed to confirm the finding. By Miriam FauziaPhotoCreditMichael SkrepnickThis Fossil Is a Freeze-Frame of a Mammal Fighting a DinosaurIt’s like a man-bites-dog story from prehistoric times, although researchers had to take steps to verify that it was not a forgery. By Kate GolembiewskiPhotoCreditDepartment of Special Collections, Hesburgh Libraries of Notre DameWhat Benjamin Franklin Learned While Fighting CounterfeitersLong before there were Benjamins in circulation, the founding father was all about experimenting with printing techniques as he worked on securing colonial printed currency. By Veronique GreenwoodOriginsMore in Origins ›PhotoCreditBizarre Sea Creatures Illuminate the Dawn of the Animal KingdomA new study bolsters the idea that the first animals were surprisingly complex, perhaps equipped with muscles and a nervous system. By Carl ZimmerPhotoCreditNico Garstman/Naturalis Biodiversity CenterScience Museums Take Stock of 1.1 Billion Objects From Around the WorldNatural history museums have joined forces to produce a global digital inventory of their prized collections, from pinned butterflies to dinosaur skulls. By Carl ZimmerPhotoCreditJürgen Vogel, LVR-LandesMuseum BonnAncient DNA Reveals History of Hunter-Gatherers in EuropeLooking at DNA gleaned from ancient remains, researchers identified at least eight previously unknown populations of early Europeans. By Carl ZimmerPhotoCreditBeth ZaikenOldest Known DNA Offers Glimpse of a Once-Lush ArcticIn Greenland’s permafrost, scientists discovered two-million-year-old genetic material from scores of plant and animal species, including mastodons, geese, lemmings and ants. By Carl ZimmerPhotoCreditSteve Gschmeissner/Science SourceÓmicron cumple un año. Así ha evolucionadoAl cumplirse el aniversario del descubrimiento de la variante, los expertos en virología siguen intentando ponerse al día con la rápida transformación de ómicron. By Carl ZimmerAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTClimate and EnvironmentMore in Climate and Environment ›PhotoCreditNatacha Pisarenko/Associated PressHeat Wave Grips Portions of South America in the Middle of WinterAn unusual winter heat wave has brought record high temperatures to cities across Argentina, Chile and Paraguay this week, triggering concerns about the impacts of climate change. By Jesus Jiménez and Natalie AlcobaPhotoCreditThe New York TimesAntarctic Sea Ice Is at a ‘Very Concerning’ Record LowIt’s winter in Antarctica, when sea ice cover typically grows. But this year’s sea ice is way behind, reaching record lows with implications for the planet. By Delger Erdenesanaa and Leanne AbrahamPhotoCreditA Desperate Push to Save Florida’s Coral: Get It Out of the SeaTeams dedicated to ocean restoration are urgently moving samples to tanks on land as a marine heat wave devastates entire reefs. By Catrin Einhorn and Jason GulleyPhotoCreditMaddie McGarvey for The New York TimesIt’s Official: Stores Can No Longer Sell Most Incandescent LightsNew efficiency rules, more than a decade in the making, have taken effect, relegating Edison’s glowing orbs to the history books. By Hiroko TabuchiPhotoCreditSeiji MatsumotoThis Guide Can Help You Save Money and Fight Climate ChangeWhether you are renovating your home, upgrading appliances or buying an electric car, this guide can help you take advantage of savings from the Inflation Reduction Act. By Nadja Popovich and Elena ShaoLatestSearchSearchClear this text inputthe new old ageStill Dreaming of Retirement in the Sun Belt?As climate change sends summer temperatures soaring, older people are increasingly vulnerable to heat-related illnesses in places like Phoenix.By Paula Span For the First Time, There’s a Pill for Postpartum DepressionBecause the pill works faster than other antidepressants and is taken for only two weeks, it may encourage more treatment of the debilitating condition.By Pam Belluck 3 Factors Keeping Americans From New Weight-Loss DrugsA survey showed that many Americans were interested in obesity treatments like Wegovy but lost interest when confronted with the price and other factors.By Gina Kolata ‘It’s Crazy’: The Scramble for Ancient Treasures After Ukraine’s Dam DisasterAfter the Kakhovka dam was blown up in June, the reservoir above it quickly drained, revealing a bonanza of artifacts that has electrified Ukrainian archaeologists.By Jeffrey Gettleman and Finbarr O’Reilly Medical Group Backs Youth Gender Treatments, but Calls for Research ReviewThe American Academy of Pediatrics renewed its support of gender care for minors while commissioning a fresh look at the evidence.By Azeen Ghorayshi Leprosy May Be Endemic in Central Florida, Scientists ReportStill, there are fewer than 200 cases nationally each year, and the numbers have fallen significantly from the peak decades ago.By Apoorva Mandavilli Amid Signs of a Covid Uptick, Researchers Brace for the ‘New Normal’Infections remain very low, despite signs of a slight increase. Now, experts are looking for clues to what living with the coronavirus will be like this winter and beyond.By Apoorva MandavilliLeer en español Alan Roland, 93, Psychoanalyst Who Cautioned Against Western Bias, DiesIn “In Search of Self” and other books, he emphasized the role of cultural influences in a patient’s life.By Neil Genzlinger NASA’s Voyager 2 Is Out of Contact but Not Lost in SpaceThe aging spacecraft’s antenna was misdirected by a glitch, although officials say the distant probe appears to be functioning as intended.By Katrina Miller Saving Lives at the Grand Canyon, One Salty Snack at a TimeIn a summer of deadly heat for hikers in the Southwest, rangers at Grand Canyon National Park use a pioneering approach of aggressive messaging and outreach to prevent disaster on the trails.By Rowan Moore Gerety AdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTSign Up for the Science Times NewsletterEvery week, we'll bring you stories that capture the wonders of the human body, nature and the cosmos.SIGN UPAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTFollow UsNYTimesSciencefacebook page for NYTimesScience@NYTSciencetwitter page for @NYTScienceSite IndexSite Information Navigation© 2023 The New York Times CompanyNYTCoContact UsAccessibilityWork with usAdvertiseT Brand StudioYour Ad ChoicesPrivacy PolicyTerms of ServiceTerms of SaleSite MapCanadaInternationalHelpSubscriptions

title: The New York Times Magazine - The New York Times
body:
Skip to contentSkip to site indexSearch & Section NavigationSection NavigationSEARCH Today’s PaperHighlightsPhotoCreditModel and photograph by Nix + GerberHow a Sexual Assault in a School Bathroom Became a Political WeaponIt was an explosive claim — that a Virginia school district covered up a crime in order to protect transgender rights. But was it true? By Charles HomansPhotoCreditTommy Kha for The New York TimesThe Art of Telling Forbidden Stories in ChinaMany writers are looking for ways to capture the everyday realities that the government keeps hidden — sometimes at their own peril. By Han ZhangPhotoCreditAndrea Frazzetta for The New York TimesCan a Rapper Change Italy’s Mind About Migrants?As the country’s right-wing government takes a hard line on Mediterranean immigration, the hip-hop artist Ghali has become a prominent voice of compassion. By Alia MalekPhotoCreditIllustration by R. O. BlechmanPoemPoem: Powerless Self-JudgementWill Alexander’s visionary work achieves its effect through sound, not image. By Will Alexander and Anne BoyerJudge John HodgmanPhotoCreditIllustration by Louise Zergaeng PomeroyJudge John Hodgman on Getting a ColonoscopyWhat should you do with a husband who “doesn’t like doctors”? By John HodgmanThe EthicistPhotoCreditIllustration by Tomi UmA Thief Returned My Stolen Bike. Do I Owe Him a Reward?The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether every promise has to be kept. By Kwame Anthony AppiahEatPhotoCreditChris Simpson for The New York Times. Food stylist: Maggie Ruggiero. Prop stylist: Sophia Pappas.The Best Chilaquiles You’ve Ever HadThe perfect breakfast of fried corn tortillas in salsa is always the one you just ate. This recipe is no exception. By Bryan WashingtonScreenlandPhotoCreditPhoto illustration by Mark HarrisWhat I Saw When I Looked Inside My Own BodyModern medicine is constantly showing us our guts and bones. Why doesn’t it feel more profound? By B.D. McClayPhotoCreditIllustration by Jules JulienThe Ongoing Mystery of Covid’s OriginWe still don’t know how the pandemic started. Here's what we do know — and why it matters. By David QuammenAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTLatestSearchSearchClear this text inputLetter of RecommendationI’ve Listened to This Breakup Song a Million TimesWhy does it feel so good to cry this hard?By Brontez Purnell TalkAlok Vaid-Menon Is ‘Fighting for Trans Ordinariness’The activist and social media star just wants to worry about basic things, not their safety.By David Marchese The EthicistMy Friend Is Trapped in a Nursing Home. What Can I Do?The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on helping people who are institutionalized against their will.By Kwame Anthony Appiah The Kidnapped Child Who Became a PoetAt age 3, Shane McCrae was taken from his Black father by his white grandparents — a rupture he explores in a new memoir.By Wyatt Mason Poem: My Life in the New MillenniumJoshua Clover begins with hating people and loving cats, quickly adding juxtapositions and surprises.By Joshua Clover and Anne Boyer Judge John Hodgman on Wordle HintsWhat should be allowed to keep your solving streak alive?By John Hodgman The EthicistMy Friend Is Mistreating Her Nanny. Should I Say Something?The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on the social costs of speaking up about an unjust situation.By Kwame Anthony Appiah EatThis Hummus Holds Up After 800 YearsFirst written down in the 13th century, this recipe has an enduring simplicity — but no garlic.By Ligaya Mishan The Fight for the Right to TrespassA group of English activists want to legally enshrine the “right to roam” — and spread the idea that nature is a common good.By Brooke Jarvis ScreenlandWhat ‘The Bear’ Gets Right About ChicagoThe show celebrates a kind of ambition — humane and independent — that’s often neglected by Hollywood. Maybe that’s why the setting is so important.By Nicholas Cannariato AdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENT










The 8.6.23 Issue

In this issue, Charles Homans on how a sexual assault in a high school bathroom became a political weapon; Alia Malek on the Italian rapper Ghali; Han Zhang on Chinese literature in the age of Xi Jinping; and more.

Read this issue


Read our previous issue


See all past issues

title: Health - The New York Times
body: Skip to contentSkip to site indexSearch & Section NavigationSection NavigationSEARCHHealth Today’s PaperAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTSupported bySKIP ADVERTISEMENTHealthHealth PolicyGlobal HealthThe New Old AgeScienceWellCovid PandemicHighlightsPhotoCreditAsh Ponders for The New York Timesthe new old ageStill Dreaming of Retirement in the Sun Belt?As climate change sends summer temperatures soaring, older people are increasingly vulnerable to heat-related illnesses in places like Phoenix. By Paula SpanPhotoCreditKate Medley for The New York TimesFor the First Time, There’s a Pill for Postpartum DepressionBecause the pill works faster than other antidepressants and is taken for only two weeks, it may encourage more treatment of the debilitating condition. By Pam BelluckPhotoCreditCydni Elledge for The New York Times3 Factors Keeping Americans From New Weight-Loss DrugsA survey showed that many Americans were interested in obesity treatments like Wegovy but lost interest when confronted with the price and other factors. By Gina KolataPhotoCreditFrederic J. Brown/Agence France-Presse — Getty ImagesThree Shots for Fall: What You Need to KnowHere’s what we know about who should get the flu, Covid and R.S.V. vaccines, and when. By Apoorva MandavilliPhotoCreditRory Doyle for The Washington Post, via Getty ImagesMedical Group Backs Youth Gender Treatments, but Calls for Research ReviewThe American Academy of Pediatrics renewed its support of gender care for minors while commissioning a fresh look at the evidence. By Azeen GhorayshiPhotoCreditErika P. Rodriguez for The New York TimesAmid Signs of a Covid Uptick, Researchers Brace for the ‘New Normal’Infections remain very low, despite signs of a slight increase. Now, experts are looking for clues to what living with the coronavirus will be like this winter and beyond. By Apoorva MandavilliPhotoCreditSteve Gschmeissner/Science SourceLeprosy May Be Endemic in Central Florida, Scientists ReportStill, there are fewer than 200 cases nationally each year, and the numbers have fallen significantly from the peak decades ago. By Apoorva MandavilliPhotoCreditJordan Gale for The New York TimesScenes From a City That Only Hands Out Tickets for Using FentanylOregon’s experiment to curb overdoses by decriminalizing small amounts of illicit drugs is in its third year, and life has changed for most everyone in the city of Portland. By Jordan Gale and Jan HoffmanPhotoCreditAlisha Jucevic for The New York TimesIs It an E-Bike, or a Motorcycle for Children?With a throttle and no pedals, Super73’s new “electric balance bike” blurs the lines of regulation and safety. “No license, registration or insurance required,” its marketing promises. By Matt RichtelAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTFrom WellMore in From Well ›PhotoCreditYael Malka for The New York TimesThe Joy of May-December FriendshipThese BFFs have learned that a 40- or 50-year age gap is no deterrent to connection. By Catherine PearsonPhotoCreditIllustration by Nicolás Ortega; Photograph by Getty ImagesIt’s OK to Be a Summer GrinchYou might be hot, sweaty and tired. But there are things you can do to manage. By Jancee DunnPhotoCreditKarsten Moran for The New York TimesAlcohol-Related Deaths Are Rising Among WomenThe gap between male and female fatalities is narrowing, including for people 65 and older. Here’s how to know if you need to cut back on your drinking. By Dani BlumPhotoCreditCaitlin O'Hara for The New York TimesDive Into an Open-Water WorkoutSwimming in a lake or the ocean is an exhilarating alternative to your usual pool routine. Here’s how to get started. By Amanda LoudinPhotoCreditEric Helgas for The New York TimesIs Menopause Changing My Hair?Shifting hormones can make hair go haywire. Experts say there are ways to manage it. By Alisha Haridasani GuptaThe Covid-19 PandemicMore in The Covid-19 Pandemic ›PhotoCreditFrederic J. Brown/Agence France-Presse — Getty ImagesThree Shots for Fall: What You Need to KnowHere’s what we know about who should get the flu, Covid and R.S.V. vaccines, and when. By Apoorva MandavilliPhotoCreditDesiree Rios for The New York TimesNew York Covid Cases Are Rising Slightly, Officials WarnA small uptick in Covid cases has led to more hospitalizations, but the numbers, about 800 statewide, are still far below previous waves. By Joseph GoldsteinPhotoCreditErika P. Rodriguez for The New York TimesAmid Signs of a Covid Uptick, Researchers Brace for the ‘New Normal’Infections remain very low, despite signs of a slight increase. Now, experts are looking for clues to what living with the coronavirus will be like this winter and beyond. By Apoorva MandavilliPhotoCreditIllustration by Jules JulienThe Ongoing Mystery of Covid’s OriginWe still don’t know how the pandemic started. Here's what we do know — and why it matters. By David QuammenPhotoCreditAn Inside Look at Covid’s Lasting Damage to the LungsThis 3-D reconstruction of lung scans reveals damage that has lingered for years in patients who became severely ill early in the pandemic. By Jeremy White, Pam Belluck, Noah Bassetti-Blum, Eleanor Lutz and Hang Do Thi DucAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTLatestSearchSearchClear this text inputEnslaved African Americans in Maryland Linked to 42,000 Living RelativesThe analysis marks the first time historical DNA has been used to trace the descendants and distant cousins of enslaved people, researchers said.By Carl Zimmer This Ancient Whale May Have Been the Heaviest Animal EverPerucetus drifted through shallow seas like a gigantic manatee, scientists suspect.By Carl Zimmer ScreenlandWhat I Saw When I Looked Inside My Own BodyModern medicine is constantly showing us our guts and bones. Why doesn’t it feel more profound?By B.D. McClay Family of Henrietta Lacks Settles With Biotech Company That Used Her CellsMs. Lacks’s family had accused Thermo Fisher Scientific of profiting from her cells, which have contributed to revolutionary advances in medicine, without seeking their permission.By Amanda Holpuch OriginsA Theory of Childbirth’s Evolution May Not Be What You’re ExpectingScientists are revisiting an influential theory that the evolution of big brains made human childbirth risky.By Carl ZimmerLeer en español ‘A Dangerous Combination’: Teenagers’ Accidents Expose E-Bike RisksThe e-bike industry is booming, but many vehicles are not legal for teenagers, and accidents are on the rise.By Matt Richtel What Is an E-Bike, and How Safe Are They?Surprisingly tricky questions about an increasingly popular vehicle.By Matt Richtel AIDS Relief Program Under Threat as G.O.P. Insists on Abortion RestrictionA decades-old program created by President George W. Bush to combat AIDS around the world is at risk of being sucked into a partisan dispute over abortion, with some Republicans threatening to block its renewal.By Sheryl Gay Stolberg The EthicistMy Friend Is Trapped in a Nursing Home. What Can I Do?The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on helping people who are institutionalized against their will.By Kwame Anthony Appiah Louise Levy, Who Was Studied for Her Very Long Life, Is Dead at 112She was one of hundreds of people, all of them Ashkenazi Jews, whose good health and cognitive ability at extreme old age were the subject of genetic research.By Richard Sandomir AdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTFollow Us@nythealthtwitter page for @nythealthNYTimesSciencefacebook page for NYTimesScienceWellNYTfacebook page for WellNYT@nytimeswelltwitter page for @nytimeswellAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTSite IndexSite Information Navigation© 2023 The New York Times CompanyNYTCoContact UsAccessibilityWork with usAdvertiseT Brand StudioYour Ad ChoicesPrivacy PolicyTerms of ServiceTerms of SaleSite MapCanadaInternationalHelpSubscriptions

title: Real Estate - The New York Times
body: Skip to contentSkip to site indexSearch & Section NavigationSection NavigationSEARCHReal Estate Today’s PaperAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTSupported bySKIP ADVERTISEMENTReal EstateOn the MarketMortgage CalculatorAffordable Housing ToolLiving InThe HuntWhat You GetThe High EndHighlightsPhotoCreditJonathan CarlsonFeeling Mortgage-Rate Envy? You’re Not Alone.With interest rates climbing, a new form of one-upmanship is making the rounds: the mortgage-rate humble brag. By Ronda KaysenPhotoCreditMark ConlanAre You Ready to Buy a Home? Should You Rent? Take Our Quiz.Finances matter, of course, but so do your future plans, lifestyle, location and other factors. Answer a few questions to learn what may be best for you. By Debra KaminPhotoCreditHow To: Decorate an outdoor spaceIt’s August Already: Are You Making the Most of Your Patio or Terrace?Designers Christine and John Gachot should know how to furnish an outdoor space: Their rental has six. Here’s their step-by-step guide. By Tim McKeoughPhotoCreditChang W. Lee/The New York Timesbig ticketTwo $50 Million Deals in Lower Manhattan Lead the Top Sales in JulyA West Village penthouse sold for $52 million and a SoHo penthouse for $50 million. Also, Julia Koch and Alexis Stewart found buyers for their homes. By Vivian MarinoThe HuntPhotoCreditAndrea Mohin/The New York TimesSeeking a Perch Above Central Park for Less Than $800,000. Which Option Did They Choose?Two first-time buyers set their sights on Morningside Heights and South Harlem, aiming for a two-bedroom or large one-bedroom in an elevator building. By Joyce CohenOn the MarketPhotoCreditKelly RogersHomes for Sale in Manhattan and QueensThis week’s properties are in Hell’s Kitchen, the financial district and Astoria. By Heather SenisonOn the MarketPhotoCreditJohn DePrimaHomes for Sale in New Jersey and New YorkThis week’s properties are a four-bedroom house in Readington, N.J., and a five-bedroom in Katonah, N.Y. By Jill P. Capuzzo and Anne MancusoCalculatorPhotoCreditRent Increases Are Softening, but Not EverywhereRents are still up over last year in just over half of the 100 largest U.S. cities. By Michael KolomatskyIN THE GARDENPhotoCreditOliver CollinsPainting With Light: This Garden Shows How It’s DoneInnisfree, in Millbrook, N.Y., “doesn’t look like other gardens.” That’s by design. By Margaret RoachWhat You GetPhotoCreditBrittany Schones, Williamson Group Sotheby's International Realty$1.2 Million Homes in Vermont, New York and OhioA saltbox house with an attached 1830 barn in Hartland, a two-bedroom condominium in a 1914 building in Brooklyn and a Tudor Revival house in Akron. By Angela SerratoreLiving inPhotoCreditTony Cenicola/The New York TimesOld Saybrook, Conn.: A Quiet Shoreline Town With Relatively Low TaxesThis Middlesex County community was once a place “where middle-class people built cottages.” Now cash buyers are winning bidding wars. By Lisa PrevostAt Home WithPhotoCreditEric Striffler for The New York TimesJose Llana (a.k.a. Ferdinand Marcos) Makes a Home in the HamptonsWhen he’s not performing in “Here Lies Love,” a musical about the Philippines’s infamous first couple, this Broadway star finds refuge outside the city. By Joanne KaufmanWhat You GetPhotoCreditPierre Galant$2 Million Homes in CaliforniaA shingled home in Altadena, a golf-course retreat in Costa Mesa and a ‘Tree House’ in San Luis Obispo. By Angela SerratorerentersPhotoCreditAndrea Mohin/The New York TimesHow the Monotony of Sunny California Made New York ShineA couple who mainly thought of the city as a vacation spot learned the hard way that finding an apartment there was anything but boring. By Lia PicardAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTAsk Real EstateMore in Ask Real Estate ›PhotoCreditNadia PillonRent-Controlled vs. Rent-Stabilized: How Much Can a Landlord Charge?Owners of the city’s roughly 16,000 rent-controlled homes can raise the rent, but only so often, and only by so much. By Jill Terreri RamosPhotoCreditNadia PillonWhat’s the Best Way to Buy My Rental Condo From the Landlord?Due diligence is required, but a private sale such as this can have advantages. By Jill Terreri RamosPhotoCreditNadia PillonMy Building Manager Wants to Get on My Renter’s Insurance. Is That Legal?It depends on what kind of apartment you rent. And it may actually be a good idea. By Andy NewmanPhotoCreditNadia PillonMy Apartment Is Infested With Bugs. How Do I Make My Landlord Fix It?There are numerous ways you can pressure a landlord to take action. Sometimes it takes using all of them to get a result. By Ronda KaysenPhotoCreditNadia PillonWhich Repairs Are the Co-op’s Responsibility, and Which Are Mine?Start by reading your co-op’s proprietary lease, then move on to city law. By Jill Terreri RamosLiving InMore in Living In ›PhotoCreditTony Cenicola/The New York TimesOld Saybrook, Conn.: A Quiet Shoreline Town With Relatively Low TaxesThis Middlesex County community was once a place “where middle-class people built cottages.” Now cash buyers are winning bidding wars. By Lisa PrevostPhotoCreditTony Cenicola/The New York TimesEsopus, N.Y.: ‘Pristine Natural Surroundings’ and Stealth WealthThis Ulster County town is known for its nature preserves, waterfront homes and quietly affluent residents: ‘They’re not in-your-face flashy.’ By Karen AngelPhotoCreditRachel Vanni for The New York TimesHanover Township, N.J.: ‘A Nice, Family-Oriented Place’With good schools and relatively low property taxes, this Morris County community is popular with buyers. No surprise, then, that the market is tight. By Jill P. CapuzzoPhotoCreditTony Cenicola/The New York TimesGlastonbury, Conn.: A Friendly Community With Grand Historic HomesThe Hartford suburb draws residents with its bustling downtown, plentiful activities and long history (including a ferry established in 1655). By Lisa PrevostAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTFeatured PropertiesAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTFeatured PropertiesAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTLatestSearchSearchClear this text inputHow to Decorate an Outdoor SpaceDesigners Christine and John Gachot offer a step-by-step guide to decorating an outdoor space.By Tim McKeough Seeing the Light, at Innisfree GardenThis landscape, in Millbrook, N.Y., “doesn’t look like other gardens.” That’s by design. Living In ... Old Saybrook, Conn.This Middlesex County community was once a place “where middle-class people built cottages.” Now cash buyers are winning bidding wars here. At Home With Jose LlanaWhen he’s not performing in “Here Lies Love,” this Broadway star finds refuge in the Hamptons. Ask Real EstateMy 55+ Community Is Discriminating Against Me. What Power Do I Have?Start with the house rules, then consider getting a lawyer involved.By Jill Terreri Ramos A Tiny Cabin, a Little Island and a Big Change: ‘Am I Crazy?’A New Jersey woman now lives alone part of the year on a remote island in Maine that Stephen King called ‘a novel here, just waiting to be written.’By Steven Kurutz Living small‘Mr. Blandings’ Is Now 75. What Can His Dream House Tell Us About Ours?The 1948 film starring Cary Grant and Myrna Loy celebrated leaving city life and spreading out in suburbia. Even then, it was a questionable idea.By Julie Lasky On the MarketHomes for Sale in New York and ConnecticutThis week’s properties are a five-bedroom in Locust Valley, N.Y., and a four-bedroom in Wilton, Conn.By Claudia Gryvatz Copquin and Alicia Napierkowski On the MarketHomes for Sale in Manhattan and BrooklynThis week’s properties are on the Upper West Side, in Murray Hill and South Park Slope.By Heather Senison CalculatorHigh Interest Rates and Low Savings Could Put Renovations on HoldAs housing stock ages in the coming years, homeowners could face challenges financing needed renovations.By Michael Kolomatsky AdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTSite IndexSite Information Navigation© 2023 The New York Times CompanyNYTCoContact UsAccessibilityWork with usAdvertiseT Brand StudioYour Ad ChoicesPrivacy PolicyTerms of ServiceTerms of SaleSite MapCanadaInternationalHelpSubscriptions

title: Sports - The New York Times
body: Skip to contentSkip to site indexSearch & Section NavigationSection NavigationSEARCHSports Today’s PaperAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTSupported bySKIP ADVERTISEMENTSportsM.L.B.N.F.L.College FootballN.B.A.W.N.B.A.College BasketballN.H.L.SoccerGolfTennisScoreboardsM.L.B.N.F.L.College FootballN.B.A.W.N.B.A.College BasketballN.H.L.GolfTennisHighlightsPhotoCreditJapan Eliminates Norway to Earn Matchup With Sweden-U.S. WinnerSpain earned another spot in the quarterfinals with its defeat of Switzerland. PhotoCreditDarron Cummings/Associated PressThe Big Ten Lands Oregon and Washington, Leaving the Pac-12 BereftThe Big Ten booms to 18 schools with the move, powered by TV money, and the once-great Pac-12 dwindles to four after three more schools leave for the Big 12. By Billy WitzPhotoCreditAmir Hamja/The New York TimesThis Jazz Artist Makes Pro Football Hall of Fame Speeches SingWhen the Pro Football Hall of Fame’s inductees began to ramble, executives turned to Jezra Kaye to help them rein it in. By Ken BelsonPhotoCreditAshley Landis/Associated PressSimone Biles Set to Compete for First Time Since Tokyo OlympicsBiles, the decorated American gymnast, is making her return to elite competition on Saturday at the U.S. Classic. The field also includes Sunisa Lee, the reigning Olympic all-around champion. By Carla CorreaPhotoCreditCameron Spencer/Getty ImagesWorld Cup Picks Up Baton for Women’s Sports in AustraliaFor as long as there have been sports in Australia, women have clamored to play and participate. But winning visibility, and support, has been a long road. By Natasha FrostPhotoCreditHenry Nicholls/Agence France-Presse — Getty ImagesShe’s One of the Fastest Women Ever. All She’s Missing Is a Gold Medal.Marie-Josée Ta Lou of Ivory Coast has been milliseconds away from the top of Olympic and World Championship podium stands. She has a chance at redemption this month in Budapest. By Kris RhimOn SoccerPhotoCreditMarty Melville/Agence France-Presse — Getty ImagesAt the World Cup, the Field Thins and the Contenders ExpandAfter 48 games, half of the teams have been sent home. And yet it feels as if the field of potential winners is bigger than it was at the start. By Rory SmithPhotoCreditSaeed Khan/Agence France-Presse — Getty ImagesSpot the Ball: Women’s World CupThe Women’s World Cup has delivered stunning goals and shocking upsets. In these photos of the action, we’ve removed the ball. See if you can guess where it was. By Michael Beswetherick, Alastair Coote, Rumsey Taylor and Elijah WalkerPhotoCreditKyodo News, via Getty ImagesJapan’s Enduring ‘Sound of Summer’Created 75 years ago for the country’s prestigious high school baseball tournament, Yuji Koseki’s “The Crown Will Shine on You” stirs memories as it inspires new ones. By Brad LeftonPhotoCreditJenna Watson/Usa Today SportsInside U.S. Team, a Campaign to Avert Disaster Gets PersonalBlocking out criticism they call “noise,” Lindsey Horan and other veterans are taking a one-on-one approach to turning around their World Cup fortunes. By Juliet MacurQ. And A.PhotoCreditArmando Babani/EPA, via ShutterstockJan Frodeno Begins His Triathlon Farewell Tour. Up Next? More Risky Sports.Frodeno, 41, has dominating the triathlon since winning Olympic gold in 2008. This will be his last competitive season. By Matthew FuttermanSports of The TimesPhotoCreditI Gave Up on Boxing, Not on This BoxerDecades after turning away from the sport because of its violence, our columnist revisited Seniesa Estrada’s journey to becoming a champion — and wondered if it was worth the risk. By Kurt Streeter and Erin SchaffPhotoCreditHector Vivas/Getty ImagesGiven Plenty of Space, Lionel Messi Is Putting on a ShowMessi is scoring in bunches and last-place Inter Miami is a contender in the Leagues Cup. Could an M.L.S. playoff push be next? By Victor MatherPhotoCreditPhelan M. Ebenhack/Associated PressOrlando Magic’s Political Donation Is ‘Alarming,’ Players’ Union SaysThe team donated $50,000 to a super PAC supportive of Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida. The union said that does not mean Magic players support him. By Sopan DebAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTWomen’s World CupPhotoCreditWomen’s World Cup Bracket: The Knockout StageIt’s “win or go home” time in the Women’s World Cup knockout stage. Follow the latest scores and the bracket here. By The New York TimesPhotoCreditWomen's World Cup Schedule PromoWomen’s World Cup Schedule: Teams, Kickoff Times and TVPrepare for some late nights and some math: The Women’s World Cup will take place in multiple time zones in two countries. PhotoCreditAllison McCannWhy U.S. Players Will Get the Most Prize Money, Even if They LoseFIFA recommended a share of the pot for all World Cup players. But the U.S. women will outpace them all because of an agreement with U.S. Soccer. By Allison McCannPhotoCreditIllustration by Madison KetchamThe Curse Stalking Women’s SoccerThe World Cup is missing some of the sport’s biggest stars because of a knee injury epidemic. No one can say for sure why it’s happening, or how to fix it. By Rory SmithPhotoCreditAbbie Parr/Associated PressCovering the Women’s World Cup Takes Stamina and CoffeeJuliet Macur, a Sports reporter, is chasing the story of the U.S. national women’s soccer team at this year’s tournament. By Emmett LindnerLatestSearchSearchClear this text inputStudying the Limits of Human Perfection, Through DartsWhy do athletes always seem to get better, generation by generation? It’s not always for the reasons you might think.By Ben Blatt and Courtney Cox EncountersAfter Transitioning, Gabbi Tuft Pays a Visit to SmackdownShe was once a 250-pound gladiator in the World Wrestling Entertainment ring. Now she’s a TikTok star who’s building a new life.By Jacob Bernstein Spain, With Flourishes, Bounds Into QuarterfinalsSpain has been one of the strongest teams in the tournament. Next, it will play either the Netherlands or South Africa.By Andrew Das Eagles’ Josh Sills Acquitted on Rape and Kidnapping ChargesSills, 25, a Philadelphia Eagles offensive lineman, was indicted in Ohio in February.By Jesus Jiménez ‘Winning Time’ Is Back. Here’s What to Know Ahead of Season 2Season 1 of HBO’s series about the 1980s Lakers came with drama, in more ways than one. Expect more for Season 2. An N.B.A. reporter takes a look.By Tania Ganguli ‘Air Bud: World Pup’ Keeps Winning Fans for the 1999 World Cup StarsThe 2000 movie used the franchise’s furry hero along with members of the actual U.S. women’s team to reimagine the penalty shootout that led to the win.By Claire Fahy Morocco Wins, Then Waits, and Then Starts CelebratingMorocco had never won a game in the Women’s World Cup a week ago but now has won two in a row to advance to the knockout rounds.By Aida Alami and Andrew Das Spain’s Team Went to War. Now It Has to Win the Peace.A failed rebellion against Coach Jorge Vilda ended with a dozen players dropped for the Women’s World Cup. Those who remain might be good enough to win it.By Rory Smith Colombia and Germany try to lock down the last two round of 16 places.By Claire Fahy on pro basketballThe N.B.A. and Its Owners Fight for Change. But Not Necessarily the Same Change.The league embraces progressive causes supported by players. But some team owners pull in the opposite direction, as apparent in the Orlando Magic’s donation to Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida.By Sopan Deb AdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTFollow UsNYTSportstwitter page for NYTSportsAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTSite IndexSite Information Navigation© 2023 The New York Times CompanyNYTCoContact UsAccessibilityWork with usAdvertiseT Brand StudioYour Ad ChoicesPrivacy PolicyTerms of ServiceTerms of SaleSite MapCanadaInternationalHelpSubscriptions

title: Style - The New York Times
body: Skip to contentSkip to site indexSearch & Section NavigationSection NavigationSEARCHStyle Today’s PaperSupported bySKIP ADVERTISEMENTStyleFashionLoveSelf-CareHighlightsPhotoCreditJim Wilson/The New York Times‘Birds Are My Eyesight’For some blind birders, avian soundscapes are a way to map the world around them. Increasing noise pollution is imperiling that navigation. By Alexandra MarvarPhotoCreditAnna Moneymaker/Agence France-Presse — Getty ImagesDoes Anyone Care About Justin Trudeau’s Separation?A stable marriage (publicly at least) used to be a cornerstone of any world leader’s résumé. Not in 2023. By Elizabeth PatonPhotoCreditKyle GordonIt Happened OnlineA Mystery on the ‘Planet of the Bass’Is the ’90s Eurodance parody an ironic hit — or just a hit? By Callie Holtermann and Madison Malone KircherPhotoCreditMichelle V. Agins/The New York TimesThe Jell-O Shot RenaissanceAcross the country, bars are serving jiggly, alcoholic concoctions that are nothing like the college party version. By Alyson KruegerPhotoCreditClive Brunskill/Getty ImagesRoger Federer Is Having Fun in RetirementThe tennis star and Jonathan Anderson have teamed up with Uniqlo to create a sports-inspired fashion collection. By Alyson KruegerStyles Group ChatPhotoCreditCraig Blankenhorn/Max‘And Just Like That …’ Episode 8 Fashion: Losing the SpanxIn the new episode, Carrie and Aidan lean into their relationship, and Charlotte and Miranda start new jobs. By The Styles DeskPhotoCreditvia CameoStriking Actors Are Turning to Cameo for Extra CashOthers are using the service, through which fans can pay for personalized videos, to engage with followers while not publicly promoting work. By Perri Ormont BlumbergPhotoCreditUnderwood Archives/Getty ImagesBefore There Was Pee-wee, There Was PinkyPaul Reubens’s trademark style took plenty of its inspiration from a performer long forgotten. By Guy TrebaySocial Q’sPhotoCreditMiguel PorlanMy New Boyfriend Is a Dud at Buying Gifts. What Can I Do?A reader asks whether she should be more blunt about her wish for birthday and anniversary presents from a man who isn’t the gift-giving type. By Philip GalanesAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTIt Happened OnlineMore in It Happened Online ›PhotoCreditAlain Jocard/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images‘X’ Marks the SpotElon Musk’s decision to ditch the Twitter brand is confusing on many levels. By Madison Malone KircherPhotoCreditJenna Schoenefeld for The New York TimesAre Influencers on Strike Too?The Hollywood work stoppage could shake up your For You page. By Madison Malone KircherPhotoCreditDado Ruvic/ReutersThreads: An Early Vibe CheckIt’s early days, but more than 30 million users have signed up. PhotoCreditYuichi Yamazaki/Agence France-Presse — Getty ImagesShein’s Influencer FiascoHow the brand’s use of creators triggered a backlash. PhotoCredit@ahrenfnThe TikTok Search for the Titanic SubTragedies can be good business on social media. LoveMore in Love ›PhotoCreditKayleigh Taylor PhotographyWhile Navigating Life’s Changes, a Teenage Romance EnduresNeither Olivia Amitrano nor Nicholas Vazquez are afraid to change their minds, whether it’s about living off the grid, work or a wedding dress. By Jenny BlockPhotoCreditTrene' Forbes PhotographyHow to Find Wedding Vendors That Celebrate InclusionFor many couples, working with businesses that share their values and support people from diverse backgrounds is an important part of the planning process. By Sadiba HasanPhotoCreditDanielle HeinsonThe Looming Crisis in the Bridal Industry? Not Enough Seamstresses.The skilled professionals who work on wedding dress alterations play a crucial role for brides, but their numbers are dwindling. By Shannon SimsPhotoCreditB. Frohman Imaging and DesignA Recipe for Love? Add ‘Water and Sunlight.’Before meeting Jennifer Ziegler, Rebecca Woodfork said she was always “looking down and getting through life.” One month together in Boston and a trip to St. Lucia changed that. By Valeriya SafronovaPhotoCreditSerge GrenierFor Luck in Love, Couples Are Breaking Plates (On Purpose)In Germany, smashing porcelain plates is a time-honored wedding custom that is said to bring good fortune and harmony to newlyweds. By Alix StraussAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTLatestSearchSearchClear this text inputwedding albumWhat They Paid for Their WeddingsFormer brides reveal where they splurged and where they scrimped for their nuptials — and what (if anything) they would have done differently.By Bridgette Bartlett Royall EncountersAfter Transitioning, Gabbi Tuft Pays a Visit to SmackdownShe was once a 250-pound gladiator in the World Wrestling Entertainment ring. Now she’s a TikTok star who’s building a new life.By Jacob Bernstein episodeI Put On Lipstick for This?Lunch with an older friend prompts a writer to try some seemingly outdated stratagems for attracting a mate.By Rebecca Anne Nguyen Modern LoveDeseo más que un ‘Gracias, ¡que pase el siguiente!’Hacer audiciones para conseguir un papel en una serie o película tiene mucho en común con buscar una amistad o una pareja, sobre todo cuando te rechazan.By Jenny GorelickRead in English Love Letter: Honoring O’Shae Sibley at the Stonewall Inn“He was just a beautiful spirit, a wonderful person, just exercising his freedom to be alive.”By Miya Lee How To: Decorate an outdoor spaceIt’s August Already: Are You Making the Most of Your Patio or Terrace?Designers Christine and John Gachot should know how to furnish an outdoor space: Their rental has six. Here’s their step-by-step guide.By Tim McKeough Japan’s Enduring ‘Sound of Summer’Created 75 years ago for the country’s prestigious high school baseball tournament, Yuji Koseki’s “The Crown Will Shine on You” stirs memories as it inspires new ones.By Brad Lefton How to Decorate an Outdoor SpaceDesigners Christine and John Gachot offer a step-by-step guide to decorating an outdoor space.By Tim McKeough Modern LoveWould Marrying Her Be a Giant Mistake?I was warned not to marry outside my faith, but when Jillian was asleep in my bed, I would cry, unable to imagine a world without her.By Istiaq Mian mini-vowsThe Unlikely Run-In That Blossomed Into MoreDancers and musicians rarely cross paths at Juilliard, so a drag queen and a T-shirt brought Christopher Reynolds and John Hewitt together.By Aamina Khan AdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTFollow UsNYTimesStylesfacebook page for NYTimesStylesNYTStylestwitter page for NYTStylesNYTFashiontwitter page for NYTFashionNYTimesFashioninstagram page for NYTimesFashionAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTSite IndexSite Information Navigation© 2023 The New York Times CompanyNYTCoContact UsAccessibilityWork with usAdvertiseT Brand StudioYour Ad ChoicesPrivacy PolicyTerms of ServiceTerms of SaleSite MapCanadaInternationalHelpSubscriptions

title: Book Review - The New York Times
body:
Skip to contentSkip to site indexSearch & Section NavigationSection NavigationSEARCHBook Review Today’s PaperAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTSupported bySKIP ADVERTISEMENTArtsBook ReviewWhat to ReadStaff CriticsBest SellersBy the BookBook Review PodcastChildren's BooksHighlightsPhotoCreditChris Felver/Getty ImagesA Poem About Dance and the Hard Work of TranscendenceThe lessons of Rita Dove’s “American Smooth,” one of the best-loved poems of the last two decades. By Dwight GarnerPhotoCreditNoah Van SciverChildren’s BooksHow One Adman Created the American Fantasy of Paul BunyanIn W.B. Laughead’s 1916 logging industry pamphlet, a minor Midwestern folk hero underwent a major growth spurt. By Patricia Nelson LimerickPhotoCreditEditors’ choice9 New Books We Recommend This WeekSuggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times. PhotoCreditDavid M. Rubenstein Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Duke UniversityNonfictionThe Sea Captain Who Ran From Abraham LincolnIn “Shipwrecked,” the historian Jonathan W. White tells the story of an outlaw mariner who worked for the Confederacy and against the Klan. By Dorothy WickendenInside the best-seller ListPhotoCreditBrian KimsleyJennette McCurdy Now Qualifies as a Veteran Best SellerSome publishers balked at the title but, just shy of its first birthday, “I’m Glad My Mom Died” has stood the test of time. By Elisabeth EganVisualsPhotoCreditIn an Open Loft in Gowanus, Six Authors and Artists Collaborate and CommuneFor the children’s book creators Doug Salati, Brian Floca, Sophie Blackall, Rowboat Watkins, Johnny Marciano and Dasha Tolstikova, the light-filled space has become much more than just a place to work. By Elizabeth A. Harris and Adrianna GlavianoPhotoCreditRaphaelle MacaronRead Your Way Through HanoiHanoi, long a city of storytellers, has been devastated and reborn time and time again. Nguyễn Phan Quế Mai guides readers through the literature that has played a part in that renewal. By Nguyễn Phan Quế MaiPhotoCreditWhat Book Should You Read Next?Finding a book you’ll love can be daunting. Let us help. By The New York Times Books StaffPhotoCredit14 New Books Coming in AugustNovels from Ann Patchett and James McBride, a biography of the Chinese American movie star Anna May Wong and a handful of edgy thrillers — including one about a scuba driver swallowed by a whale. By The New York Times Books StaffAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTBooks of The TimesMore in Books of The Times ›PhotoCreditHow Four Female Philosophers Responded to a Dire Decade“The Visionaries,” by Wolfram Eilenberger, examines the divergent theories of self and other developed in a time of crisis by Hannah Arendt, Simone de Beauvoir, Ayn Rand and Simone Weil. By Jennifer SzalaiPhotoCreditOwen Gent‘Tom Lake’ Finds Ann Patchett in a Chekhovian MoodThis time the celebrated novelist spins the cozy tale of a former actress, her three daughters and their rueful memories. There’s a cherry orchard, too. By Alexandra JacobsPhotoCreditStories Like Norman Rockwell Paintings, if Rockwell Painted GuillotinesIn his new story collection, “Disruptions,” Steven Millhauser reveals the bizarre within the mundane. By Dwight GarnerPhotoCreditTony Luong for The New York TimesA New Arrival in ‘The Country of the Blind’In his memoir, Andrew Leland discovers that slowly losing one’s sight offers a special understanding of vision — and its limits. By Alexandra JacobsPhotoCreditDiego MalloAfter a Great Flood, a Struggle Between Faith and ReasonKhaled Khalifa’s new novel follows two friends through disaster and religious tension in early-20th-century Syria. By Dwight GarnerLatestSearchSearchClear this text inputFictionA Swedish Fever Dream of Literature and Love, Lost and FoundIn Ia Genberg’s “The Details,” the unnamed narrator spends the duration of an illness reflecting on her bygone relationships.By Catherine Lacey FictionNo Place Is Home, for the Immigrant Hero of This Debut Novel“Hangman,” by Maya Binyam, follows the narrator on a disorienting trip back to his native country.By Katie Kitamura A New Frontier for Travel Scammers: A.I.-Generated GuidebooksShoddy guidebooks are flooding Amazon. Their authors claim to be renowned travel writers, but are they A.I. inventions? And how big is the problem?By Seth Kugel and Stephen Hiltner Julia Scully, Influential Photography Editor and Memoirist, Dies at 94She oversaw Modern Photography for 20 years and wrote an acclaimed book about her rough-and-tumble childhood, some of it spent in an orphanage and in remote Alaska.By Richard Sandomir Ann Patchett on Summer Love and Her New NovelThe author discusses “Tom Lake,” bookstore secrets and the play “Our Town.” Paperback Row6 Paperbacks to Read This Week Selected paperbacks from the Book Review, including Paul Newman's memoir and novels by James Hannaham and Adam Levin.By Shreya Chattopadhyay Seiichi Morimura, 90, Who Exposed Japanese Wartime Atrocities, DiesIn a widely read book, he detailed gruesome biological experiments on people at a secret Imperial Army site in occupied China before and during World War II.By Richard Sandomir阅读简体中文版閱讀繁體中文版 Book ExcerptThe Playwright Who Changed the Face of American TheaterIn this excerpt from “August Wilson: A Life,” the playwright, on the cusp of stardom, is polishing off his latest play, “Fences,” at the O’Neill writers’ conference.By Patti Hartigan ‘The Notebook’ Musical to Land on Broadway in the SpringThe adaptation of the popular Nicholas Sparks romance novel, with music and lyrics by Ingrid Michaelson, had a well-reviewed run last year in Chicago.By Sarah Bahr The Art of Telling Forbidden Stories in ChinaMany writers are looking for ways to capture the everyday realities that the government keeps hidden — sometimes at their own peril.By Han Zhang AdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTBest Sellers
Book Review Podcast
